A few scholars , most prominently Christopher Beckwith and Roy Andrew Miller , argue that Chinese is not related to Tibeto-Burman .
In opposition to this view , scholars in favor of the Sino-Tibetan hypothesis such as W. South Coblin , Graham Thurgood , James Matisoff , and Gong Hwang-cherng have argued that there are regular correspondences in sounds as well as in grammar .
The Sino-Tibetan languages form a language family composed of , at least , the Chinese and the Tibeto-Burman languages , including some 250 languages of East Asia .
They are second only to the Indo-European languages in terms of their number of speakers .
They point to an absence of regular sound correspondences , an absence of reconstructable shared morphology , and evidence that much shared lexical material has been borrowed from Chinese into Tibeto-Burman .

Bright 's disease is a historical classification of kidney diseases that would be known in modern medicine as acute or chronic nephritis .
The term is no longer used , as diseases are now classified by their more fully known etiologies .

The Joy of Giving Week -LRB- JGW -RRB- , planned for Sept 27 - Oct 3 , 2009 as a national movement , aims at engaging at least one crore Indians in different `` acts of giving '' - money , time , resources and skills - spanning the corporate , NGO and government sectors , schools , colleges and the general public . The idea is to create a `` festival of philanthropy '' that can , over the years , become a part of the Indian ethos , with the Week being celebrated every year covering Gandhi Jayanti .
7Days7Gifts , a simple idea where people will be encouraged to do random acts of kindness to people they donâ t know for every day of the week .
The initiative is being led by JAM Magazine and is being supported by MTV .
A `` College Joyfest '' that hopes to have 300 + college campuses in India partner with local NGOs to hold cultural festivals that promote awareness and sensitivity among youth , while also being fundraisers for the partner NGOs .
Goonj runs a unique Vastradaan initiative that provides clothes and other amenities to the far flung villages , collecting on an average 20,000 kg or about 1.2 lac units of clothing every month , process it and distribute it through a unique clothes for work program .
Several corporates , celebrities and organizations have already finalized their efforts towards awareness , volunteering and fundraising events that they will organize during the Joy of Giving Week .
For the Joy of Giving Week , Goonj is undertaking a massive Clothes Collection Drive in over 25 cities , targeting to collect at least 1 crore units of clothing during the Week .
Presented by Riverside School in Ahmedabad , NID , Stanford Design School and IDEO -LRB- the world 's # 1 design firm -RRB- , in partnership with hundreds of educational NGOs and schools across India .
The Design for Giving School Contest will inspire children aged 10-13 from over 10,000 private and government schools all over India to design solutions to India 's problems and implement them during the Week .
`` Battle of the Buffet '' events by the 5 star Hotels in Chennai and Hyderabad , where they provide their most lavish spreads free of cost to NGOs of the city , who work together as a city and sell donor passes to raise funds for their work .

The Earl Marshal , a hereditary office held by the Duke of Norfolk , oversees the College , but he is not a member .
A partial exception to this rule is the case of a woman who has no brothers , or whose brothers have no children ; such a woman is called a heraldic heiress and may transmit the arms to her children as a quartering with their father 's arms , and to their descendents .
There are , three levels of officers of arms : Kings of Arms , Heralds , and Pursuivants .
The Earl Marshal 's court -LRB- called the Court of Chivalry -RRB- can hear cases about using coats arms , but the court has not sat since 1954 .
The officers of arms occupy posts bearing traditional titles :
The Kings of Arms grant coats of arms by letters patent . Before they can even consider the granting of arms , an application , -LRB- called a memorial -RRB- must be made to the Earl Marshal , and a fee paid .
Although daughters and sons inherit the right to bear arms for themselves personally , the right passes only through the male line : hence , a son transmits the arms to his children , but a daughter , can use them herself , but her children can not .
If it does proceed , its success or otherwise will depend on the approval of the Earl Marshal , who may apply his own standards .
Before they can even consider the granting of arms , an application , -LRB- called a memorial -RRB- must be made to the Earl Marshal , and a fee paid .
-LRB- Scotland has its own heraldic authority : Lord Lyon King of Arms and his office . -RRB-
In 1616 , Ralphe Brooke , York Herald , tricked the Garter King of Arms into granting a coat of arms to the common hangman for a fee of 22 shillings -LRB- Â # 1-20p -RRB- .
The applicant does not buy a coat of arms : the arms themselves are freely given , but fees must be paid to the heralds and artists involved as professionals , and to support the buildings and other running costs of the College .
For these public appearances , the officers of the college wear costume showing their place in the Royal Household , either simple red livery or the herald 's traditional colourful outfit of a tabard emblazoned with his master 's arms -LRB- in this case the royal arms -RRB- .
If a herald is approached and does not consider that the application has merit , he may tactfully suggest to the applicant that he or she should not proceed .
The college is involved in genealogy and have many pedigrees -LRB- family trees -RRB- in their records .
William IV reduced them to the old level in the 1830s .
The Kings of Arms grant coats of arms by letters patent .

The officers of arms earn money from their own private practices in heraldry and genealogy . They get only nominal salaries as officers of the College .
The College of Arms does not need to approve the use of the arms in each generation : the original grant of arms is the only authority required .

Since the heralds get fees for granting arms , they have always been generous when deciding who should be allowed a coat of arms .
The coat of arms , or a differenced version of them using marks of cadency , can be used by all of the legitimate children of an individual and such children and their descendants may bear the arms -LRB- or a differenced version of them -RRB- from the moment of birth : they do not have to wait for the death of the previous generation .

Many years ago , when the use of instrumental music was growing , trumpets became very important . Trumpets were long and without valves .
A trumpet is a brass instrument used mainly in Classical music and jazz music . The most common type of trumpet is a Bb trumpet , meaning that if the player plays a C , it will sound like a Bb in concert pitch .
The chromatic trumpet was developed in the late 18th century . Later on , valves were developed , and it became easier to play notes on the trumpet .

Louder Than Live is a home video released by the Seattle grunge band Soundgarden featuring songs performed live at the Whisky a Go Go in Los Angeles , California on December 7 , 1989 and December 10 , 1989 .
The vinyl includes the 5 live tracks from the video in addition to `` Beyond the Wheel '' .
This album has been bootlegged on black vinyl ; genuine copies can be distinguished by the A&M logo .
It features five live tracks filmed during the Louder Than Love tour .
It is on this video that frontman Chris Cornell is seen wearing his infamous silver duct-tape shorts .
The live tracks are `` Get on the Snake '' , `` Gun '' , `` I Awake '' , `` Big Dumb Sex '' , and a medley of Spinal Tap 's `` Big Bottom '' and Cheech & Chong 's `` Earache My Eye '' , with footage from both concerts mixed together .
The center label features a close-up picture of guitarist Kim Thayil 's face .
Louder Than Live was released on VHS only , with no official DVD version available .
Hemoglobin -LRB- also spelled hemoglobin -RRB- is a protein in the blood which contains Iron and is used to transport oxygen around the body .
Hemoglobin is made from three parts : a heme molecule , a globin chain , and an iron atom .
When hemoglobin has oxygen in it , its called oxyhemoglobin .
Hemoglobin are found in the red blood cells .

Past episodes of melting and volcanism at the outer levels of the mantle have produced a very thin crust of crystallized melt products near the surface , where we live .
The gases evolved during the melting of Earth 's mantle have a large effect on the composition and size of Earth 's atmosphere .
It lies about three kilometres under the ocean surface and covers thousands of square kilometres .
A thin crust , the upper part of the lithosphere , surrounds the mantle and is about 5 to 75 km thick .
In 2007 a team of scientists on board the RRS James Cook went to an area of the Atlantic seafloor where the mantle has no crust covering .
It is called the asthenosphere , and is composed of flowing rock in the state of plasticity , about 200 km thick , and the lowermost part of the lithosphere , composed of rigid rock , about 50 to 120 km thick .
The uppermost mantle plus overlying crust are relatively rigid and form the lithosphere , an irregular layer with a maximum thickness of perhaps 200 km , of which the uppermost mantle is 120 to 50 km thick .

The Akkadian language was made the official language of international discourse .
He is sometimes regarded as the first person in recorded history to create a multiethnic , centrally ruled empire , although the Sumerians Lugal-anne-mundu and Lugal-zage-si also have a claim .
During Sargon 's reign , Akkadian was standardized and adapted for use with the cuneiform script , which was previously used for the Sumerian language .
He ruled from a new capital , Akkad , which the Sumerian king list claims he built on the left bank of the Euphrates .
Sargon 's vast empire is known to have extended from Elam to the Mediterranean Sea , including Mesopotamia , parts of modern-day Iran and Syria , and possibly parts of Anatolia and the Arabian peninsula .

Jazz piano is a word for the ways pianists play jazz . The piano has been an important part of the jazz , in both solo and group settings .
For this reason it is also an important tool in the understanding of jazz theory and arranging for jazz musicians and composers .
Jazz piano is a word for the ways pianists play jazz .
The piano has been an important part of the jazz , in both solo and group settings .
Its role is one of the biggest . This is because of the instrument 's combined melodic and harmonic nature .
Together with the guitar , vibraphone , and other keyboard instruments , the piano is one of the few instruments in a jazz combo which can play chords , instead of only single notes -LRB- as with the saxophone or trumpet -RRB- .

An area of disturbed weather , related to Tropical Depression Eight , moved across the northwest Caribbean Sea and the Yucatan Peninsula .
The system became better-organized and when the depression moved into the Gulf of Mexico , it was absorbed by a non-tropical system on 30th .
The storm weakened quickly to a tropical depression , which then moved around Georgia and Alabama until it dissipated on July 7 .
The 1994 Atlantic hurricane season was the time from June 1 to November 30 , 1994 when hurricanes officially formed in the Atlantic Ocean .
A tropical wave moved into the area , causing an increase in showers and cloudiness .
However in this season no Tropical Cyclone formed after November 30 , the end of the season because the last storm , Hurricane Gorden died on November 21 just nine days before the 30th .
The wave was upgraded into a depression on August 29 near the Yucatan Peninsula .
Tropical Storm Alberto continued north , making landfall near Destin , Florida on July 3 as a moderately strong tropical storm .
Tropical Depression Eight made landfall in Mexico and dissipated the next day over Guatemala .
The strongest , Hurricane Florence , it 's top winds were at a Category 2 storm with winds of 110 mph -LRB- 175 km\/h -RRB- . Aside from Chris , Florence , and Gordon , none of the storms became hurricanes .
The season was unusual in that it produced no major hurricanes , which are those of Category 3 status or higher on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale .
The wave that would become Tropical Depression Five was tracked beginning on August 17 .
Tropical Depression Nine form off the coast of Africa on September 26 .
Tropical Depression Eight formed on September 19 in the southwestern Caribbean Sea . The wave strengthened into Tropical Depression Eight on September 24 near Honduras .

A platform game , or platformer , is a genre of video game . Platformer gameplay is about jumping between platforms or over obstacles .
The player controls these jumps and must use skill to avoid their character falling off of platforms or missing jumps .
Games where jumping is not controlled by the player , such as The Legend of Zelda : Ocarina of Time , are not thought of as platform games .

The patents will expire in 2010 -- 2011 .
IDEA can be used with the OpenPGP standard .
Each of the eight round uses six sub-keys , while the half-round uses four ; for a total of 52 sub-keys . Each sub-key is a 16-bit in length .
IDEA operates on 64-bit blocks , using a 128-bit key . It contains a series of eight identical transformations -LRB- rounds -RRB- and one output transformation -LRB- the half-round -RRB- .
IDEA derives much of its security by interleaving operations from different groups -- modular addition and multiplication , and bitwise eXclusive OR -LRB- XOR -RRB- -- which are chosen to be `` algebraically incompatible '' .
The processes for encryption and decryption are similar .
As of 2007 , the best attack which applies to all keys can break IDEA if reduced to 6 rounds -LRB- the full IDEA cipher uses 8.5 rounds -RRB- .
-LRB- Applied Cryptography , 2nd ed . -RRB-
In 1996 , Bruce Schneier wrote about IDEA , `` In my opinion , it is the best and most secure block algorithm available to the public at this time . ''
The designers analyzed IDEA to measure its strength against differential cryptanalysis and concluded that it is unsusceptible only under certain assumptions .
However , by 1999 he was no longer recommending IDEA due to the availability of faster cryptographic algorithms , some progress in its cryptanalysis , and the issue of patents .
Today , IDEA is licensed worldwide by a company called MediaCrypt .
In cryptography , the International Data Encryption Algorithm -LRB- IDEA -RRB- is a block cipher designed by Xuejia Lai and James Massey of ETH Zurich in 1991 .
IDEA very like an earlier cipher called Proposed Encryption Standard -LRB- PES -RRB- , but with some improvements . Because of this , IDEA was first called IPES -LRB- Improved PES -RRB- .
IDEA was used in Pretty Good Privacy -LRB- PGP -RRB- v2 .0 after the cipher used in v1 .0 , BassOmatic , was found to be breakable .
The first eight sub-keys are extracted directly from the 128-bit key , with K1 being the lowest sixteen bits and K8 is the highest sixteen bits ; further groups of eight keys are created by rotating the main key left 25 bits after the creation of the previous group ; six rotations generate all sub-keys .
The cipher is patented in a number of countries but can be used by anyone for non-commercial use .
The name `` IDEA '' is also a trademark .
It was meant to be a replacement for the Data Encryption Standard .

The concept of context assumes significance in the case of interruptible tasks , wherein upon being interrupted the processor saves the context and proceeds to serve the Interrupt service routine .
In computer science , a task context -LRB- process , thread ... -RRB- is the minimal set of data used by this task that must be saved to allow a task interruption at a given date , and a continuation of this task at the point it has been interrupted and at an arbitrary future date .

The plant 's sharp taste is due to oxalic acid , which is a poison .

Madison sought to accomplish this by demonstrating conclusively that the Acts violated the constitution .
Jefferson eagerly sought copies for distribution to Republican members of Congress departing for their home states , and when they failed to arrive he entreated Monroe for at least one copy that he could reproduce .
Parties outside Virginia seemed uninterested in the rehashing of the 1798 Resolutions , and in other states there was very little public comment .
Other cases to cite the Report for a similar purpose include Thornhill v. Alabama -LRB- 1940 -RRB- and Nixon v. Shrink Missouri Government PAC -LRB- 2000 -RRB- .
The general purpose of the Report was the affirmation and expansion of the principles in the Virginia Resolutions .
In the 1957 Roth v. United States opinion by William Brennan , Madison 's Report is cited as evidence that `` the fundamental freedoms of speech and press have contributed greatly to the development and well-being of our free society and are indispensable to its continued growth . ''
As well , Madison attacked Federalist carriage laws and bank laws as unconstitutional .
In defense of Virginia Republicans and the Resolutions , Madison emphasized that even if one disagreed with the compact theory , the Virginia Resolutions and the Report of 1800 themselves were simply protests , which states were surely entitled to produce .
Madison thought the Resolutions and Report were consistent with this principle while the Ordinance of Nullification was not .
Though it had little impact on the immediate election , Madison 's Report clarified the legal argument against the Acts and for states ' rights in general , particularly in its advancement of the Tenth Amendment rather than the Ninth as the main bulwark against federal encroachment on state autonomy .
The arguments made in the Resolutions and the Report were later used frequently during the nullification crisis of 1832 , when South Carolina declared federal tariffs to be unconstitutional and void within the state .
To remedy the defects revealed by the passage of the Alien and Sedition Acts , Madison called for citizens to have an absolute right to free speech .
Freedom of the press was necessary , because `` chequered as it is with abuses , the world is indebted to the press for all the triumphs which have been gained by reason and humanity over error and oppression . ''
Contrary to the Sedition Act , the federal government had no power to protect officials from dissent or libelous attack , beyond the protection it accorded to every citizen ; indeed , such special intervention against the press was `` expressly forbidden by a declaratory amendment to the constitution . ''
Madison won over Jefferson , who shortly thereafter wrote to Wilson Cary Nicholas that : `` From -LRB- this position -RRB- I retreat readily , not only in deference to -LRB- Madison 's -RRB- judgment but because as we should never think of separation but for repeated and enormous violations , so these , when they occur , will be cause enough of themselves . ''
The measure came before the House of Delegates , the lower house of the General Assembly , on January 2 .
These replies contended that the Supreme Court of the United States had the ultimate responsibility for deciding whether federal laws were constitutional , and that the Alien and Sedition Acts were constitutional and necessary .
However , James Monroe , who would become Governor of Virginia before the end of the year , visited Jefferson at Monticello and cautioned him against meeting with Madison , since another meeting between two of the most important Republican leaders would provoke significant public comment .
The state governments themselves , no less than the federal judiciary , possess only delegated power and therefore can not decide questions of fundamental importance .
This resolution had been the principal target of the Federalist attack on the Resolutions .
Particularly at issue was the sense in which the states were parties to the federal compact .
The basic message was that the states were the ultimate parties constituting the federal compact , and that therefore the individual states were ultimate arbiters of whether the compact had been broken by the usurpation of power .
The Report was received warmly by Virginia Republicans .
The Alien Act granted the President the unenumerated power of deporting friendly aliens .
The most significant of these were the Alien and Sedition Acts , four laws that allowed the President to deport aliens at will , required a longer period of residence before aliens could become citizens , and made it a crime to publish malicious or defamatory material against the government or its officials .
Henry Clay said on the floor of the House of Representatives that it was from the Report of 1800 , above other documents , that he had developed his own theories on constitutional interpretation .
At the time , leading Virginia Republican figures such as Rep. William Branch Giles -LRB- in public -RRB- and Sen. John Taylor of Caroline -LRB- in private -RRB- actually were contemplating disunion , and the Virginia General Assembly chose this juncture for finally constructing a new state armory in Richmond , so there was some truth to the charge .
They were `` expressions of opinion , unaccompanied with any other effect than what they may produce on opinion by exciting reflection . ''
The Resolutions , usually discussed together with Thomas Jefferson 's contemporaneous Kentucky Resolutions , were a response to various perceived outrages perpetrated by the Federalist-dominated national government .
According to Kevin Gutzman , the Report , together with the Kentucky and Virginia Resolutions , forms a foundation for the `` radical southern states ' rights tradition . ''
The first major goal of the Resolutions was to bring about the repeal of the Alien and Sedition Acts by generating public opposition that would be expressed through the state legislatures .
The General Assembly arranged for five thousand copies to be printed and distributed in the state , but there was not much public response to the Report , and it appears to have had relatively little impact on the presidential election of 1800 -LRB- which was , nevertheless , a major victory for the Republicans and a repudiation of Federalist policies -RRB- .
Jefferson underlined the importance of this work in a November 26 letter to Madison in which he identified `` protestations against violations of the true principles of our constitution '' as one of the four primary elements of the Republican Party plan .
The Virginia General Assembly adopted the Report in January 1800 . The document primarily subtly amends arguments from the 1798 Virginia Resolutions .
Madison writes that the ability to prosecute speech amounts to `` a protection of those who administer the government , if they should at any time deserve the contempt or hatred of the people , against being exposed to it . ''
In more recent years , the main practical interest in the Report has been its absolutist understanding of the First Amendment .
H. Jefferson Powell , a modern jurist , identifies three persistent themes of Republican constitutionalism which emerged from the Resolutions and the Report : -LRB- 1 -RRB- a textual approach to the Constitution , -LRB- 2 -RRB- the compact theory , and -LRB- 3 -RRB- that caution , not trust , should characterize our approach to those who hold political power .
A major item on his agenda was the defense of the General Assembly 's 1798 Virginia Resolutions , of which Madison had been the draftsman .
The Report of 1800 , Madison argued , did not say the government was a compact of the individual states , as the pro-nullification elements suggested .
Multiple Supreme Court decisions have cited the case as evidence of the Framers ' ideas on free speech .
The reason for the criticism was that the General Assembly , led in the effort by state-sovereignty advocate John Taylor of Caroline , had put a state-sovereignty spin on the Virginia Resolutions of 1798 despite Madison 's hopes .
The Report of 1800 was a resolution drafted by James Madison . It argued for the sovereignty of the individual states under the United States Constitution and against the Alien and Sedition Acts .
However , Madison rebuffed charges that his writings supported the constitutional interpretation advanced by pro-nullification Southerners .
Once at Richmond , Madison began drafting the Report , though he was delayed by a weeklong battle with dysentery .
The Report was regarded in the early 19th century as among the more important expressions of Republican principles .
In modern scholarship outside the legal arena the Report is mostly studied for its discussion of states ' rights with regard to federalism and republicanism .
The Virginia Resolutions had in the year since publication received highly critical replies from state legislatures , including those of New York , Delaware , and the five New England states .
Madison , a member of the Republican Party , was elected to the Republican-dominated Virginia General Assembly from Orange County in 1799 .
Despite Jefferson 's approval of and attempt to distribute Madison 's work , the national reaction was tepid .
Their discussion was important in that it persuaded Jefferson to depart from his radical stance on dissociation from the Union , which is expressed at the end of the excerpt above .
The Assembly session began in early December .
The Federalists accused the Republicans of seeking disunion , even contemplating violence .
Republicans were outraged by the legislation , and Madison and Jefferson drafted the highly critical Resolutions adopted in response by the Virginia and Kentucky state legislatures .
Rather the Report of 1800 described a compact of `` the people in each of the States , acting in their highest sovereign capacity . ''
The Report was the last important explication of the Constitution produced before the 1817 Bonus Bill Veto Message .
More generally , the Report made the argument in favor of the sovereignty of the individual states , for which it is best known .
The Report was ultimately amended to provide greater clarity on this issue by emphasizing that it was the people themselves , acting through the states in their sovereign capacity , who were parties to the Constitution .
Adrienne Koch and Harry Ammon , examining Jefferson 's later writing , conclude that Madison had a significant role `` in softening Jefferson 's more extreme views . ''
This doctrine is known as the compact theory .
At the very least , Virginia or Kentucky taking such a stance publicly would have justified the Federalist attacks against the secessionist tendencies of the Republicans .
The committee members were Madison , John Taylor , William Branch Giles , George Keith Taylor , John Wise , John Mercer , and William Daniel .
At some point in the next two weeks , it passed the Senate by a margin of 15 to 6 .
Spencer Roane described it as `` the Magna Charta on which the republicans settled down , after the great struggle in the year 1799 . ''
On December 23 , Madison moved for the creation of a special seven-member committee with himself as chairman to respond to `` certain answers from several of the states , relative to the communications made by the Virginia legislature at their last session . ''
Either formulation would help the Republican cause by refuting the finality of any constitutional interpretation advanced by the Congress and federal judiciary , both of which were dominated by Federalists .
The Report supported a strict interpretation of the First Amendment .
The amended Report passed the House of Delegates on January 7 by a margin of 60 to 40 .
In response to this letter , Madison visited Jefferson at Monticello during the first week of September .
The task of writing the Virginia Report was left solely to Madison .
Jefferson hoped for further involvement with the production of the Report and planned to visit Madison at Montpelier on his way to Philadelphia , the national capital , for the winter session of the United States Congress .
While the Federalists interpreted the amendment as limiting the power of Congress over the press , but implying that such power existed , Madison argued that the First Amendment wholly prohibited Congress from any interference with the press .
Whether Madison 's theory of republicanism really supported the nullification movement , and more broadly whether the ideas he expressed between 1798 and 1800 are consistent with his work before and after this period , are the main questions surrounding the Report in the modern literature .
Madison , however , rejected the concept of nullification and the notion that his arguments supported such a practice .
It was the presence of this argument in the Resolutions that had allowed the Federalists to paint the Republicans as leaning toward secession ; in the amended Report the line is moderated , with an emphasis that it is the states as political societies of the people -LRB- and therefore , one reads in , not the state legislatures alone -RRB- which possess this power .

The next day , Christmas Eve , the committee produced a first version of the Report .
By eschewing direct action in favor of influencing popular opinion , Madison tried to make clear that the Republicans were not moving toward disunion .

Craigslist is a centralized network of online communities for free classified advertisements -LRB- with jobs , internship , housing , personal advertisements , erotic services , for sale\/barter\/wanted , services , community , and pets categories -RRB- and forums on various topics .
With over thirty million new classified advertisements each month , Craigslist is the leading classifieds service in any medium .
The service was founded in 1995 by Craig Newmark for the San Francisco Bay Area .
The site receives over two million new job listings each month . So it is one of the top job boards in the world .

In 1994 and 1995 more and more bands in the genre appeared from different places in Europe and also in Israel .
This music genre is a mixture of heavy metal and traditional folk music .
The Irish band Cruachan was one of these early bands , and so were the bands Orphaned Land , from Israel , and the German band Subway to Sally . Each band started to develop their own styles of folk metal and these styles became Celtic metal , Oriental metal and Medieval metal .
Folk metal is a subgenre of heavy metal music that started in Europe in the 1990s .
A few bands also use keyboards to make the sound of folk instruments .
Each band started to develop their own styles of folk metal and these styles became Celtic metal , Oriental metal and Medieval metal .
Lyrics in Folk metal are normally about nature , fantasy , mythology and history .
The earliest example of folk metal was the English band Skyclad .
Their first album The Wayward Sons of Mother Earth was made in 1990 .
Folk instruments are used a lot and sometimes traditional singing styles are also used .
The music of Folk metal is very diverse . Different bands perform a lot of different styles .

Each of these variants can bind to a different antigen .
Each tip of the `` Y '' of an antibody contains a structure -LRB- like a lock -RRB- that fits one particular key-like structure on an antigen . This binds the two structures together .
The production of antibodies is the main function of the humoral immune system .
Several complex genetic mechanisms have evolved . These allow vertebrate B cells to generate a huge pool of antibodies from a relatively small number of antibody genes .
The antibody recognizes a unique part of the foreign target called an antigen .
Actually , humans generate about 10 billion different antibodies , each capable of binding a distinct antigen site .
This enormous diversity of antibodies allows the immune system to recognize an equally wide variety of antigens .
Using this binding mechanism , an antibody can tag a microbe or an infected cell for attack by other parts of the immune system , or can neutralize its target directly .
Though the general structure of all antibodies is very similar , that small region at the tip of the protein is extremely variable . This allows millions of antibodies with different tip structures to exist .

The noun Anglican is used to describe the people , institutions and churches as well as the liturgical traditions and theological concepts developed by the state established Church of England and the Anglican Communion , a theologically broad and often divergent affiliation of thirty-eight provinces that are in communion with the Archbishop of Canterbury .
The term Anglican derives from a Medieval Latin phrase dating to at least 1246 - ecclesia anglicana - meaning ` the English Church ' .

In ancient Egypt , when the Nile River overflowed its banks and washed out farm boundaries , the boundaries were recreated by surveyors using simple geometry .
These points are usually , but not always , associated with positions on the surface of the Earth . They are often used to make land maps and boundaries for ownership of land .
Surveying has existed throughout much of our history .
Surveying is the technique and science of accurately finding out the position of points and the distances and angles between them .
Surveying has been very important in the development of the human environment since the beginning of recorded history -LRB- ca .
Its most common uses are in the fields of transport , building and construction , communications , mapping , and the making of legal boundaries for land ownership .

language , affectionately known as `` wikipuke '' .
: : : -LRB- This essay is a draft to be expanded later . -RRB-
Well , perhaps the users and article editors might find the coding steps somewhat annoying , adding the '' '' bar , just to avoid producing quoteboxes .
Rather than maintaining some basic , core levels of simplicity , the multiple nerdisms start interfering with earlier peculiar features , and the result becomes conflicting nerdisms with almost unpredictable , expanding quirks .
Do n't design coding as quotebox .
The exact causes , behind each quirk , are perhaps too complex to explain in this essay .
Perhaps the world is seeing a rapid growth in the rise of `` nerdnology '' as typical notions of quality control have been abandoned , almost everywhere .
Instead , the quirks are not the work of college-dropout billionaires , but rather just a collection of misdirected changes .
So even an organization with $ billions of revenue can not seem to avoid utterly spastic , peculiar quirks in their webpages .
In the second use of `` Mytemplate '' , the value of param1 is only `` aaa '' because the vertical-bar -LRB- or pipe -RRB- '' '' stopped param1 from including the line-break newline .
Kids do n't do this .
Those preferences could be set to overcome some design flaws in the basic design of a system -LRB- such as a browser -RRB- , until the more normal settings are preset as the defaults in later software versions .
For example , in some mainsteam browsers :
, some really bizarre features are added , such as allowing wiki-templates to pass newlines at the end of parameter values , simply by indenting the next line , when calling a template .
Unfortunately , `` one man 's bizarreness is other man 's ordinary dork-otopia '' and some developers think that everyone should change their ways to adjust to the new stuff .
Even Google Inc. , with all the $ billions , has had some very unusual things happening in the official websites -LRB- for years -RRB- :
Overly often , peculiar ideas are treated as mainstream `` everyone-should-know-nerdisms '' which become some of the widespread quirks that appear , from day to day .
Ah so , oh-so-important quotebox he look like : Me is quotebox â `` I so cool , so important .
This essay , WP : Avoiding Wikipedia quirks , is intended to try to explain what is happening , hourly , to the Wikipedia system , and to suggest work-around solutions .
Wikipedia 's underlying software system , with the MediaWiki markup language , is constantly being changed to fix old problems and try to offer new , better features , but better for whom ?
Not all problems are caused by Wikipedia 's software configuration .
However , along with that stuff , there is a 2nd language as wikitable codes -LRB- in Table -RRB- , so that a table begins with '' '' which formerly were required in column 1 but can be indented now -LRB- at least sometimes , or maybe not whatever -RRB- .
Everything is changing , without warning , and lots of it is quirky .
The most normal language is the typical free-flowing text that allows triple-quote ` bold-font ' , along with the HTML tags , such as .
In the first use of `` Mytemplate '' , the value of param1 can be considered to be `` xxx '' because the coding was split , with param2 -LRB- value `` yyy '' -RRB- on the 2nd line .
Normally , bizarre features would be designed to require special coding to trigger those features , such as : if you want to pass newlines in parameter values , then specify them , explicitly , such as `` param = aa # nuline ; bb # nuline ; cc # nuline ; '' where the code '' # nuline ; '' or '' '' -LRB- or some other invented thing -RRB- is the feature to be requested .
No longer are major changes tested on a sample user-group , but instead , released untested to the entire world .
However , imagine the stress on the Wikipedia developers , having to ensure that any changes or enhancements , to the MediaWiki interfaces , must continue to work as before , generating the same demented , peculiar sets of quotebox indentations , everywhere they had popped up before .
By considering the design flaws , and the operational instability , it is possible to get a better understanding of the psychological pressures that people face when using Wikipedia .
In advanced software design , users would be allowed to set preferences for text-wrapping , cursor-movement , cursor-shape , etc. .
Many problems are actually from each user 's PC setup or browser , such as pressing F5 or -LRB- before edit-preview -RRB- and losing all edit-text -LRB- see below : Browser nightmares -RRB- .
There are hundreds of unusual , or unexpected quirks or glitches in the way things sort-of-do , sort-of-don ' t work .
The quirks are not merely planned obsolescence , similar to allowing computer viruses , which are known to kill user computers and cause people to buy new or fix-it software products -LRB- as the planned result -RRB- .
All of those problems are caused by quirky browser operation -LRB- not Wikipedia -RRB- , as the browser does not reflect the way that people actually think .
Me is quotebox â `` wiki would die without me .
Knowing the details , about specific quirks , can help avoid the stress or frustrations in the future .
On any given day , new problems might arise , or old problems get fixed , as the developers adjust the servers or hack the MediaWiki code to alter character-shift typesetting for the 200 + Wikipedia languages -LRB- see below : Why quirks occur -RRB- .
Even the most level-headed , otherwise-normal software developers will become overwhelmed by the pre-exising nerdisms , so that even simple changes can introduce new quirks , and hence , no single group of people can be blamed for the combined , bizarre outcomes .
Many problems that users think are caused by Wikipedia are actually caused by limited Web browsers .
Well , as can be expected with multiple personality disorder -LRB- MPD -RRB- , the 3 languages fight for power : when HTML code is formatted with typical indentation , the me-is-quotebox personality , at times , hijacks the page , and you get hypertext-markup-laughter displayed in a box that looks like -LRB- ... wait for it ... -RRB- a QuoteBox !
Also , Wikipedia is not alone in having website quirks , even Google has had them -LRB- see section below : `` Google quirks '' -RRB- .
Wikipedia is not alone in having many website quirks .
Then there is the 3rd language : the `` infamous '' if-you-indent , you get `` quotebox '' yes the all-important quotebox , which in computer-typesetting typically requires only 2 markers ; instead , just indent and the whole section turns into quotebox â `` quotebox â `` quotebox .
Many changes are made to support the unusual typesetting needs of rare written languages that use split-character placement of text or other unusual options not seen in English or other European languages .
Complicating the complications is the reality that , eventually , several multiple nerdisms are implemented .
The MediaWiki markup language is a peculiar twisto-mash of 3 computer languages .
Far surpassing `` creeping featurism '' the total system becomes `` featured creepyism '' .
The above text , with the multi-line footnote shows use of 4 HTML comment lines '' '' to simulate indenting by putting each text segment on a separate line .
Sometimes -LRB- or often ? -RRB-
Me is quotebox â `` I exist here 8 years plus forever .
When the template begins to process `` xxx '' then the newline might be seen as an indentation , within the template , so the template would start considering all subsequent lines to be part of the oh-so-important quotebox , generated now in the middle of the template procedural coding .
So , anyway , put all 3 schidzo languages , blended together , and you get MediaWiki markup -LRB- or markdown ? -RRB-
However , some general principles can explain how the problems have arisen , over the years .
The English Wikipedia is impacted because all 200 + languages share some common software , and that software gets changed for everyone .

The hill chain extends from southwest to northeast parallel to the course of the Danube River and is continued on either side of the district .

The city of Ulm is surrounded by the district .

An affluent of the Danube , the Iller River , forms the southeastern border of the Alb-Donau district , before it meets the Danube in Ulm .

The full explanation of the tengwar was published in 1955 in Appendix E of The Lord of the Rings .
The tengwar were probably developed in the late 1920s or in the early 1930s .
Tolkien used the tengwar to write texts for his fictional world Middle-earth and other things .
In some modes the tengwar are used for vowels and consonants ; and in other modes the tengwar are only used for the consonants , and the vowels are marked by signs above or below the tengwa . These vowel signs are called tehtar -LRB- `` signs '' ; singular : tehta , `` sign '' -RRB- .
But Tolkien used the tengwar mostly for writing English .
The first published sample of tengwar writing was 1937 in The Hobbit , to so-called The Lonely Mountain Jar Inscription .
In the late 1910s , J. R. R. Tolkien developed the script Sarati , which was already a bit similar to tengwar . The tengwar were probably developed in the late 1920s or in the early 1930s .
The tengwar are used to write some of Tolkien 's constructed languages , like for example the elven languages Quenya and Sindarin .
In the Quenya language , tengwar means `` letters '' , tengwa is the singular and means `` letter '' .

Peter Ahlwardts -LRB- `` Reasonable and Theological Considerations about Thunder and Lightning '' , 1745 -RRB- said people who sought to protect themselves from lightning should go anywhere except in or around a church .
Early on , Christian churches tried to prevent the damage of lightning by prayers .
A lightning rod or lightning conductor is a metal rod that is used to make lightning strike it , rather than strike something else .
Balls of solid glass occasionally were used in a method thought to prevent lightning strikes to ships .
The patent was granted due to a fault in Franklin 's original theory of operation ; the pointed lightning rod actually ionizes the air around itself . This makes the air conductive , which in turn raises the probability of a strike .
Many years after receiving his patent , in 1919 Dr. Tesla wrote an article for The Electrical Experimenter entitled `` Famous Scientific Illusions '' , in which he explains the logic of Franklin 's pointed lightning rod and discloses his improved method and apparatus .
Glass objects do not conduct electricity well . They are seldom struck by lightning .
The church tower was usually the highest structure or building in medieval European towns and villages . It was also the building very often hit by lightning .
In the 19th century the lightning rod became a symbol of American ingenuity and a decorative motif .
Lightning rods were often embellished with ornamental glass balls -LRB- now prized by collectors -RRB- .
The ornamental appeal of these glass balls has also been incorporated into weather vanes .
In the United States , the pointed lightning rod conductor , often incorrectly referred to as the `` lightning attractor , '' was invented by Benjamin Franklin as part of his groundbreaking explorations of electricity .
Lightning can damage structures made of most materials -LRB- masonry , wood , concrete and even steel -RRB- . The huge currents involved can heat materials , and especially water to high temperatures .
Franklin thought that , with an iron rod sharpened to a point at the end ,
The random behavior of lightning ensured that the method gained a good bit of credence even after the development of the marine lightning rod soon after Franklin 's initial work .
It is part of a lightning protection system .
Franklin speculated about lightning rods for several years before his reported kite experiment .
Nikola Tesla 's was an improvement in lightning protectors .
Priests prayed , `` temper the destruction of hail and cyclones and the force of tempests and lightning ; check hostile thunders and great winds ; and cast down the spirits of storms and the powers of the air . ''
Hence the best method for preventing a lightning strike to a wooden ship was to bury a small solid glass ball in the tip of the highest mast .
`` The electrical fire would , I think , be drawn out of a cloud silently , before it could come near enough to strike -LRB- ... -RRB- . ''
This experiment , in fact , took place because he was tired of waiting for Christ Church in Philadelphia to be completed so he could place a lightning rod on top of it .
Therefore , goes the theory , there must be something about glass that repels lightning .

`` Owen : the most distinguished vertebrate zoologist and palaeontologist ... but a most deceitful and odious man . ''
A fine example was his decision to classify man in a separate sub-class of the Mammalia -LRB- see Thomas Henry Huxley -RRB- .
`` At the root was Owenâ s feeling that Kew should be subordinate to the British Museum -LRB- and to Owen -RRB- and should not be allowed to develop as an independent scientific institution with the advantage of a great botanic garden . ''
In the second part of his career his reputation slipped .
Also , his unwillingness to come off the fence concerning evolution became increasingly damaging to his reputation as time went on .
`` It is painful to be hated in the intense degree with which Owen hates me '' .
Owen is probably best remembered today for coining the word Dinosauria -LRB- meaning ` Terrible Reptile ' -RRB- , and for his outspoken opposition to Charles Darwin 's theory of evolution by natural selection .
Owen , in Darwin 's opinion , was `` Spiteful , extremely malignant , clever ; the Londoners say he is mad with envy because my book is so talked about '' .
This was not the first or last time Owen would deliberately claim a discovery as his own , when in fact it was not .
In the first part of his career Owen was regarded rightly as one of the great scientific figures of the age .
In this Owen had no supporters at all .
Owen credited himself and Georges Cuvier with the discovery of the Iguanodon , completely excluding any credit for the original discoverer of the dinosaur , Gideon Mantell .
Owen was finally dismissed from the Royal Society 's Zoological Council for plagiarism .
This was not solely due to his underhanded dealings with colleagues ; it was also due to the serious errors of scientific judgement which were discovered and publicized .
Sir Richard Owen KCB -LRB- Lancaster , 20 July 1804 -- 18 December 1892 -RRB- was an English biologist , comparative anatomist and palaeontologist .
Owen was highly critical of Darwin 's On the Origin of Species , in part because Darwin did not refer much to the previous scientific theories of evolution . Instead , Darwin compared the theory of evolution by natural selection with the unscientific theory in the Bible .

A new single parliament and government , based in Westminster in London , controlled the new kingdom .

The people of Nagar have their literacy rate more than 90 % in men . While women have about 59 % .
The climate of Nagar remains pleasant from mid-April to the end of September .
The British gained control of Nagar during a battle at place of Nilt -LRB- Jangir-e-Laye -RRB- between 1889 and 1892 .
Although never ruled directly by neighbouring Kashmir or the British , Nagar and Hunza were a vassal of Kashmir from the time of Maharaja Ranbir Singh of Jammu and Kashmir .
The Mirs of both sent an annual tribute to the Kashmir Durbar until 1947 , and along with the ruler of Hunza , was considered to be among the most loyal vassals of the Maharaja of Kashmir .
The Tham -LRB- Chief -RRB- of that time , Azur Khan , was sent in exile to Kashmir .

Since 2001 , these have been led by democratically elected local councils , each headed by a Nazim -LRB- the word means `` supervisor '' in Urdu , but is sometimes translated as mayor -RRB- .
There are over five thousand local governments in Pakistan .

A rod , a perch or a pole is a unit of length in the imperial and US systems .

Solitary confinement is a punishment or special form of imprisonment . A prisoner is not allowed contact with anyone , except the prison staff .
In the US Federal Prison system , solitary confinement is known as the Special Housing Unit -LRB- SHU -RRB- , .
In American English it also called the ` hole ' , ` lockdown ' , the ` SHU ' -LRB- pronounced ` shoe ' -RRB- or the ` pound ' . In British English people say ` block ' or ` the cooler ' .
In other states , it is known as the Special Management Unit -LRB- SMU -RRB- , pronounced \/ Ë smuË \/ .
California 's prison system also uses the abbreviation SHU , but it stands for Security Housing Units .
This form of solitary confinement is sometimes called protective custody .
Finally , it may be used for prisoners who are at high risk of being attacked by other inmates , such as pedophiles , celebrities , or witnesses who are in prison themselves .
Opponents of solitary confinement claim that it is cruel and unusual punishment and torture Taking away human contact , and the sensory input is usually part of solitary confinement and can have a powerful negative effect on a prisoner 's mind . This may lead to mental illnesses such as depression and even death .

Two more children followed : Anna Maria Luisa , Electress Palatine , and Gian Gastone , the last Medici Grand Duke of Tuscany .

Thus without political influence , Marguerite Louise sorted the education of her eldest son , Grand Prince Ferdinando .

The word cardiomyopathy means `` heart muscle disease '' . Cardiomyopathies are a group of diseases in which the function of the myocardium -LRB- heart muscle -RRB- is impaired for any reason .
People with cardiomyopathy are often at risk of arrhythmia and\/or sudden cardiac death .

The outer covering is the pericardium .
The inner layer is the endocardium .

Octal is similar to hexadecimal because they are both easily converted to binary .
Octal is similar to hexadecimal because they are both easily converted to binary . Where Octal is equal to three digit binary , hexadecimal is equal to four digit binary .
The octal numeral system is a base 8 numeral system . It uses the numerals 0 through 7 .
The grouping of the binary digits is done from right to left .

Esa-Pekka Salonen -LRB- born 30 June 1958 -RRB- is a Finnish conductor and composer .
Salonen married Jane Price who used to play with the Philharmonia Orchestra . They have three children .
He is conductor of the Los Angeles Philharmonic and the Philharmonia Orchestra in London .
Salonen was principal conductor of the Swedish Radio Symphony Orchestra from 1984-1995 .

He started conducting in 1979 with the Finnish Radio Symphony Orchestra , mainly in order to conduct his own compositions .
Later he studied composition with several composers including Einojuhani Rautavaara .

Royal Commissions are called to look into very important matters and usually controversy .
For example , these can be about government structure , the treatment of minorities , or the events that had received concern from the public or economic questions .
Because of this governments are usually very careful about framing the Terms of Reference and generally include in them a date by which the commission must finish .
In Australia -- and particularly New South Wales -- Royal Commissions have been investigations into police and government corruption and organised crime . They have used the powers of the Royal Commissioner to force powerful , but corrupt , public officials to tell the truth .
In other cases , where the Commissioner has not kept to the terms of reference , the commission has been stopped by a superior court .
In practice -- unlike other forms of inquiry -- once a Commission has started the government can not stop it .
The results of Royal Commissions are published in , often , massive reports of findings containing policy recommendations .
They can call witnesses under oath , offer indemnities , seize documents and other evidence -LRB- sometimes including those normally protected , such as classified information -RRB- , holding hearings in camera , and can force all government officials to help the Commission .
Because of their legal powers the Commissioners are often retired senior judges .
They often have long and complex names , for example , the `` Royal commission into whether there has been corrupt or criminal conduct by any Western Australian Police Officer '' . Because of this they are commonly known by the name of the main Commissioner .
A Royal Commissioner has a lot of power , more than those of a judge but these are limited to the `` Terms of Reference '' of the Commission .
The Commission is created by the Head of State -LRB- the Sovereign , or his\/her representative in the form of a Governor-General or Governor -RRB- on the advice of the Government .
Royal Commissions are usually run by one or more notable figures .
In states that are Commonwealth Realms a Royal Commission is a major government public inquiry into an important issue .
They have been held in the United Kingdom , Canada , Australia , New Zealand , Kenya and Saudi Arabia .
Many Royal Commissions last many years and , often , a different government is left to respond to the findings .
In Hong Kong , Ireland and South Africa , they are called a Commission of Enquiry or Commission of Inquiry .
These reports are often quite important , with the government making some or all recommendations into law . The work of some Commissions have been almost completely ignored by the government .

Richmond is the capital city of the state of Virginia , in the United States of America .
Much of the American Civil War was fought near Richmond , because Richmond was the capital of the Confederate States of America . Today , Richmond has a population of about 204,000 people , with more than a million people in the area around Richmond .

United States Tennis Association -LRB- USTA -RRB- is the organization that controls tennis at national level in the United States .
The USTA runs the USTA Billie Jean King National Tennis Center which hosts the U.S. Open , the last grand slam of the year .
It is a non-profit private organization formed in 1881 to standardize rules the rules of tennis in United States and affiliated to International Tennis Federation , the international governing body of tennis . At present USTA has more than 700,000 members , its whole aim is to promote and develop the game of tennis and to develop better infrastructure for tennis .

Born in Hamburg , Germany , he studied zoology at the University of Berlin , receiving his PhD in 1923 at the age of 21 .
In 1931 , he was the first to demonstrate crossover of homologous chromosomes in Drosophila melanogaster , only weeks after Barbara McClintock and Harriet Creighton had done so with maize .
The Curt Stern Award , established by the American Society of Human Genetics in 2001 , recognizes a scientist who has made major scientific achievements in human genetics during the previous 10 years .
Curt Stern -LRB- 30 August 1902 â `` 23 October 1981 -RRB- was a German-American geneticist .
He was selected for a fellowship to study at Columbia University , then the site of Thomas Hunt Morgan 's famous drosophila fly room .
During World War II , he led research for the American government on low dose radiation safety .
In 1936 , he demonstrated that recombination can also take place in mitosis resulting in somatic mosaics , organisms that contain two or more genetically distinct types of tissues .
Both his teaching and his textbook were instrumental in re-founding human genetics on a non-racist basis , in contrast with pre-war German and American traditions in the subject .
Although not a physician , he engaged in clinical work in human genetics .
After the war his research focused on human genetics , pioneering in what is now known as gene regulation .
From 1947 until his retirement in 1970 , he was a professor at the University of California , Berkeley , where he had numerous doctoral students .
Stern was a signatory of the 1950 UNESCO statement The Race Question , a statement by leading scientists in many fields that questioned the validity and scientific foundations of racism .
From 1933 to 1947 , he taught at the University of Rochester .
In 1943 he began teaching a course in human genetics to medical students at the University of Rochester .
The first edition of Stern 's pioneering textbook The Principles of human genetics was published in 1949 .

Ã ras an UachtarÃ in is the official home of the President of Ireland .
His official residence was in the Viceregal Apartments in Dublin Castle .
On 1 May 2004 , during Ireland 's six-month presidency of the European Union , Ã ras an Uachtarain was the Venue for the European Day of Welcomes -LRB- Accession Day -RRB- in which ten new members joined the EU .
It was bought by the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland .
Ã ras an UachtarÃ in also houses the headquarters of the Garda Mounted Unit .
In 2001 , the Irish state opened a guest residence nearby in Farmleigh , a former Guinness mansion .
Guests do not normally stay at the Ã ras .
All 25 heads of government attended the flag raising ceremony in the gardens of the palace .
The current occupant , Mary McAleese lives in the 1911 wing .

Other famous visitors to the Ã ras an UachtarÃ in have been Princess Grace of Monaco and her husband , Prince Rainier III ; King Baudouin of the Belgians ; King Juan Carlos and Queen Sophia ; Pope John Paul II ; Prince Charles , and Prince Philip .
In 1882 , the grounds around the house became the location for a famous murder .
After the Irish Free State was established in 1922 , it became the home of the Governor-General of the Irish Free State until 1932 .
In 1911 , the house got a large extension for the visit of King George V and Queen Mary .
The house in the park then became the Viceregal Lodge , the `` out of season '' residence of the Lord Lieutenant -LRB- also known as the Viceroy -RRB- , where he lived for most of the year from the 1820s onwards .
Various visiting British kings and queens stayed at the Viceregal Lodge , notably Queen Victoria and George V. American presidents that visited include Presidents John F. Kennedy , Richard Nixon , Ronald Reagan and Bill Clinton , who are all of Irish descent .
The house was left empty for some years , until the office of President of Ireland was created in 1937 .
Later presidents moved to the new wing attached to the main house that had been built on for the visit of King George V in 1911 .

Professional certification , trade certification , or professional designation , often called simply certification or qualification , is a certification a person gets to assure that he\/she is qualified to perform a job or task .
Certifications are very common in aviation , construction , technology and other industrial sectors , as well as health care and finance .

The southern and western boundaries are based on the continental shelf .

The surface gravity may be thought of as the acceleration caused by the gravity experienced by a hypothetical test particle which is very close to the object 's surface and which , in order not to disturb the system , has negligible mass.
The surface gravity , g , of an astronomical or other object is the gravitational acceleration experienced at its surface .
Surface gravity is measured in units of acceleration , which , in the SI system , are meters per second squared .
It may also be described as a multiple of the Earth 's gravity , g = 9.80665 m\/s2 .
In astrophysics , the surface gravity may be expressed as log g , which is obtained by first expressing the gravity in cgs units , where the unit of acceleration is centimeters per second squared , and then taking the base 10 logarithm .

The 2006 unnamed tropical storm was a short-lived tropical cyclone .
The northern one became an extratropical cyclone , a type of weather system , on July 16 .
It was the second tropical storm of the 2006 Atlantic hurricane season . It formed as an extratropical cyclone , a type of weather system , to the southeast of Nantucket , Massachusetts .
It moved to the northwest over warm water temperatures . These temperatures were 80 -- 82 Â F -LRB- 27 -- 28 Â C -RRB- .
The storm quickly reached peak winds of 50 mph -LRB- 85 km\/h -RRB- .
Late on July 17 , the storm reached its peak winds of 50 mph -LRB- 85 km\/h -RRB- . At this time , it was located about 245 miles -LRB- 395 km -RRB- to the south of Halifax , Nova Scotia .
A cold front moved off the east coast of the United States late on July 13 . While it was over the western Atlantic Ocean , it stopped moving .
It then moved to the northwest over warm water temperatures . It turned into a tropical storm on July 17 , when an area of thunderstorms formed near the center of the cyclone .
It quickly weakened as the convection quickly diminished , and it died out on July 18 .
It turned into a tropical depression on July 17 , when it was located about 240 miles -LRB- 390 km -RRB- to the southeast of Nantucket , Massachusetts .

The Template : Strlen_quick gives the length of parameter 1 , as a text string , with a count of 0-80 characters , using a simple , quick method .
This markup template was designed to run quickly and use only 5 levels of MediaWiki expansion depth , rather than 9-13 or more levels as in other string-length templates .

Typical music includes largely British and North American hip hop , grime , bassline , garage , dubstep , drum and bass , bashment , soca , reggae , gospel music , bhangra and R&B .
1Xtra 's audience is usually aged between 15 and 30 years old .

It is the sister station to BBC Radio 1 and is broadcast from the same building as Radio 1 - Yalding House in central London . This is part of the BBC 's massive Broadcasting House complex of radio studios and other offices .

The Labor Party had controlled the LCC from 1934 and by the 1950s the Conservative Government considered that elections were becoming one-sided , since the London County Council -LRB- LCC -RRB- covered only the inner -LRB- generally Labour-voting -RRB- districts .
The Mayor of London elections were won by the same Ken Livingstone , who began his victory speech with the words : `` As I was saying before I was so rudely interrupted 14 years ago '' .
In 1999 a referendum was held on the establishment of a new London authority and elected mayor , which was approved by a two to one margin .
The new Greater London Authority -LRB- GLA -RRB- was established in 2000 .
Livingstone 's high-spend socialist policies put the GLC into direct conflict with Margaret Thatcher 's Conservative government .
Most of the powers of the GLC were given to the London boroughs .
It replaced the earlier London County Council -LRB- LCC -RRB- which had covered a much smaller area .
The Local Government Act 1985 , which abolished the GLC , faced considerable opposition from many quarters but was narrowly passed in Parliament , setting the end of the council for 31 March 1986 .
The government sought to create a new body covering all of London .
The Greater London Council -LRB- GLC -RRB- was the local government administrative body for Greater London from 1965 to 1986 .
Some powers , such as the fire service , were taken over by joint boards made up of councillors appointed by the boroughs - see waste authorities in Greater London for an example .
Livingstone soon became a thorn in the side of the sitting Tory government .
The GLA has a very different structure to the GLC , it consisted of a directly elected Mayor of London and a London Assembly .
Tony Blair 's Labor government was elected in 1997 , and was committed to bring back London-wide government .

Disney remade the movie in 1996 as 101 Dalmatians , a live-action film starring Glenn Close as Cruella De Vil .
It was then released on VHS on April 10 , 1992 as part of the Walt Disney Classics video series .

There are various types of barometers such as the water barometer , aneroid barometer , and the mercury barometer .
Barometer is an instrument used to measure air pressure .
The most used purpose of the barometer was measuring air pressure . The barometer is a good tool for predicting weather .
Air pressure and differences in pressure are important ways to describe or measure weather .
There are various types of barometers such as the water barometer , aneroid barometer , and the mercury barometer . They were created by an Italian mathematician named Evangelista Torricelli in 1643 .

The lost energy is converted into heat , raising the temperature of the system .
In Hydrology , dissipation is the process of converting mechanical energy of downward flowing water into thermal and acoustical energy .
Such systems are called dissipative systems .
In computational physics , a numerical dissipation is also known as `` artificial dissipation '' or `` artificial diffusion '' or `` numerical diffusion '' .
Very often these devices look like small waterfalls or cascades , where water flows vertically or over riprap to lose some of its kinetic force .
In physics , dissipation includes the concept of a dynamical system where important mechanical modes , such as waves or oscillations , lose energy over time , typically due to the action of friction or turbulence .
The dissipative nature depends on the nature of the wave : an atmospheric wave , for instance , may dissipate close to the surface due to friction with the land mass , and at higher levels due to radiative cooling .
Various devices are designed in stream-beds -LRB- river-banks -RRB- to reduce the kinetic energy of flowing waters to reduce their erosive potential on banks and river bottoms .
They all mean this : when the pure advection equation -- which , by definition , is free of dissipation -- is solved by a numerical approximation method that reduces the amplitude and changes the shape of the initial wave in a way analogous -LRB- similar -RRB- to a diffusional process , the method is said to contain ` dissipation ' .
For example , a wave that loses amplitude is said to dissipate .

In Great Britain , bonfires are particularly associated with Guy Fawkes Night .

In ancient times , cattle were important symbols of wealth and status . Such cattle was led through the smoke of a bonfire .

The magnitude of the gradient will determine how fast the temperature rises in that direction .
If a road goes directly up the hill , then the steepest slope on the road will also be 40 % .
Consider a room in which the temperature is given by a scalar field , so at each point the temperature is . We will assume that the temperature does not change in time .
Consider again the example with the hill and suppose that the steepest slope on the hill is 40 % .
Then , at each point in the room , the gradient at that point will show the direction in which the temperature rises most quickly .
Consider a hill whose height above sea level at a point is .
The steepness of the slope at that point is given by the magnitude of the gradient vector .
For example , if the angle between the road and the uphill direction , projected onto the horizontal plane , is 60 Â , then the steepest slope along the road will be 20 % which is 40 % times the cosine of 60 Â .
The gradient of at a point is a vector pointing in the direction of the steepest slope or grade at that point .
A generalization of the gradient , for functions which have vectorial values , is the Jacobian .
If instead , the road goes around the hill at an angle with the uphill direction -LRB- the gradient vector -RRB- , then it will have a shallower slope .
The gradient can also be used to measure how a scalar field changes in other directions , rather than just the direction of greatest change , by taking a dot product .
In vector calculus , the gradient of a scalar field is a vector field which points in the direction of the greatest rate of increase of the scalar field , and whose magnitude is the greatest rate of change .

The Hammersmith & City line is a line of the London Underground , colored salmon pink on the London Underground Map , running between Hammersmith in West London and Barking in East London .
According to Livy -LRB- 59 BC â `` 17 -RRB- the Palatine hill got its name from the Arcadian settlement of Pallantium .
Seventy-six trains out of a fleet of 88 are needed to run the line 's peak service . One unit -LRB- 166-566-366 -RRB- was severely damaged by the terrorist attack of 7 July 2005 .
-LRB- In order from east to west . -RRB-
Trains will also make an additional stop at during early mornings and late evenings but will not stop at the station during the main part of the day .
The Piccadilly line was to be upgraded in 2014 â `` 15 and would have had new trains as well as new signalling .
Bids for the rolling-stock order were submitted in 2008 .
This would have increased the line 's capacity by some 24 % .
The line is controlled from the control center at Earl 's Court , which it used to share with the District line .
Out of the 53 stations served , 25 are underground .
The line was previously worked by 1959 stock , 1956 stock , 1938 stock , standard tube stock and 1906 gate stock .
Other services operate at times , especially at the start and towards the end of the traffic day .
The stock was recently refurbished , and was due for replacement by 2014 , but the order for new trains was canceled in July 2010 .
The line has two depots , at Northfields and Cockfosters .
It is the second longest line on the system , after the Central Line .
It is the fifth busiest line on the Underground network judged by the number of passengers transported per year .
However , after the acquisition of Tube Lines by Transport for London in June 2010 , this order was canceled .
Like most Underground lines , the Piccadilly line is operated by a single type of rolling stock . In this case it is the 1973 tube stock .
It is in need of resignalling , and this work is planned to be carried out by 2014 .
Often late evening services terminate at instead of Cockfosters .
The Piccadilly line is a line of the London Underground . It is colored dark blue on the Tube map .
It is mainly a deep-level line , running from the north to the west of London via Zone 1 . However , there are a number of surface sections mostly in its westernmost parts .
There are sidings at Oakwood , South Harrow , Arnos Grove , Rayners Lane , Down Street , Wood Green , Acton Town , Ruislip and Uxbridge .

GÃ del 's incompleteness theorems is the name given to two theorems , proved by Kurt GÃ del in 1931 . They are about limitations in all but the most trivial formal systems for arithmetic of mathematical interest .
All axioms are supposed to be true , even without a proof . A theory then serves to come up with other true statements from the axioms , using certain rules .
Most people think they show that Hilbert 's program to find a complete and consistent set of axioms for all of mathematics is impossible . This would give a negative answer to Hilbert 's second problem .
The theorems are very important for the philosophy of mathematics .

In this rigorous series , begun in 1949 , Albers explored chromatic interactions with flat colored squares arranged inside each other .

Most famous of all are the hundreds of paintings and prints that make up the series Homage to the Square .
He studied art in Berlin , Essen , and Munich , before enrolling as a student at the prestigious Weimar Bauhaus in 1920 .

Pulitzer changed its focus to human-interest stories , scandal , and sensationalism .
Under Pulitzer 's leadership circulation grew from 15,000 to 600,000 , making the New Your World the largest newspaper in the country .
In 1902 , Columbia 's new president Nicholas Murray Butler was more receptive to the plan for a school and prizes , but it would not be until after Pulitzer 's death that this dream would be fulfilled .
Then , in 1878 , he bought the St. Louis Dispatch for $ 2,700 and merged the two papers , which became the St. Louis Post-Dispatch , which remains St. Louis ' daily newspaper .
The university initially turned down the money , evidently unimpressed by Pulitzer 's unscrupulous character .
That newspaper had been losing $ 40,000 a year . He paid $ 346,000 to Jay Gould , the owner .
In 1895 the World introduced the popular Yellow Kid comic by Richard F. Outcault . This was the first newspaper comic printed with color .
In 1887 , he recruited the famous investigative journalist Nellie Bly .
In 1917 , the first Pulitzer Prizes were awarded , in accordance with Pulitzer 's wishes .
Pulitzer left the university $ 2 million in his will , which led to the creation in 1912 of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism , but by then the first school of journalism had been created at the University of Missouri .
In 1892 , Pulitzer offered Columbia University 's president , Seth Low , money to set up the world 's first school of journalism .
Pulitzer 's already failing health deteriorated rapidly , and he left the newsroom . He continued to actively manage the paper from his vacation retreat in Bar Harbor Maine and his New York mansion .
After the World exposed a fraudulent payment of $ 40 million by the United States to the French Panama Canal Company in 1909 , Pulitzer was indicted for libeling Theodore Roosevelt and J. P. Morgan .
In 1872 , Pulitzer bought the Post for $ 3,000 .
This competition with Hearst , particularly the coverage before and during the Spanish-American War , linked Pulitzer 's name with yellow journalism .
In 1989 Pulitzer was inducted into the St. Louis Walk of Fame .
He is interred in the Woodlawn Cemetery in The Bronx , New York .
In 1885 , he was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives , but resigned after a few months ' service .
The courts dismissed the indictments , in a victory for freedom of the press .
It was at the Post-Dispatch that Pulitzer developed his role as a champion of the common man with exposÃ s and a hard-hitting populist approach .
In 1895 , William Randolph Hearst purchased the rival New York Journal , which led to a circulation war .

Lepisma saccharina -LRB- commonly called the fishmoth , urban silverfish or just the silverfish -RRB- is a small , wingless insect .
Its common name comes from the animal 's silvery blue color , combined with the fish-like appearance of its movements . The scientific name indicates the silverfish 's diet of carbohydrates such as sugar or starches .

Gilbertâ s potoroo was not seen again for many years , even though many people had searched for them in the 1970s .
Three potoroos , one male and two females , were moved to Bald Island in August 2005 .
A few young were born in the first couple of years , but then breeding just stopped .
It is not known how long gestation is for Gilbertâ s potoroo , but it is thought to be the same as the Long-nosed Potoroo ; about 38 days .
Liz Sinclair had been studying wallabies and caught the potoroo in one of her traps .
Potoroos live under thick bushes and shrubs .
If the first baby does not survive , the second baby can start growing right away .
Once thought to be extinct , it is listed as being critically endangered .
They can keep a second embryo in a state of diapause while the first embryo is growing .
Gilbert 's Potoroo is one of the world 's rarest mammals .
Australia has many different kinds of truffles and potoroos like to eat many of them .
Since then , four more potoroos have been sent to start a breeding colony .
It has a pointed face and it is about the size of a rabbit .
The female potoroos can have two babies in a year , but only carry one at a time .
The species was believed to be extinct for 120 years before it was re-discovered in 1994 in Two Peoples Bay Nature Reserve .
Potoroos have sharp three toed claws that help them dig into the ground to find the truffles growing in the soil .
Potoroos are nocturnal and they spend their days hiding .
It also helps with raising money for more study and captive breeding programs for Gilbertâ s potoroo .
In 2001 , a group was formed called the Gilbertâ s Potoroo Action Group -LRB- GPAG -RRB- .
Gilbert 's Potoroo -LRB- Potorous gilbertii -RRB- is an Australian marsupial , sometimes called a rat-kangaroo .
Gilbertâ s potoroo was first discovered in 1840 , and named in 1841 after the English naturalist and explorer John Gilbert .
Gilbert had collected several animals at King George Sound in Australia , including this potoroo .

It is commonly used as a measure of antagonist drug potency in pharmacological research .
EC50 also represents the plasma concentration required for obtaining 50 % of a maximum effect in vivo .
It indicates how much of a particular drug or other substance is needed to inhibit a given biological process -LRB- or component of a process , i.e. an enzyme , cell , cell receptor or microorganism -RRB- by half .
According to the FDA , IC50 represents the concentration of a drug that is required for 50 % inhibition in vitro .
It is comparable to an EC50 for agonist drugs .
Sometimes , it is also converted to the pIC50 scale -LRB- - log IC50 -RRB- , in which higher values indicate exponentially greater potency .
In other words , it is the half maximal -LRB- 50 % -RRB- inhibitory concentration -LRB- IC -RRB- of a substance -LRB- 50 % IC , or IC50 -RRB- .
