2 Maccabees was written in Koine Greek , probably in Alexandria , Egypt , c 124 BC .
2 Maccabees is a sacred book of the Bible which focuses on the Jews ' revolt against Antiochus IV Epiphanes and ends with the defeat of the Syrian general Nicanor in 161 BC by Judas Maccabeus , the hero of the work .
It gives a revised version of the historical events recounted in the first seven chapters of 1 Maccabees .
Nicolas-Joseph Cugnot -LRB- 26 February 1725 - 2 October 1804 -RRB- was a French inventor .
He is believed to have built the first self-propelled mechanical vehicle .
Emphysema is a disease of the lungs .
It occurs when the very small air sacs -LRB- called the alveoli -RRB- at the ends of the airways in the lungs start to break down from many sacs to form much bigger sacs . The alveoli are the areas of the lung where oxygen and carbon dioxide are exchanged into and out of the blood .

The William M. Jennings Trophy was created as a new award for the goaltender -LRB- s -RRB- of the team that surrenders the fewest goals in regular season play .
Since 1981 , the Vezina Trophy has been awarded by the NHL General Managers to the most outstanding goaltender .
Before 1981 , it was awarded to the goaltender -LRB- s -RRB- of the team allowing the fewest number of goals during the regular season ; now , the William M. Jennings Trophy is awarded under this previous definition .
Chuck Rayner was the only goaltender to win the Hart Memorial Trophy , but never the Vezina .
Players for the Montreal Canadiens have won the Vezina 28 times .
There are only three players that have won both the Vezina and Hart Memorial Trophy for the same season : Jacques Plante , who won both trophies for the 1961 â `` 62 season ; Dominik Hasek who won both for the 1996 â `` 97 and 1997 â `` 98 seasons ; and Jose Theodore , who won the Vezina and Hart for the 2001-02 NHL season .
The NHL adopted the current criteria for the Vezina Trophy beginning in 1982 .
The Vezina Trophy is awarded every year to the National Hockey League 's goaltender who is chosen as the best goaltender .
At the end of each season , the 30 General Managers of the teams in the National Hockey League vote to determine the goaltender who was the most valuable to his team during the regular season .
Two other Vezina winning goaltenders have also won the Hart Memorial Trophy : Roy Worters and Al Rollins .
Until the 1980 â `` 81 season , the trophy was awarded to the goaltender -LRB- s -RRB- of the team that gave up the least goals during the regular season .
Vezina felt sick during a game in 1925 because he had tuberculosis .
When Vezina died , the trophy was given to the League by the former owners of the Montreal Canadiens , Leo Dandurand , Louis Letourneau and Joe Cattarinich .
In the 1973-74 NHL season , Tony Esposito of the Chicago Black Hawks and Bernie Parent of the Philadelphia Flyers finished tied for the fewest goals against , the only time that there would be a tie between two players from different teams .
Under the original definition , there would often be multiple winners from the same team during one season .
However , it was recognized that this system often meant the trophy went to the goaltender of the better team rather than the individual and hence the change was made to offer the William M. Jennings Trophy to the goaltender -LRB- s -RRB- playing for the team with the fewest goals against .
There have been numerous instances of players receiving the trophy many times in different years , and players tying for the trophy .
The Vezina Trophy was named for Georges VÃ zina , a very good goaltender with the Montreal Canadiens .
The voting is conducted at the end of the regular season by the 30 general managers of the teams in the National Hockey League , and each individual voter ranks their top three candidates on a 5-3-1 points system .
Three finalists are named and the trophy is awarded at the NHL Awards ceremony after the playoffs .

Few examples of Greek wall paintings have survived the centuries .
The figurines were equally fashionable .
Their mother Gaia , come to their aid , can do nothing and must watch them twist in pain under the blows of the gods .

Previously reserved for religious use , in Hellenistic Greece the terra cotta figurine was more frequently used for funerary , and even decorative , purposes .
Pergamon did not distinguish itself with its architecture alone : it was also the seat of a brilliant school of sculpture called Pergamene Baroque .
The most representative copies of this style come from Centuripe in Sicily , where a workshop was active until the 3rd century B.C. .
Molded glass continued , notably in the creation of intaglio jewelry .
The work on metal vases took on a new fullness : the artists competed among themselves with great virtuosity .
It is decorated with a 32-centimetre-tall frieze of figures in relief representing Dionysus surrounded by Ariadne and her procession of satyrs and maenads .
Because of this , only the smaller objects still exist .
Artemis Rospigliosi of the Louvre is probably a copy of one of them ; as for copies of the Dying Gaul , they were very numerous in the Roman period .
The Olympians triumph in it , each on his side , over Giants most of which are transformed into savage beasts : serpents , birds of prey , lions or bulls .
The second temple of Apollo at Didyma was like that . It was twenty kilometers from Miletus in Ionia .
The fragility of the pigments preventing frequent use of these vases , they were reserved for use in funerals .
The jewellers of the time excelled at handling details and filigrees : thus , the funeral wreaths present very realistic leaves of trees or stalks of wheat .
The art of glass developed especially in Italy .
The shapes of the vases are also inspired by the tradition of metal : thus with the lagynos -LRB- pictured here -RRB- , a wine jar typical of the period .
In parallel there subsisted a tradition of polychromatic figurative painting : the artists sought a greater variety of tints than in the past .
In it one sees four doves perched on the edge of a basin filled with water .
For example , the tomb said to be that of Philip II has provided a great frieze representing a royal lion hunt , remarkable by its composition , the arrangement of the figures in space and its realistic representation of nature .
Certain mosaics , however , provide a pretty good idea of the `` grand painting '' of the period : these are copies of frescoes .
The `` grotesques '' are equally common at Tarsus and also at Alexandria .
One such is the Barberini Faun of Munich , representing a sleeping satyr with relaxed posture and anxious face , perhaps the prey of nightmares .
The art of engraving on gems hardly advanced at all , limiting itself to mass-produced items that lacked originality .
Sometimes , they were reduced to echoing a form from the great sculptures : thus one finds numerous copies in miniature of the Tyche -LRB- good luck -RRB- of Antioch , of which the original dates to the beginning of the 3rd century BC .
It is believed to be a copy of a work described by Pliny the Elder -LRB- XXXV , 110 -RRB- which had been painted by Philoxenus of Eretria for King Cassander of Macedon at the end of the 4th century BC .
Attalus I -LRB- 269-197 BC -RRB- , to commemorate his victory at Caicus against the Gauls â '' called Galatians by the Greeks â '' had two series of votive groups sculpted : the first , consecrated on the Acropolis of Pergamon , includes the famous Gaul killing himself and his wife , of which the original is lost -LRB- the best copy is in the Massimo alle Terme museum of Rome , see illustration -RRB- ; the second group , offered to Athens , is composed of small bronzes of Greeks , Amazons , gods and giants , Persians and Gauls .
The evolution is similar for the art of jewellery .
Fortunately , during Hellenistic Greece , the raw materials were plentiful following eastern conquests .
An example is the Alexander Mosaic , showing the confrontation of the young conqueror and the Grand King Darius III at the Battle of Issus , a mosaic which adorns the walls of the House of the Faun at Pompeii .
Another phenomenon appears in Hellenistic sculpture : privatization , which involves the recapture of older public patterns in decorative sculpture .
The mosaic allows us to admire the choice of colors , the composition of the ensemble with turning movement and facial expressivity .
In Tanagra , in Boeotia , the figurines , full of lively colors , most often represent elegant women in scenes full of charm .
One of them is watering herself while the others seem to be resting , which creates effects of reflections and shadow perfectly studied by the artist .
At Smyrna , in Asia Minor , two major styles occurred side-by-side : first of all , copies of masterpieces of great sculpture , such as Farnese Hercules in gilt terra cotta .
The refinement of molding techniques made it possible to create true miniature statues , with a high level of detail .

Many of the large bronze statues were lost - with the majority being melted to recover the material .
At Panagyurishte -LRB- now in Bulgaria -RRB- , skilfully sculpted gold vases have been found : on an amphora , two rearing centaurs form the handles .
The drunk woman , also at Munich , portrays without reservation an old woman , thin , haggard , clutching against herself her jar of wine .
In Derveni , not far from Salonica , a tomb has provided a great krater with bronze volutes dating from approximately 320 BC and weighing 40 kilograms -LRB- Derveni krater -RRB- .
As for the portraits , they are tinged with naturalism , under the influence of Roman art .
This type of retrospective style also exists in ceramics .
Pergamon is a very good example of Hellenistic architecture .
As compensation , the cameo made its appearance .
These characteristics are pushed to their peak in the friezes of the Great Altar of Pergamon , decorated under the order of Eumenes II -LRB- 197-159 BC -RRB- with a gigantomachy stretching 110 metres in length , illustrating in the stone a poem composed especially for the court .
A very big theater has benches stretched out over the sides of the hill , for people to sit on , and is able to hold almost 10,000 people .
The figures , often female , are represented in colored clothing : blue-violet chiton , yellow himation , white veil .
It was in the Hellenistic period that the Greeks , who until then only knew molded glass , discovered the technique of glass blowing , thus permitting new forms .
Or they could simply be caricatures , designed to provoke laughter .
They represented divinities as well as subjects from contemporary life .
Thus , Venus de Milo , even while echoing a classic model , is distinguished by the twist of her hips .
The expression of sentiments , the forcefulness of details â '' bushy hair and moustaches here â '' and the violence of the movements are characteristic of the Pergamene style .
The Hellenistic period is that of the decline of painting on vases .
One finds also more complex relief , based on animals or mythological creatures .
Thus emerged the theme of the `` negro '' , particularly in Ptolemaic Egypt : these statuettes of Black adolescents were successful up to the Roman period .
The most common vases are black and uniform , with a shiny appearance approaching that of varnish , decorated with simple motifs of flowers or festoons .
In this period the insetting of precious stones flourished .
It is also the period when vases in relief appeared , doubtless in imitation of vases made of precious metals : wreaths in relief were applied to the body of the vase , or again the one shown here received veins or gadroons .
Hellenistic sculpture repeats the innovations of the second classicism : perfect sculpture in the round , allowing the statue to be admired from all angles ; study of draping and effects of transparency of clothing ; suppleness of poses .
It has long been necessary to content oneself with studying the Hellenistic influences in Roman frescoes , for example those of Pompeii or Herculaneum .
Progress in bronze casting made it possible for the Greeks to create large works , such as the Colossus of Rhodes , with a height of 32 meters .

The team 's headquarters were first located at Meta Images 's offices in Madrid , housing marketing and administration . Its technical center is located at Campos Racing 's headquarters in Alzira , Valencia .
It is the first Spanish team to race in Formula One . A previous Spanish effort known as Bravo F1 tried but failed to enter the sport in .
The team 's headquarters were moved to Grupo Hispania 's offices in Murcia .

The Southern Railway -LRB- SR -RRB- gave the designation Sub to the wide variety of electric multiple units that were used on inner-suburban workings in the South London area .
Originally these units were formed as three-car units , but in the 1940s , all surviving units were increased to four cars by the addition of an ` Augmentation ' trailer .
New four-car units were also built at this time , and these survived in passenger use until late 1983 , by which time British Rail had allocated to them TOPS Class 405 .

The length of the hypotenuse can be calculated if the other two sides are known , using Pythagoras ' Theorem . In fact , the length of any side of a right triangle can be calculated if the other two sides are known , using this theorem .
The hypotenuse is the side opposite the 90 degrees angle in a right triangle . It is always the longest side .

This continuo is usually played by two instruments : typically a cello or bass viol and a keyboard instrument such as the harpsichord .
Some of the best trio sonatas are those by Arcangelo Corelli .
The trio sonata by Johann Sebastian Bach that belongs to the The Musical Offering is for violin , flute and continuo .
A trio sonata is written for three voices -LRB- three parts -RRB- , in other words , it can be played by three different instruments .
A trio sonata is a type of music for three instruments which was very popular during the 17th century and early 18th century : the period known as the Baroque period .
Bach also wrote sonatas for one melodic instrument and harpsichord .
Nelson 's Column is a national monument of the United Kingdom based in Trafalgar Square , London , England . The column was built between 1840 and 1843 to commemorate Admiral Horatio Nelson 's death at the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805 .

Ninety people died , one of whom was Bresci 's sister .
He was sentenced in Milan on August 29 , 1900 , to life imprisonment on the jail of Santo Stefano Island near Ventotene , where lot of other anarchists had also been sent over the years .
In Milan , an unarmed group of workers , women and children marched together for protesting , near the palace , which was surrounded by a strong military force under command of General Fiorenzo Bava-Beccaris .
Less than a year later he was found dead in prison .

About 40 % of the Earth 's surface is now underlain by continental crust .
Continental crust is also less dense than oceanic crust , though it is considerably thicker ; mostly 35 to 40 km versus the average oceanic thickness of around 7-10 km .
It is less dense than the material of the Earth 's mantle , which consists of mafic rock .
The continental crust is the layer of granitic , sedimentary , and metamorphic rocks which form the continents and the areas of shallow seabed close to their shores , known as continental shelves .

Parasitic wasps are typically parasitoids , and extremely diverse in habits , many laying their eggs in inert stages of their host -LRB- egg or pupa -RRB- , or sometimes paralyzing their prey by injecting it with venom through their ovipositor .
Parasitic wasps are increasingly used in agricultural pest control as they prey mostly on pest insects and have little impact on crops .
With most species , adult parasitic wasps themselves do not take any nutrients from their prey , and , much like bees , butterflies , and moths , those that do feed as adults typically derive all of their nutrition from nectar .
The host remains alive until the parasitoid larvae are mature , usually dying either when the parasitoids pupate , or when they emerge as adults .
They then insert one or more eggs into the host or deposit them upon the host externally .
Almost every pest insect species has at least one wasp species that preys upon it or parasitizes it , making wasps critically important in natural control of their numbers -LRB- biocontrol -RRB- .
Most wasps are social insects , like bees and ants , but there are a few solitary wasps . Social wasps are formed of paper wasps , yellow jackets and hornets .

The Valencia Street Circuit is a semi-permanent street circuit in Valencia Spain .
The circuit will host the Formula One European Grand Prix for seven years starting in The first Formula One race on the circuit was held on 24 August 2008 , with Felipe Massa winning the event , the European Grand Prix .
The circuit has been criticised by the drivers for its lack of overtaking opportunites .
The track is 5.419 k long and incorporates a total of 25 turns . There are 11 right-hand turns and 14 left-hand turns .
The official track layout was unveiled by Valencia councillor and transport minister , Mario Flores , on 19 July 2007 .

Anatoliy Tymoshchuk -LRB- born 30 March 1979 -RRB- is an Ukrainian football player . He plays for Bayern Munich and Ukraine national team .
Nikolai Suetin used suprematist motifs on works at the St. Petersburg Lomonosov Porcelain Factory where Malevich and Chashnik were also employed , and Malevich designed a suprematist teapot .
This development in artistic expression came about when Russia was in a revolutionary state , ideas were in ferment , and the old order was being swept away .
He created a suprematist ` grammar ' based on fundamental geometric forms ; in particular , the square and the circle .
Malevich 's architectural projects were known after 1922 Arkhitektoniki .
`` Black Square '' was painted in 1915 and was a breakthrough in his career and in art in general .
As the new order became established , and Stalinism took hold from 1924 on , the state began limiting the freedom of artists .
The centerpiece of his show was the Black Square , placed in what is called the red\/beautiful corner in Russian Orthodox tradition , the place of the main icon in a house .
Another part of the formalism was low regard for triangles which were dismissed as ancient , pagan , or Christian .
I felt only night within me and it was then that I conceived the new art , which I called Suprematism .
There was some crossover with constructivism , with suprematists such as Lyuba Popova and especially El Lissitzky working on propaganda and industrial design .
Lissitzky spread suprematist ideas abroad in the early 1920s .
Malevich also painted White on White which marked a breakthrough from polychrome to monochrome suprematism .
From the late 1920s the Russian avant-garde experienced direct and harsh criticism from the authorities and in 1934 the doctrine of socialist realism became official policy , and prohibited abstraction and different artistic expression .
Some of the titles to paintings in 1915 express the concept of a non-euclidean geometry which imagined forms in movement , or through time ; titles such as : Two dimensional painted masses in the state of movement .
The suprematists also made architectural models in the 1920s which offered a different conception of socialist buildings to those developed in constructivist architecture .
Designs emphasized the right angle , with similarities to De Stijl and Le Corbusier , and were justified with an ideological connection to communist governance and equality for all .
In 1915 , Malevich exhibited his early experiments in suprematist painting .
Salmonella is closely related to the Escherichia genus and are found worldwide in cold - and warm-blooded animals -LRB- including humans -RRB- , and in the environment .
They cause illnesses like typhoid fever , paratyphoid fever , and the foodborne illness .

There were two cellos that Du PrÃ usually played . One was a Stradivari cellos , the Stradivarius made in 1673 , and the other was made in 1712 and was called the Davydov Stradivarius .
It was the Peresson cello that du PrÃ played for the rest of her career until 1973 , including a second , live recording of the Elgar Concerto , and her last studio recording in 1971 of the sonatas by Frederic Chopin and CÃ sar Franck .
Her last public concerts were in New York in February 1973 , where she was going to play four performances of the Brahms Double Concerto with the violinist Pinchas Zukerman , and Leonard Bernstein conducting the New York Philharmonic .
She performed with the 1673 Stradivarius from 1961 until 1964 when she got the Davydov .
She performed at the The Proms in 1963 playing the Elgar concerto again , with Sir Malcolm Sargent .
After her death a rose was named after her by the Royal Horticultural Society .
Du PrÃ later said she had difficulty in opening the cello case .
From 1969 to 1970 du PrÃ played a Francesco Goffriller cello , and in 1970 she got a modern instrument from the Philadelphia violin maker Sergio Peresson .
Jacqueline du PrÃ met pianist Daniel Barenboim on New Year 's Eve in 1966 .
Both instruments were gifts from her godmother .
She regularly performed with conductors such as Barbirolli , Sir Adrian Boult , Sir Malcolm Sargent , Daniel Barenboim -LRB- her husband -RRB- , Zubin Mehta , and Leonard Bernstein .
They were married the following June -LRB- 1967 -RRB- at the Western Wall in Jerusalem . As her husband was Jewish , she converted to Judaism .
In 1965 , when she was 20 , she recorded the Elgar concerto for EMI with the London Symphony Orchestra and Sir John Barbirolli .
Du PrÃ performed at the Proms every year until 1969 .
She performed the Elgar Concerto for her last London concerts in February 1973 with Zubin Mehta and the New Philharmonia Orchestra .
Many of her most famous recordings were made on this instrument , including the Elgar Concerto with Barbirolli , the Robert Schumann Cello Concerto with Barenboim and the two Brahms cello sonatas .
In 1971 , Jacqueline du PrÃ â s started to suffer from multiple sclerosis . She began to lose feeling in her fingers , as well as in other parts of her body .
She played with the worldâ s greatest orchestras and conductors , including the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra , London Symphony Orchestra , London Philharmonic , New Philharmonia Orchestra , BBC Symphony Orchestra , New York Philharmonic , Israel Philharmonic , and the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra .
She took part in a masterclass with Pablo Casals in Zermatt , Switzerland in 1960 , and had some lessons with Paul Tortelier in Paris in 1962 , and with Mstislav Rostropovich in Russia in 1966 .
In March 1961 , when she was 16 , du PrÃ gave her first concert at the Wigmore Hall , London , and she played the Elgar Cello Concerto in 1962 in the Royal Festival Hall with the BBC Symphony Orchestra conducted by Rudolf Schwarz .
The music building of St Hilda 's College , Oxford is named after her .
Du PrÃ â s main teacher , from 1955 to 1961 , both privately and at the Guildhall School of Music in London , was the famous cellist William Pleeth .
When she was four Jacqueline heard the sound of a cello on the radio and she told her mother she wanted `` one of those . ''
She started with lessons from her mother , who composed little pieces with little drawings . Then , when she was five , she went to the London Violoncello School .

ACE is a measure of the power of the hurricane multiplied by the length of time it existed , so storms that last a long time , as well as strong hurricanes , have high ACEs .
A tropical disturbance in the eastern Caribbean Sea was in an area not expecting any development in the second week of October .
An area of low pressure stopped moving in the Caribbean Sea without showing tropical development for the first few days at the beginning of November .

Ike developed an eye late on September 3 as it did explosive intensification , as it strengthened from a tropical storm to a Category 4 hurricane in twelve hours with an guessed pressure drop of 43 mbars , from 991 to 948 mbars ; and a 24 hour pressure drop of 61 mbar , from 996 to 935 mbars . Ike weakened back to a Category 2 hurricane before re-intensifying back to Category 4 .

It meandered around Puerto Rico and Hispaniola , dumping lots of rain across those islands causing a significant amount of damage , despite never developing a closed circulation .

The National Hurricane Center upgraded the system to Tropical Depression Two in the morning hours of July 3 after the system was able to keep convection over its center for at least 12 hours .
Bertha again began to quickly strengthen on July 9 as a new eye had formed and the system became more symmetrical .
It tracked westward into the Caribbean Sea where it encountered better conditions for cyclone development , and became a tropical depression on the morning of August 25 , west of the Windward Islands .

Ashes of broom were used to treat dropsy , while its strong smell was said to be able to tame wild horses and dogs .
The brooms belong to the subfamily Faboideae of the legume family Fabaceae , mainly in the three genera Chamaecytisus , Cytisus and Genista , but also in five other small genera -LRB- see box , right -RRB- .
All genera in this group are from the tribe Genisteae -LRB- syn .
These genera are all closely related and share similar characteristics of dense , slender green stems and very small leaves , adaptations to dry growing conditions .
Like most brooms , it has apparently leafless stems that in spring and summer are covered with golden-yellow flowers .
In late summer , its pea-pod like seed capsules burst open , often with an audible pop , spreading seed from the parent plant .
A traditional rhyme from Sussex says : `` Sweep the house with blossed broom in May\/sweep the head of the household away . ''
Many brooms -LRB- though not all -RRB- are fire-climax species , adapted to regular stand-replacing fires which kill the above-ground parts of the plants , but create conditions for regrowth from the roots and also for germination of stored seeds in the soil .
Despite this , it was also common to include a decorated bundle of broom at weddings .
All the brooms and their relatives -LRB- including Laburnum and Ulex -RRB- grow in Europe , north Africa and southwest Asia . The greatest diversity one can find in the Mediterranean region .
It makes a shrub about 1 â `` 3m tall , rarely to 4m . It is also the hardiest broom , tolerating temperatures down to about -25 Â C.
Norman Jay Coleman -LRB- May 16 , 1827 -- November 3 , 1911 -RRB- was a newspaper publisher and the first United States Secretary of Agriculture .
His career in politics continued when he was made the Lieutenant Governor of Missouri from 1875 to 1877 .
He was a member of the Freemasons .
Under the administration of President Grover Cleveland , he served as its first Secretary .
He received a law degree from the University of Louisville Law School in 1849 .
As a result of the newspaper , Coleman became an important person in the Missouri farming community , which helped him become a member of the Missouri House of Representatives .
Colemanâ s newspaper stopped due to the American Civil War , but three years after the war he started the Colemanâ s Rural World .

Coleman then moved to Missouri and went into farming .

Extending the definition of remainder for real numbers as described above is not of theoretical importance in mathematics ; however , many programming languages implement this definition -- see modulo operation .
If a and d are integers , with d non-zero , then a remainder is an integer r such that a = qd + r for some integer q , and with 0 â r -LRB- d .
42 = 8 -LRB- 5 -RRB- + -LRB- 2 -RRB- .
If the quotient is constrained to being an integer however , the concept of remainder is still necessary .
As in the case of division of integers , the remainder could be required to be negative , that is , - d -LRB- r â 0 .
This ambiguity in the value of the remainder is not very serious ; in the case above , the negative remainder is obtained from the positive one just by subtracting 5 , which is d. This holds in general .
It can be proved that there exists a unique integer quotient q and a unique real remainder r such that a = qd + r with 0 â r -LRB- d .
When a and d are real numbers , with d non-zero , a can be divided by d without remainder , with the quotient being another real number .
When defined this way , there are two possible remainders .
If a and d are natural numbers , with d non-zero , it can be proved that there exist unique integers q and r , such that a = qd + r and 0 â r -LRB- d. The number q is called the quotient , while r is called the remainder .
So the remainder is then either 3 or 2 .
For example , the division of 42 by 5 can be expressed as either
When dividing by d , if the positive remainder is r1 , and the negative one is r2 , then
In arithmetic , the result of the division of two integers usually can not be expressed with an integer quotient , unless a remainder -- an amount `` left over '' -- is also accepted .

The districts typically have populations of 174,000 to 1.1 million .
In 1986 the old metropolitan county councils were abolished by the Local Government Act 1985 and most of their functions were given to the boroughs , so they are to a large extent unitary authorities .
The new metropolitan boroughs replaced the county boroughs , municipal boroughs and urban and rural districts which existed before .
Some of the functions of the abolished county councils were taken over by joint bodies such as Passenger Transport Authorities , and joint fire , police and waste disposal authorities .
A metropolitan borough -LRB- or metropolitan district -RRB- is a type of local government district in England and covers urban areas within metropolitan counties .

A square foot is a way to measure area . It is the area made by a square that has 1 foot sides .
However , the driftwood provides shelter and food for birds , fish and other aquatic species as it floats in the ocean .
Gribbles , shipworms and bacteria decompose the wood and gradually turn it into nutrients that are reintroduced to the food web .
Driftwood is wood that has been washed onto the shore of a sea , river , or lake by winds , tides , waves or man .
Many people use driftwood as parts of decorative furniture or other art forms , and it is a popular element in the scenery of fish tanks .
According to Norse mythology , the first humans , Ask and Embla , were formed out of two pieces of driftwood , an ash and an elm , by the god Odin and his brothers , Ve and Vili .
Driftwood carried by Arctic rivers was the main , or sometimes only , source of wood for some Inuit and other Arctic populations living north of the tree-line until they came into regular contact with European traders .
In some waterfront areas , driftwood is a major nuisance .
Sometimes , the partially decomposed wood washes ashore , where it also shelters birds , plants , and other species .
Driftwood can become the foundation for sand dunes .
It is a bird of large inland and coastal waters , especially shallow lakes .
It breeds in southern Asia from southern Pakistan .

Courteron is a commune of the Aube dÃ partement in the north-central part of France .
Decent people wo n't believe too many angry remarks that others say about you .
Those articles should be avoided , abandoned , as areas of continual confrontation , at least for a few weeks or months .
Plus , even a small percentage , of users , is a considerable number of difficult users .
Simple Wikipedia has roughly thousand registered users , so if the vast bulk of people were jerks , then every article would be totally trashed , and every user-page would be filled with warring insults added by everyone else .
Then , later , try to improve some other significant article , which is not a battleground for such controversies .
Consequently , they are encountered , every few days , and even though rare , they know how to be difficult .
So it is not a real problem , like it might be in live social settings , where typically , insults must be backed by some real facts to convince others .
The vast majority of Wikipedia articles are written by normal people , with healthy attitudes , and common courtesy .
Avoiding those users also means avoiding several significant articles where they obsess and dwell .
However , remember , in general , when it comes to your `` bad '' wiki-reputation , no one really cares .
Even though they are few , when perhaps 5 people gang up and spew vitriol onto a new user , it gives the intense illusion , as one person concluded : `` The inmates are running the asylum '' .
If people really cared about that , then certainly all difficult users would have been banned for their reputations , many years ago , banned from the wiki-Solar System long ago .
It 's a volunteer project , and most people are too busy to worry about wiki-reputations .
Again , the interactions with difficult users can be so unpleasant that many people have quit .
It might be tempting to try to reform the difficult users .
Most people have simply decided to ignore those difficult users and , also , ignore the veiled insults or other mud thrown at wiki-reputations .
They have a history of being difficult , so they 've had a lot of practice , and know all the tricks to upsetting people .
Basically , you do n't even need to be present , at all , to have a long set of problems thrust into each article you wrote , contacts to users you know , and debates stating how wrong your opinions are -LRB- or rather , would be as the guess you would state -RRB- .
A moderate amount of personal discussion , with those users , could be considered as beneficial to Wikipedia .
Each veiled insult , or slur , against your wiki-reputation can be given an easy spin , with follow-on wording that focuses on a strongly positive view about each comment .
A dull veiled insult , obviously intended to scar your reputation -LRB- in writing -RRB- , is reformed into a 100x times greater compliment , to all who later see the entry .
Most of the admins on Simple Wikipedia are well-mannered and grounded in reality , and any unusual admins who join are generally removed , and soon .
Of course , many Wikipedia editors have left in disgust at such petty , childish , psycho behavior .
However , soon , some of those users will likely `` archive '' your comment topics -LRB- as being old topics -RRB- from the active talk-page , further denying your voice about the article .
The real dangers :
Instead , just keep a private list , off-line from Wikipedia , so that when the names of difficult users re-appear , you can review their infamous antics of the past , and take evasive action .
Now , remember , that several users might just be copy-catting bad behavior , so the first impressions , of how people behave , are somewhat misleading .
Because of the hugely wonderful , over-the-top positive wording , those spins have a second benefit of laughing away the insults , which were not just undone , but thoroughly trounced , beaten down 100 times , by the overly-positive wording of the enthusiastic spin .
In general , people do n't think about who is wrong or who is right , but rather , `` Those guys sure argued a whole lot '' .
Although the glowing , positive terms might seem excessive , the effect is perfect .
It would be unethical to use Wikipedia outside the stated policies of the Wikimedia Foundation , even when following good intentions .
You will have won , completely , and avoided the insulting words of the difficult users .
Rather than having to re-read , each time , the negative wording of the insult , the text to be seen , each time , is the glowing positive view of the improvements -LRB- or other `` great impact to the universe '' -RRB- that you have made .
But they have n't ; instead , troublesome users are generally ignored , and so are their angry remarks about your wiki-reputation .
Most people in charge are not nut-cases , not slowly insulting others .
Confrontations with them can be utterly demoralizing and make people want to quit Wikipedia , then warn hundreds of people about the horrifying , degrading , disgusting experiences they had while being insulted , tormented , and hounded on Wikipedia .
The illusion of `` jerk-ipedia '' is fostered when difficult users band together , as a sort of gang mentality .
Even though you never even entered the discussion , some users will predict your opinions -LRB- in writing -RRB- just to let others see how wrong you are about something you never said .
Specific changes will be reverted and disallowed by them .
At any given time , there are well over 50,000 highly significant article topics , so just visit some minor articles first , until those difficult users have lost interest in following .
The problem of wiki-stalking involves tracing user-editing of various pages , along with determining a list of people you have contacted , by analyzing your access to user-talk pages , or other websites .
To avoid them , perhaps just switch the subject to edit even 5 other , minor articles , and the trolls will lose interest , because the controversial issue they debated has been washed away by the numerous details in 5 dull articles .
Only a few users are difficult , so they should be avoided to keep working with the nice guys .
Wikipedia warns each new user not to reveal personal information .
However , Wikipedia is funded to write the encyclopedia , not provide cyber-counseling or psychiatric treatment to disturbed individuals , and not to convert the hearts of hateful people to become humanized or Christianized .
Perhaps the most you can do is to say a prayer , or otherwise , counsel with them outside the scope of Wikipedia , but always protect your identity : `` Beyond this point , there be demons '' .
Mustering the renewed enthusiasm , to improve even one more article , is the ultimate win .
Vast numbers of users , rarely seen , are highly considerate and intelligent people .
Many types , of difficult users , can be detected early , by off-balance actions that they employ : `` where there 's smoke there 's fire '' .
Perhaps the most that can be done is to lodge a `` POV dispute '' on an article 's talk-page , but not carry out a protracted debate , because the difficult users will likely escalate any rebellion to become wiki-stalking and hounding of their rivals .
Many difficult users tend to block progress , and some simply want to stop others from writing , or expanding articles , with information they do n't want to be shown .
The reason each spin can work so well , against the insults , is that , typically , an insulting remark must be mild -LRB- otherwise it becomes a vicious personal attack -RRB- , so consequently the positive spin can easily claim a viewpoint 100x times the opposite , as an enormous compliment .
Eventually , they snapped , and went out in a `` blaze of glory '' by insulting everything and everyone , until the admins reverted their hateful , final rants from the pages where they had cast their vicious parting remarks .
No , instead , most wiki-people are basically good , and it is just a `` small group '' of difficult users who cause most problems .
Try to tune out the difficult users and , instead , always remember the millions of other people who are helping to improve Wikipedia .
One user thought the solution was to list every difficult user on his user-talk page , but that tends to merely anger them .
There are relatively few difficult users , but they need to be avoided to stay focused on writing the encyclopedia , and not let petty squabbles cause frustrations and doubts about other , decent users .
Consequently , because of that focus , the simple act of ignoring troublesome users , and moving on to improve another article , constitutes a total victory over their attempts to block other people from working on other articles , although the trolled articles are virtually hopeless .
Just as the troll exerts power against those wanting to cross the bridge , the difficult users feel they have a `` captive audience '' in particular articles .
Many difficult users have left within 2 years of joining Wikipedia , as they struggled to gain more power , but were continually ignored or rejected .
The result : insults can always be reworded as a 100x better compliment .
Look for 2 or more warning signs , and compare as repeated patterns of behavior .
However , other less maniacal users have acted as `` semi-trolls '' with more balance , and remained years longer .
Again , many difficult users have a lot of impact , so some new users might get goaded into bad behavior , in a copy-cat manner , and it takes a few combined actions to realize the behavior is a pattern of intentional , negative , and insulting actions by truly difficult users .
Similar to a legendary troll under the bridge , who waits and makes demands of travellers trying to cross the bridge , the difficult users tend to hang around some significant articles , knowing that certain people will want to change or correct part of the text .
Although they do n't necessarily know where anyone lives , some difficult users find where you write .
It 's a guaranteed easy win , with a humerous spin 100x times funnier than the meager insults .
Also , if most trouble makers are ignored rather than scolded , then they lose interest when their victims escape the trap of posting angry replies , so they move on to find other victims .

The paper has won 10 Pulitzer Prizes .
The Black Vulture -LRB- Coragyps atratus -RRB- , also known as the American Black Vulture , is a bird in the New World vulture family whose range extends from the southeastern United States to Central Chile and Uruguay in South America .
Despite the similar name and appearance , this species is unrelated to the Eurasian Black Vulture .
Although a common and widespread species , it has a somewhat more restricted distribution than its compatriot , the Turkey Vulture , which breeds well into Canada and south to Tierra del Fuego .

Sebaceous glands produce the oily , waxy substance called sebum -LRB- Latin , meaning fat or tallow -RRB- that is made of fat -LRB- lipids -RRB- , wax , and the leftover dead fat-producing cells .
Excess sebum has been linked to eating red meats , fried , oily or other foods , but studies are not conclusive .

This is the reason shelf life is generally extended by temperature control : -LRB- refrigeration , insulated shipping containers , controlled cold chain , etc -RRB- and the reason some medicines and foods must be refrigerated .
This is often indicated by a graphic of an open tub , with the number of months written inside -LRB- e.g. , `` 12M '' means use the product within 12 months of opening -RRB- .
The same is true , to a point , of the chemical reactions of life .
Nitroglycerine is notorious .
Open Dating is the use of a date or code stamped on the package of a food product to help determine how long to display the product for sale .
The Agriculture Dept. , which controls fresh produce and meats , only requires labeling of the date when poultry is packed at the farm .
Rubber products also degrade as sulphur bonds induced during vulcanization revert ; this is why old rubber bands and other rubber products soften and get sticky as they age .
Many other brewers have started adding freshness dates to their products , but there is no standard for what the date means .
Foods that have a best before date are usually safe to eat after the date has passed , although they are likely to have deteriorated either in flavor , texture , appearance or nutrition .
Just as temperature increase speeds up reactions , temperature decreases reduce them .
However , as with all rules of thumb , there are many caveats and assumptions .
A study done by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration covered over 100 drugs , prescription and over-the-counter .
These breakdown processes usually happen more quickly at higher temperatures .
That 's because formula must contain a certain quantity of each nutrient that is described on the label .
In this case , a term like best before see bottom or best before see lid might be printed on the label and the date marked in a different location as indicated .
These dates are meant to help keep track of the stock in stores .
Preservatives and antioxidants may be put into some food and drug products to make their shelf life longer .
Joel Davis , a former FDA expiration-date compliance chief , said that with a handful of exceptions - notably nitroglycerin , insulin and some liquid antibiotics - most expired drugs are probably effective .
This is important , as stores can be fined for selling out of date products . Most shops , if not all , will have to mark such products down as wasted , leading to a loss of profit .
The shelf life is an important factor to health .
Examples are the breakdown of many chemical explosives into more unstable compounds .
Transparent beer bottles do not .
A product that has passed its shelf life might still be safe , but quality is no longer guaranteed .
Generally , foods that have a use by date written on the packaging must not be eaten after it has expired .
The results showed that about 90 % of them were safe and effective as far as 15 years past their expiration date .
In most food stores , shelf life is controlled by using stock rotation . This means moving products with the earliest sell by date to the front of the shelf , so that most shoppers will pick them up first and so getting them out of the store .

Vladimir Kramnik , born 25 June 1975 , is a Russian chess grandmaster .
He was Classical World Chess Champion from 2000 to 2006 , and undisputed World Chess Champion from 2006 to 2007 .
In October 2000 , he defeated Garry Kasparov in a match played in London , and became the Classical World Chess Champion .
In October 2006 , Kramnik , the Classical World Champion , defeated reigning FIDE World Champion Veselin Topalov in a unification match .

Xangsane made landfall in the Philippines , battering the northern islands with torrential rains and strong winds , and causing widespread flooding and landslides .
Later that day the JTWC upgraded as the depression moved towards the west it was upgraded to a Tropical Storm by the JTWC .
Philippine Airlines canceled over half of its flights to and from Ninoy Aquino International Airport for September 28 , and various transit services also suspended service .
When it became clear that Xangsane would approach the Capital , PAGASA upgraded the warning for Manila and central Luzon to Storm Signal Number 3 on September 28 .
The JTWC ceased advisories after landfall , while the JMA carried the storm inland until it was over Thailand as a tropical depression .
Storm Signal Number 2 , for winds of 60 - 100 km\/h -LRB- 37 - 62 mph -RRB- , was raised for northern Samar Island and central Luzon .
On September 27 , PAGASA issued Storm Signal Number 3 , a warning for winds of 100 - 185 km\/h -LRB- 62 - 115 mph -RRB- , for areas of southern Luzon .
Early the next day Xangsane was upgraded to a category 2 typhoon and then over the next six hours Xangsane rapidly intensified into a category 4 typhoon with wind speeds of 115 kts -LRB- 130 mph , 215 km\/h -RRB- .
Schools in the warned area were suspended , and airports and seaports were closed .
Typhoon Xangsane -LRB- international designation : 0615 , JTWC designation : 18W , PAGASA name : Typhoon Milenyo -RRB- was a deadly typhoon that affected the Philippines , Vietnam , and Thailand during the 2006 Pacific typhoon season .
After passing over Manila and emerging over the South China Sea , the typhoon made a second landfall in central Vietnam , also causing flooding and landslides there and in Thailand .
The JTWC assessed the development of a significant Tropical cyclone , as fair .
Late on September 24 , 2006 , the Joint Typhoon Warning Center , noted that an area of convection , had persisted about 460 NM to the southeast of Manila , in the Philippines .
Early that afternoon the JTWC reported that Xangsane , had reached its peak wind speeds of 125 kts -LRB- 145 mph , 230 km\/h -RRB- .
It was the fifteenth tropical storm and ninth typhoon recognized by the Japan Meteorological Agency operationally during the season , although in post-operational analysis it became the tenth typhoon of the season with the addition of Typhoon Maria .
Meanwhile the JMA reported that Xangsane had reached its peak wind speeds of 85 kts -LRB- 100 mph , 155 km\/h -RRB- .
Xangsane then passed through the Philippine islands , wreaking havoc and becoming the strongest typhoon to directly impact Metro Manila in eleven years .
Later on September 26 , the JMA upgraded Xangsane to a severe tropical storm , whilst six hours later both the JMA and the JTWC upgraded Xangsane to typhoon with the JTWC reporting wind speeds equivalent to a category one typhoon .
Later that morning the JTWC reassessed the potential of the disturbance forming into a significant tropical Cyclone within 24 hours as good , and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert on the developing disturbance .
According to the Joint Typhoon Warning Center , Xangsane was the sixteenth tropical storm and tenth typhoon of the season , and was a Category 4-equivalent typhoon in terms of 1-minute average wind speeds .
Storm Signal Number 1 -LRB- 30 - 60 km\/h , 20 - 37 mph -RRB- was issued for northwestern Luzon , including Metro Manila , and northern Visayas , including the rest of Samar Island .
This was because convection was beginning to flare up near a developing Low Level Circulation Center , the JTWC also noted that the disturbance had a broad circulation .
Early the next day both the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Philippine Atmospheric , Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration -LRB- PAGASA -RRB- designated the Tropical disturbance as a Tropical Depression with PAGASA assigning the local name of Tropical Depression Milenyo , to the depression .
As it entered the South China Sea as a weak typhoon , it began to re-intensify , reaching its secondary peak strength shortly before landfall at Danang , Vietnam on October 1 .
Early that afternoon the JTWC started to issue advisories on the disturbance and designated it as Tropical Depression 18W .

The National Register of Historic Places -LRB- NRHP -RRB- is the United States government 's official list of districts , sites , buildings , structures , and objects worthy of preservation .
Each year around 30,000 properties are added to the National Register as part of districts or through individual listings .
The National Register of Historic Places -LRB- NRHP -RRB- is the United States government 's official list of districts , sites , buildings , structures , and objects worthy of preservation . The passing of the National Historic Preservation Act -LRB- NHPA -RRB- in 1966 created the National Register and the method for adding properties to it .

The sculpture was made from the same weathering steel -LRB- also known as Cor-Ten -RRB- as the Angel of the North sculpture . This slowly develops a tightly adhering oxide layer as it is exposed to the elements .
Despite Gormley 's plea , removal of B of the Bang began in April 2009 .
In May 2006 a total of nine spikes were removed from the sculpture and taken away for metallurgical analysis , to discover the stresses being placed on the steel .
It was taken apart in 2009 due to structural problems .
B of the Bang originally stood 56 m tall . It had 180 hollow tapered steel columns or spikes coming out of a central core .
One possibility involved the replacement of the steel spikes with alternatives made from carbon fiber , although the report underlined the necessity for extensive testing .
This was the largest load that could be transferred via road from the factory , and required a police escort .
As a result some of the joints were re-welded , with equipment put in place to prevent excessive movement .
After inspection , the event went ahead as planned .
Six days before the launch , the sculpture suffered the first of three visible structural problems . The tip of one of the spikes came off and fell to the ground .
The report recognized the sculpture 's aesthetic value for Manchester and Manchester City Council committed itself to working with the artist to reach a long-term solution .
The sculpture was commissioned in 2003 . Construction went longer than planned and the official unveiling was delayed until 12 January 2005 .
The artwork had been nicknamed KerPlunk by the locals after the popular children 's game from the 1970s .
It was taller and leaned at a greater angle than the Leaning Tower of Pisa .
It took its name from a quotation of British sprinter Linford Christie in which he said that he started his races not merely at the ` bang ' of the starting pistol , but at ` The B of the Bang ' .
The location of the time capsule after being taken apart is currently unknown .
Legal action started a year later , resulting in an out-of-court settlement totalling Â # 1.7 m.
In total the sculpture cost Â # 1.42 million to design and construct â '' twice the original estimate , as the initial costing had neglected to include installation costs .
The design was selected by a panel consisting of both local residents and art experts via a competition in 2002 . The sculpture was designed by Thomas Heatherwick .
Angel of the North stands at 66 f. It was designed to look like an exploding firework . It was taller and leaned at a greater angle than the Leaning Tower of Pisa .
It was approved at the start of 2003 , with the central core arriving in Manchester on the 13 June 2004 .
Funding was sourced from a European Regional Development Fund contribution of Â # 700,000 , the North West Development Agency , contributing Â # 500,000 , and Manchester City Council providing Â # 120,000 .
It was angled at 30 degrees and supported by five 25 m long , tapered steel legs . These connected to the spikes 22 m above the ground .
Early estimates had given an optimistic completion date of July 2003 , which contributed to the sculpture gaining the nickname G of the Bang .
In February 2009 Manchester City Council announced that the sculpture would be taken apart and placed in storage , as the `` only practical alternative '' .
The tip of one of the 2.1 m spikes detached and fell from the sculpture on the 6 January 2005 , only six days before the official unveiling .
Four months later , in May 2005 , a second spike had to be cut off by firefighters after it was discovered hanging loose .
This layer prevents further corrosion by reducing its permeability to water .
This consisted of retrofitting tip weights to 170 of the spikes .
The foundations are 20 m deep .
The official unveiling by Linford Christie took place on 12 January 2005 .
The sculpture weighed 165 tonnes . The concrete in the foundations weighed over 1,000 tonnes , including a 400 m reinforced concrete slab .
As part of the design , the spikes moved slightly in the wind in order to withstand gusts over 100 m. At the time of construction a time capsule was placed in one of the spikes of the sculpture . It contained children 's poems and paintings , due to be opened around 2300 .
The agreement was to pay the council Â # 1.7 m in damages for breach of contract and negligence .
Despite the promise of storage and potential reassembly , the core and legs of the sculpture were cut apart during removal .
In January 2009 , Antony Gormley , creator of the Angel of the North â '' to which B of the Bang is often compared â '' spoke out in support of the sculpture , stating that , `` It is a great tribute to Manchester that this ground-breaking work was commissioned .
This central core was lifted into place in August 2004 , after which the 180 spikes could begin being attached .
In November 2008 this culminated in an out-of-court settlement being reached between Manchester City Council , the project 's designers Thomas Heatherwick Studio Ltd , and the engineering and construction subcontractors Packman Lucas Ltd , Flint and Neill Partnership and Westbury Structures Ltd. .
Despite these modifications , B of the Bang remained fenced off , prompting a local newspaper campaign to ` Get It Sorted ' .
Commissioned to mark the 2002 Commonwealth Games , it was one of the tallest structures in the City of Manchester . It was the tallest sculpture in the UK until the completion of Aspire in 2008 .
It was announced in October 2007 that Manchester City Council were taking legal action against the makers of the sculpture , with the aim of completing the necessary repairs to the sculpture .
Acting on a report in January 2009 , the city council recommended that B of the Bang should be dismantled and placed in storage until funds could be raised for its safe reinstatement .
To allow it to disappear would be a loss not just of an inspirational artwork but also of the council 's nerve . ''
The sculpture was constructed in Sheffield by Thomas Heatherwick Studio , Packman Lucas , Flint and Neill and Westbury Structures .
B of the Bang was a sculpture in Manchester , England , located next to the City of Manchester Stadium at Sportcity . The work was designed by Thomas Heatherwick .
The sculpture took its name from a quotation of British sprinter Linford Christie . In the quotation he said that he started his races not at the `` bang '' of the starting pistol , but at ` The B of the Bang ' .
More substantial hoarding was erected around the site and demolition firm Connell Bros Ltd. began removing the spikes with oxyacetylene cutting equipment .
At that time the sculpture was closed off to the public , and the junction and pathway near the sculpture were temporarily closed .
B of the Bang was located next to the City of Manchester Stadium at Sportcity , in Beswick , at the corner of Alan Turing Way and Ashton New Road ; coordinates .
The council said it was committed to working closely with the design team in order to `` determine whether there is a robust and affordable strategy for the re-construction of the structure on the site '' .
It was commissioned by New East Manchester Limited to commemorate the 2002 Commonwealth Games .
Although the council had earlier promised to store the complex central core and legs , these too were cut apart during removal , casting doubt on future prospects for the landmark sculpture 's return .

There are stories of pigs , sheep or other domestic farm animals consuming duroplast .
Duroplast is a resin plastic made up mixing formica and bakelite reinforced with fibers -LRB- either cotton or wool -RRB- or glass fibers .
It was also made of recycled material , cotton waste from Russia and phenol resins from the East German dye industry making the Trabant the first car with a body made of recycled material .
Duroplast can not be completely recycled , and burning it produces toxic fumes , so disposing of the bodies of old Trabants is a problem .
Duroplast was used by Eastern European automobile manufacturer VEB Sachsenring Automobilwerke Zwickau to produce the body of the popular Trabant motor car , toilet seats , and parts for the BMW X3 .
Because it can be made in a press similar to shaping steel , it 's easy to produced .
A Berlin biotechnology company claims that it has developed a solution to the duroplast problem : a bacterium that will eat a Trabant in 20 days and leave only compost .
Apart from the use in cars duroplast was also used to make suitcases .
Duroplast was first used in the body of the IFA F8 and later also the AWZ P70 or Zwickau P70 and later used in the body of the Trabant .
Duroplast is light , flexible , and strong .

British Rail Class 158 Express Sprinter is a type of diesel multiple unit -LRB- DMU -RRB- train . They were built for British Rail between 1989 and 1992 by BREL at their Derby Works .
They were built to replace old DMUs and locomotive-hauled passenger trains .

The Advertising Council , mostly called as the Ad Council , is an American non-profit organization that creates public service announcements on behalf of sponsors , including non-profit organizations and the United States government .
The Advertising Council was created in 1941 , and shortly after , in February 1942 , it was registered as the The War Advertising Council for the purpose of being in the advertising industry in support of the war effort .
In 1945 , the Ad Council began working with the National Safety Council .
The Advertising Council does not make public service advertisements for itself but it acts as a creator of them for others .
After the Second World War the War Advertising Council changed its name to the Advertising Council and shifted its focus to peacetime ads .
The Advertising Council allows sponsor organizations to create advertising that are on social issues as well .

Peter Coudrin of France founded the Congregation of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary on Dec 24 , 1800 .
The Catholic acts of consecration , reparation and devotion were introduced when the feast of the Sacred Heart was declared .
It was in the fervent atmosphere of the Benedictine or Cistercian monasteries , in the world of those who followed the teachings of St. Anselm or St. Bernard of Clairveaux , that the devotion arose , although it is impossible to say positively what were its first texts or who were its first devotees c. From the 13th century to the sixteenth century , the devotion was propagated but it did not seem to have developed in itself .
It was , nevertheless , a private , individual devotion of the mystical order .
In his Papal Bull `` Auctorem Fidei '' , Pope Pius VI praised devotion to the Sacred Heart .
The practice of the Enthronement is based upon Pope Pius XII 's declaration that devotion to the Sacred of Jesus is `` the foundation on which to build the kingdom of God in the hearts of individuals , families , and nations ... '' -LRB- 4 -RRB-
Little by little , the devotion to the Sacred Heart became a separate one , and on August 31 , 1670 , the first feast of the Sacred Heart was celebrated in the Grand Seminary of Rennes .
Sacred Heart is still a widely used name for many Catholic institutions , including schools , colleges , and hospitals in many countries around the world .
It is common in Roman Catholic services and occasionally is to be found in Anglican services .
Coutances followed suit on October 20 , a day with which the Eudist feast was from then on to be connected .
The devotion spread , particularly in religious communities .
It was everywhere practiced by individuals and by different religious congregations , such as the Franciscans , Dominicans , Carthusians , etc. .
The mirror images reflect an eternal binding of the two hearts .
It is also the name of many Catholic parishes , religious orders , and stores selling Catholic goods .
The Feast of the Sacred Heart is a holy day in the Roman Catholic liturgical calendar , and is celebrated 19 days after Pentecost .
-LRB- 3 -RRB- In the eleventh and twelfth centuries the first indications of devotion to the Sacred Heart of Jesus are found .
The Marseilles plague , 1720 , furnished perhaps the first occasion for a solemn consecration and public worship outside of religious communities .
There is nothing to indicate that she had known the devotion prior to the revelations , or at least that she had paid any attention to it .
Worship of the Sacred Heart mainly consists of several hymns , the Salutation of the Sacred Heart , and the Litany of the Sacred Heart .
In his letter to Father Kolvenbach , Pope Benedict reaffirmed the importance of the devotion to the Sacred Heart of Jesus .
It was established as a devotion with prayers already formulated and special exercises , found in the writings of Lanspergius -LRB- d. 1539 -RRB- of the Carthusians of Cologne , the Louis of Blois -LRB- Blosius ; 1566 -RRB- , a Benedictine and Abbot of Liessies in Hainaut , John of Avila -LRB- d. 1569 -RRB- and St. Francis de Sales , the latter belonging to the seventeenth century .
Since c. 1850 , groups , congregations , and States have consecrated themselves to the Sacred Heart .
The image of the Sacred Heart of Jesus was everywhere in evidence , largely due to the Franciscan devotion to the Five Wounds and to the habit formed by the Jesuits of placing the image on their title-page of their books and the walls of their churches .

Religious imagery depicting the Sacred Heart is frequently featured in Catholic , and sometimes Anglican homes .
A blessed image of the Sacred Heart , either a statue or a picture , is then `` enthroned '' in the home to serve as a constant reminder to those who dwell in the house of their consecration to the Sacred Heart .
On May 15 , 2006 , Pope Benedict XVI sent a letter to FatherPeter Hans Kolvenbach , the Superior General of the Society of Jesus , on the 50th Anniversary of the encyclical `` Haurietis Aquas '' , about the Sacred Heart , by Pope Pius XII .
In 1889 it was raised by the Catholic Church to the double rite of first class .
The prayer `` O Sacred Heart of Jesus , I place all my trust in Thee '' is often used .
Sometimes images display beneath them a list of family members , indicating that the entire family is entrusted to the protection of Jesus in the Sacred Heart , from whom blessings on the home and the family members are sought .
Outside of the Visitandines , priests , religious , and laymen espoused the devotion , particularly a Capuchin , Margaret Mary 's two brothers , and some Jesuits , among the latter being Fathers Croiset and Gallifet , who promoted the devotion .
The Enthronement of the Sacred Heart is a Catholic ceremony in which a priest or head of a household consecrates the members of the household to the Sacred Heart .
Nevertheless , the devotion remained an individual , or at least a private , devotion .
The most significant source for the devotion to the Sacred Heart in the form it is known today was a nun of the religious congregation of the Visitation of Mary Saint Margaret Mary Alacoque -LRB- 1647-1690 -RRB- , who claimed to have received visions of Jesus Christ .
Jean Eudes -LRB- 1602-1680 -RRB- made it public , gave it an Office , and established a feast for it .
Finally , by order of Leo XIII , in his encyclical `` Annum Sacrum '' -LRB- May 25 , 1899 -RRB- , as well as on June 11 , he consecrated every human to the Sacred Heart .
In the sixteenth century , the devotion passed from the domain of mysticism into that of Christian asceticism .
Nothing of a general movement had been inaugurated , except for similarities found in the devotion to the Five Wounds by the Franciscans , in which the wound in Jesus ' Heart figured most prominently .
Margaret Mary reported feeling `` dreadful confusion '' over the book 's contents , but resolved to make the best of it , approving of the book for the spreading of her cherished devotion .
In spite of all sorts of obstacles , and of the slowness of the Holy See , which in 1693 imparted indulgences to the Confraternities of the Sacred Heart and , in 1697 , granted the feast to the Visitandines with the Mass of the Five Wounds , but refused a feast common to all , with special Mass and Office .
Other cities of the South followed the example of Marseilles , and thus the devotion became a popular one .

Roasted eggs are used at the Jewish holiday of Passover Eating raw eggs is not recommended for people who may be likely to catch to salmonella , such as the elderly , the infirm , or pregnant women .
They can be pickled ; hard-boiled , soft-boiled , scrambled , fried and refrigerated ; or eaten raw .
Most eggs that are eaten by humans , including birds ' eggs and turtle 's eggs , have a protective , oval eggshell , the albumen -LRB- egg white -RRB- , the vitellus -LRB- egg yolk -RRB- , and various thin membranes , that are layers like skin . Every part of the egg is edible , although the eggshell is usually thrown away .
Chicken eggs are widely used in many types of cooking . Dishes that use eggs range from both sweet to savoury dishes .
Most commercially produced chicken eggs intended for human consumption are unfertilized , because hens are kept without any roosters .
Fertile eggs can be bought and eaten as well .
The most commonly used bird eggs are those from the chicken , the duck , and the goose , but smaller eggs such as quail eggs are occasionally used as a gourmet ingredient , as are the largest bird eggs , from ostriches .
The body can use about 91 % of the protein of a cooked eggs , nearly twice as much as from a raw egg .
Only selenium tetrachloride escapes . This is reduced to selenium again , making pure selenium .
This can be used to purify selenium . Impure selenium can be placed in the flask , reacted with chlorine .
It reacts with selenium dioxide to make selenium oxychloride , a mixture of selenium dioxide and selenium tetrachloride bonded together .
Only selenium tetrachloride escapes .
Selenium tetrachloride is a yellow or white solid .
It is used to make other selenium compounds .

Following the Turko-Persian Mahmud of Ghazni 's Ghaznavid conquest of South Asia , a hybrid language of Turkish , Arabic and Persian and local dialects began to form , one that would eventually be known as Urdu .
Under Persian influence from the state , the Persian script and Nasta ` liq form of cursive writing was adopted , with additional figures added to accommodate the Indic phonetic system .
This language was called Zaban-e-Ordu -LRB- ` language of the army ' -RRB- to distinguish it from Farsi , the court language , and was later shortened to just Urdu .
Many distinctly Persian forms of literature , such as Ghazal , Qasida , Marsia and Nazms , caried over into Urdu literature , producing a distinct melding of Iranian and South Asian heritages .
Some grammatical elements peculiar to Persian , such as the enclitic ezÄ fe , and the use of the takhallus , were readily absorbed into Urdu literature both religious and secular .
A famous cross-over writer was Amir Khusro , whose Persian and Urdu couplets are to this day read in South Asia .
Urdu is a morpho-syntax\/grammatically an Indic language , written in the Perso-Arabic script , and contains literary conventions and specialised vocabulary largely from Persian .
Despite the heavy influence of Persian on Urdu , linguistically , Urdu is not classified as an Iranian language -LRB- as is Persian -RRB- but rather as an Indo-Aryan language -LRB- like Punjabi , Gujarati , Punjabi , Seraiki and Sindhi -RRB- .
The Persian language influenced the formation of many modern languages of the Greater Middle East , Central Asia , and South Asian regions , including Urdu .
It grew from the interaction of Persian and Turkic speaking Muslim soldiers and the native peoples .
Urdu soon gained distinction in literary and cultural spheres because of the hybrid nature of the language .

Knol has `` nofollow '' outgoing links , using an HTML directive . This prevents links in its articles from influencing search engine rankings .
Content designed to promote businesses , products or services is allowed , but articles devoid of substantive content and created solely to generate ad revenue are not .

Knol is a Google project which aims to include user-written articles on a range of topics .
There has been debate whether Google search results can remain neutral because of possible conflict of interest .

The term knol , which Google defines as a `` unit of knowledge '' , refers to both the project and an article in the project .

This is the diurnal motion -LRB- daily motion -RRB- .
As an angle of 1 Â corresponds to 4 minutes in time -LRB- 360 Â = 24 hours -RRB- , we need therefore 4 extra minutes of diurnal motion to see the Sun back on the same meridian again , making the duration of one rotation just 24 hours exactly -LRB- on the average , ignoring small seasonal variations , see equation of time -RRB-
The Earth rotates from west to east around its axis once every 24 hours . The celestial sphere and all objects on it appear to rotate from east to west around the celestial poles in the same time .
Such globes map the constellations on the outside of a sphere , resulting in a mirror image of the constellations as seen from Earth .
In astronomy and navigation , the celestial sphere is an imaginary sphere -LRB- ball -RRB- of a very large unspecified size . The sphere is concentric with the Earth .
The reason for this is that the Sun does not stand still on the celestial sphere , and the stars do . The sun moves about 1 Â per day eastwards over a great circle known as the ecliptic -LRB- which is 360 Â or a full circle in one year , the annual motion of the Sun -RRB- .
On the next night a particular star will rise again , but with our normal clocks running a 24 hour 0 minutes cycle , it will do so 4 minutes earlier .

p202 Evaporation is especially high in its eastern half , causing the water level to decrease and salinity to increase eastward .
Evaporation greatly exceeds precipitation and river runoff in the Mediterranean , a fact that is central to the water circulation within the basin .
The Sea of Marmara is often considered a part of the Mediterranean Sea , whereas the Black Sea is generally not .
The Mediterranean has a deep blue color .
The combination of similarly shared climate , geology and access to a common sea has led to numerous historical and cultural connections between the ancient and modern societies around the Mediterranean .
As a sea around which some of the most ancient human civilizations were arranged , it has had a major influence on the history and ways of life of these cultures .
It provided a way of trade , colonization and war , and was the basis of life -LRB- via fishing and the gathering of other seafood -RRB- for numerous communities throughout the ages .
To the east it connects to the Sea of Marmara and the Black Sea , by the Dardanelles and the Bosporus respectively .
p206 This pressure gradient pushes relatively cool , low-salinity water from the Atlantic across the basin ; it warms and becomes saltier as it travels east , then sinks in the region of the Levant and circulates westward , to spill over the Strait of Gibraltar .
Being nearly landlocked affects the Mediterranean Sea 's properties . Tides are limited by the narrow connection with the Atlantic Ocean .
p206\/7 Thus , seawater flow is eastward in the Strait 's surface waters , and westward below ; once in the Atlantic , this chemically distinct `` Mediterranean Intermediate Water '' can persist thousands of kilometers away from its source .

Throughout modern times , the largest known prime number has very often been a Mersenne prime .
Since there are tricks to finding Mersenne primes quickly the largest primes known are usually Mersenne primes .
Historically , the study of Mersenne primes was motivated by this connection ; in the 4th century BC Euclid demonstrated that if M is a Mersenne prime then M -LRB- M +1 -RRB- \/ 2 is a perfect number .
A Mersenne prime is a Mersenne number that is a prime number . , The exponent n must be prime too .
Mersenne primes have a close connection to perfect numbers , which are numbers equal to the sum of their proper divisors .
Most sources restrict the term Mersenne number to where n is prime , as all Mersenne primes must be of this form as seen below .
And 24 -1 = 15 can be shown to be composite because 4 is not prime .
A Mersenne prime is a Mersenne number that is a prime number .

So far reaching were the bishopâ s powers that the steward of Bishop Anthony Bek commented in 1299 AD : â There are two kings in England , namely the Lord King of England , wearing a crown in sign of his regality and the Lord Bishop of Durham wearing a mitre in place of a crown , in sign of his regality in the diocese of Durhamâ . All this activity was administrated from the castle and buildings surrounding the Palace Green .
As the north east was so far from Westminster the bishops of Durham enjoyed extraordinary powers . They had the ability to hold their own parliament , raise their own armies , appoint their own sheriffs and Justices , administer their own laws , levy taxes and customs duties , create fairs and markets , issue charters , salvage shipwrecks , collect revenue from mines , administer the forests and mint their own coins .
Durham is well known for its Norman Cathedral and 11th-century castle , and is home to Durham University .
It lies to the south of Newcastle Upon Tyne , Chester-le-Street and Sunderland and to the north of Darlington .
The Prince Bishops also had their own court system , most notably the Durham Court of Chancery .
The present city can clearly be traced back to AD 995 , when a group of monks from Lindisfarne chose to settle there with the body of Saint Cuthbert , which had previously lain in Chester-le-Street .
Durham is well known for its Norman Cathedral and 11th-century castle , and is home to Durham University . HM Prison Durham is also located close to the city center .
It is within the County Durham local government district , and is the county town of the larger ceremonial county .
The county also had its own attorney general , whose authority to bring an indictment for criminal matters was tested by central government in the infamous case of Rex v. Mary Ann Cotton -LRB- 1832 -RRB- .
The courts and judicial posts for the county were finally abolished in 1873 .
Durhamâ s geographical position has always given it an important position in the defense of England against the Scots .
Before the Reformation the shrine of Saint Cuthbert , situated behind the High Altar of Durham Cathedral , was the most important religious site in England until the martyrdom of St. Thomas Becket at Canterbury .
Every Bishop of Durham from 1071 to 1836 was a Prince Bishop except for the first Norman-appointed Bishop Walcher who was styled an Earl-Bishop .
Saint Bede 's bones are also entombed in the cathedral , drawing the mediaeval pilgrim to the city .
HM Prison Durham is also located close to the city center .
Despite a brief translation back to Holy Island during the Norman Invasion the saint 's relics remain enshrined to the present day .
The city has played an important part in the defense of the north and Durham Castle is the only Norman castle keep never to have suffered a breach .
The city suffered from a number of plague outbreaks in 1544 , 1589 and 1598 .
Henry VIII cut some of the Prince-Bishop 's powers and , in 1538 , ordered the destruction of the shrine of Saint Cuthbert .
The last Prince Bishop of Durham Bishop William Van Mildert founded Durham University .
The Battle of Neville 's Cross which took place near the city on 17 October 1346 between the English and Scots was the most famous battle of its age .
Archeological evidence shows settlement in the area since 2000 BC .
