The White House is the home and main workplace of the President of the United States .
The property is owned by the National Park Service and is part of the President 's Park .
Construction continued with the addition of the South Portico in 1824 and the North in 1829 .
Eight years later , President William Howard Taft expanded the West Wing and created the first Oval Office . This was eventually moved as the section was expanded .
Under Harry S. Truman , the interior rooms were completely taken apart and a new internal load-bearing steel frame was built inside the walls .
In 2007 , it was ranked second on the American Institute of Architects list of `` America 's Favorite Architecture . ''
Once this work was done , the interior rooms were rebuilt .
A newly built East Wing was used as a reception area for social events . Jefferson 's colonnades connected the new wings .
Reconstruction began almost immediately . President James Monroe moved into the partially reconstructed house in October 1817 .
The term White House is regularly used as a metonym for the Executive Office of the President of the United States and for the president 's administration and advisers in general .
By 1948 , the house 's load-bearing exterior walls and internal wood beams were found to be close to failure .
Because of crowding within the executive mansion itself , President Theodore Roosevelt had all work offices moved to the newly constructed West Wing in 1901 .
When Thomas Jefferson moved into the house in 1801 , he -LRB- with architect Benjamin Henry Latrobe -RRB- expanded the building outward . They made two colonnades that were meant to hide stables and storage .
East Wing changes were completed in 1946 .
The third-floor attic was changed into living quarters in 1927 .
The White House is made up of six storiesâ '' the Ground Floor , State Floor , Second Floor , and Third Floor , as well as a two-story basement .
It has been the home of every U.S. President since John Adams .
It is located at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue NW in Washington , D.C. . The building was built between 1792 and 1800 of white-painted Aquia sandstone in the Neoclassical style .
In 1814 , during the War of 1812 , the mansion was set on fire by the British Army in the Burning of Washington .
Today , the White House Complex includes the Executive Residence , West Wing , Cabinet Room , Roosevelt Room , East Wing , and the Old Executive Office Building , which houses the executive offices of the President and Vice President .

In September 2010 , The Sunday Times selected King 's as its `` University of the Year '' .
King 's is ranked 63rd in the world -LRB- and 16th in Europe -RRB- in the 2010 Academic Ranking of World Universities , 21st in the world -LRB- and 6th in Europe -RRB- in the 2010 QS World University Rankings , and 77th in the world -LRB- and 15th in Europe -RRB- in the 2010 The Times Higher Education World University Rankings .
King 's College London -LRB- ` King 's ' or ` KCL ' -RRB- is a public research university in London , and a college of the federal University of London .
King 's has around 18,600 full-time students and 5,030 staff and had a total income of Â # 508 million in 2009\/10 , of which Â # 144 million was from research grants and contracts .
It forms part of the ` Golden Triangle ' of British universities .
King 's is one of the largest centres for graduate and post-graduate medical teaching and biomedical research in Europe . It is home to six Medical Research Council centres , the most of any British university .
King 's is a member of the European University Association and the Russell Group .
In 1836 King 's became one of the two founding colleges of the University of London .
There are 10 Nobel Prize winners amongst King 's alumni and current and former faculty .

Vancouver , Washington is a United States city , just north of the Columbia River in the state of Washington . It is directly north of Portland , Oregon and 305 m south of Vancouver , British Columbia .
Because it is in a valley between the Pacific Coast and Cascade mountains , there are clouds in winter . When it is clear one can see Mount Hood , the Mount Saint Helens volcano and Mount Adams from Vancouver .
Vancouver is just north of the Columbia River and west of the volcanic Cascade Range mountains and the Columbia gorge .
Both cities were named for George Vancouver , a British explorer and sea captain . Vancouver , Washington , includes the old Fort Vancouver , begun by the British Hudson 's Bay Company in 1824 .

The climate in Lower Egypt is milder than that of Upper Egypt .
Lower Egypt is the fertile Nile Delta region , which stretches from the area between El-Aiyat and Zawyet Dahshur , south of modern-day Cairo , and the Mediterranean Sea .
Lower Egypt was represented by the Low Red Crown Deshret , and its symbol was the papyrus .
Its patron goddess was the cobra goddess Wadjet .
Lower Egypt was mostly undeveloped scrubland , undeveloped for human life and filled with all types of plant life such as grasses and herbs .
Lower Egypt was known as Ta-Mehu which means `` land of papyrus . ''
The capital of Lower Egypt was Buto .
Western Sahara has been on the United Nations list of non-self-governing territories since the 1960s when it was a Spanish colony .
Polisario has won formal recognition for SADR from 81 states , and was extended membership in the African Union , while Morocco has won recognition for its position from the Arab League .
In both instances , recognitions have over the past two decades been extended and withdrawn according to changing international trends .
The Kingdom of Morocco and the Polisario Front independence movement , with its Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic -LRB- SADR -RRB- government , both want to control of the territory .
Since a United Nations-sponsored ceasefire agreement in 1991 , most of the territory has been controlled by Morocco , backed by France , and the rest by the Polisario\/SADR , backed by Algeria .

Octopuses have a relatively short life expectancy , and some species live for as little as six months .
At least four specimens of the Veined Octopus -LRB- Amphioctopus marginatus -RRB- have been seen picking up discarded coconut shells , and then reassembling them to use as shelter .
The young larval octopuses spend a period of time drifting in clouds of plankton , where they feed until they are ready to descend to the ocean bottom , where the cycle repeats .
All octopuses are venomous , but only the small blue-ringed octopuses are known to be deadly to humans .
An octopus trails its eight arms behind it as it swims .
When octopuses reproduce , males use a specialized arm to put packets of sperm into the female 's mantle cavity .
The female cares for the eggs , guarding them against predators , and gently blowing currents of water over them so that they get enough oxygen .
Larger species , such as the North Pacific Giant Octopus , may live for up to five years under suitable circumstances .
The exact extent of their intelligence and learning capability is much debated among biologists . Maze and problem-solving experiments have shown that they do have both short and long-term memory .
In some species , the female octopus can keep the sperm alive inside her for weeks until her eggs are mature .
Some octopuses , such as the Mimic Octopus , can move their arms in ways which copy the movements of other sea creatures .
They have been seen in what some have described as play : repeatedly releasing bottles or toys into a circular current in their aquariums and then catching them .
Reproduction is a cause of death : males can only live for a few months after mating , and females die shortly after their eggs hatch .
The female does not hunt during the roughly one-month period spent taking care of the unhatched eggs and may ingest some of her own arms for sustenance .
The octopus is the only invertebrate which has been conclusively shown to use tools .
Octopuses often break out of their aquaria and sometimes into others in search of food .
An octopus has a hard beak , and its mouth is at the center point of the arms .
Males die within a few months of mating .
In laboratory experiments , octopuses can be readily trained to distinguish between different shapes and patterns .
There are about 300 octopus species , which is over one-third of the total number of known cephalopods .
At around the time the eggs hatch , the mother leaves the lair and is too weak to defend herself from predators like cod , often succumbing to their attacks .
Most octopuses have no internal or external skeleton , allowing them to squeeze through tight places .
In the UK , cephalopods such as octopuses are regarded as honorary vertebrates under the Animals -LRB- Scientific Procedures -RRB- Act 1986 giving them protection not normally afforded to invertebrates .
They neglect to eat during the -LRB- roughly -RRB- one month period spent taking care of their unhatched eggs , but apparently they do not die of starvation .
The Octopus is a cephalopod mollusc in the order Octopoda .
They have even boarded fishing boats and opened holds to eat crabs .
After they have been fertilized , the female lays about 200,000 eggs -LRB- this figure dramatically varies between species -RRB- .
Octopuses are highly intelligent , probably more so than any other invertebrate .
The term octopus may also be used to refer only to those creatures in the genus Octopus .

Eraclea Mare is famous cause of its pinewood and `` Mort lagoon '' -LRB- in Italian : Laguna del Mort -RRB- .
Eraclea Mare is the Lido of Eraclea .
The Mort stretches between Eraclea Mare and the mouth of the Piave river and it is a sea-lagoon , being supplied with water only by the flood-tides .
It is located on the Adriatic Sea near the coast between the rivers Piave and Livenza and between two famous touristic towns : Caorle and Jesolo .
Still uncontaminated , the Mort is characterized by shallow and calm waters with a sandy and muddy seabed , rich in phytoplankton .
Within the last year , a steady growth of foreign tourists , especially from Germany , has been recorded .
The Mort Lagoon , an extremely evocative naturalistic site between Eraclea and Jesolo , was originated by the overflowing of the Piave river in 1936 , whose bed was modified in its last stretch after a big flood .

A. afarensis is similar to the younger Australopithecus africanus .
Australopithecus afarensis is an extinct hominid . It lived between 3.9 and 2.9 million years ago .
It has been thought that A. afarensis was an ancestor to both the genus Australopithecus and the genus Homo . Homo includes the modern human species , Homo sapiens . .
In the parliamentary session of 1905 plans were submitted for another station at the south end of the tunnel . The station would be underneath Wellington Street .
However , there were legal problems and these delayed the permission that was needed to build the subway and tram route . Permission to build the subway was not given until 1906 , and they were still not allowed to build the tram line over the bridge .
This was in case they were needed for the Coronation . However , proposals to convert the tramway subway to a car park or a film studio failed and it was leased out as a storage facility from October 1957 .
In 1946 , it was decided to replace all of London 's remaining trams `` as soon as possible '' .
A new sharp curve was built under Lancaster Place to alllow an exit through the western side wall of Waterloo Bridge . A triangular junction with the through line was constructed .
In June 1958 , the London County Council proposed to use the tunnel for light traffic coming from Waterloo Bridge . This would reduce traffic congestion at its junction with Strand .
The first public tram through the subway ran on 24 February 1906 . It ran from The Angel , Islington to Aldwych .
In 1929 , it was then decided that the headroom of the tunnel would be increased to 16 f. This would be done by raising the roof or deepening the tunnel as appropriate .
Drivers of the trams recorded difficulty in climbing the ramp north from Holborn tramway station and would sometimes roll all the way back to the station .
On the 16 November of the same year the routes were extended north from The Angel to Highbury station .
A new entrance was built in a position centrally underneath the bridge . This opened on 21 November of that year .
It was 16 m long . This made it the longest tram route operated entirely within the County of London .
In some places the trackbed was lowered by 5 f. This meant that the walls had to be underpinned with concrete .
The southern section of the abandoned tunnel between the Embankment and the Strand Underpass has been converted into a branch of the Buddha Bar chain of bars and restaurants .
The services continued to change for many years , especially when the tram lines over Blackfriars Bridge opened on 14 September 1909 . During the 1920s the LCC also realized that for the subway to remain profitable it would need to be able to take double-deck trams .
The London County Council had two tramway systems called the `` North Side '' and `` South Side '' .
In 1902 , the Council decided to build a tramway that was under the ground -LRB- subway -RRB- . The subway went from Theobalds Road in the north to the Embankment underneath Waterloo Bridge to the south .
Work started on 11 September 1929 . The work resulted in the replacement of the cast iron tubes with a new steel girder-supported roof .
The eastern side of this junction , leading to Blackfriars , was removed as part of the 1930s upgrade .
During the early hours of the next morning all of the remaining trams north of the subway were driven through the subway to the depots south of the Thames .
A weekend service was introduced between Highgate -LRB- Archway -RRB- and Downham via Brockley . This route closed in 1932 .
They ran from Highbury station to Tower Bridge and to Kennington Gate . There was a procession of six cars that went south from the Holborn through to Kennington .
The route used special trams built from materials that could not catch fire . Wooden trams , like those used on other routes , were not allowed to go through the subway .
As well as the whole tunnel being rebuilt , the two tramway stations were as well .
Soon after this takeover , the LPTB decided to replace all of the trams in London by `` more modern vehicles '' .
This latter service was short-lived and the tracks were removed in 1930 .
The abandonment program began in 1935 . The trams in the South-West , West , North-West , North and East London were mostly replaced with trolleybuses .
This involved the demolition of the pedestrian subways under Waterloo Bridge , and extensive construction in the bridge 's undercroft .
At the north end the approach near Southampton Row was an 170 f open cutting with a 1 in 10 -LRB- 10 % -RRB- slope .
The Kennington service was not commercially viable and services were diverted to operate to Queens Road in Battersea . Due to a low bridge this service could only be operated with single-deck vehicles .
The first journey took 10 minutes to go to Aldwych and 12 minutes to get back . This was also allowing for the horse-drawn vehicles that were using the roads on the overground part of the route .
It did not re-open until 14 February 1930 which was the formal re-opening . Tram number 1931 was used on the new route 31 .
When the trams left the subway at the southern end they could turn right along the Embankment to Westminster Bridge or left on a service from Bloomsbury to the Hop Exchange .
In 1933 , the London Passenger Transport Board -LRB- LPTB -RRB- was formed . They took over the London County Council trams .
The tunnel would also only be able to have single-deck trams in it . This was because of a sewer at the northern end of the tunnel and the District Railway at the southern end .
Services now ran from Hackney to Wandsworth or Tooting , Leyton to Westminster , Highbury to Waterloo or Norbury and Archway to Kennington .
Construction began in September of the same year . The subway opened to road traffic as the Strand Underpass on 21 January 1964 .
The trams in London stopped running on 5 July 1952 . After this the tracks on the street were lifted .
In 1940 , the last tram conversion took place before the Second World War . This left only the South London trams and subway routes 31 , 33 and 35 running .
The tracks passed through cast iron tubes underneath the Fleet sewer . They then rose slightly to enter Holborn tramway station .
From here up to Aldwych tramway station the subway was built with a steel roof . Because it was not planned to run a public service south of here at first , the tracks leading towards the Strand were used as a depot with appropriate equipment and inspection pits .
The opening of the new tramway along the Embankment meant it was decided to link up with this route instead and the station was never built .
Drivers on routes through the tunnel had to have at least two years experience on other services to be considered for these routes .
Routes 33 and 35 were closed at the end of service on Saturday 5 April 1952 . The last public services through the subway were ` specials ' which ran on the Sunday , shortly after midnight .
This was because the trolleybuses would have had to run on battery power through the subway . They would have had to have used battery power because headroom restrictions made it impossible to use overhead current collection .

Marshal of the Royal Air Force Hugh Montague Trenchard , 1st Viscount Trenchard GCB OM GCVO DSO -LRB- 3 February 1873 -- 10 February 1956 -RRB- was a British Army soldier who did a lot to start the Royal Air Force .
In 1912 , Trenchard learned to fly and joined the Royal Flying Corps .
As a boy Trenchard found learning difficult .
After his health got better still , Trenchard returned to the war in South Africa .
In modern times , some people say that Trenchard was one of the first people to argue for strategic bombing .
Trenchard first when to India with the Army and he then asked to go to South Africa because he wanted to fight in the Boer War .
He became the second most important man at the Central Flying School in England and had several important jobs in the Royal Flying Corps during World War I. Trenchard was the man in charge of the Royal Flying Corps in France from 1915 to 1917 .
He has been called the Father of the Royal Air Force .
Winston Churchill put him back in charge of the Royal Air Force in 1919 .
In 1918 , he was the first man in charge of the Royal Air Force for a short time .

Massalia has an above-average density for S-type asteroids , similar to the density of silicate rocks .
20 Massalia is a big and fairly bright Main belt asteroid .
It orbits at very low inclination in the intermediate main belt , and is by far the biggest asteroid in the Massalia family .
The remaining family members are pieces blown off by a cratering event on Massalia .
Massalia is an S-type asteroid .
Massalia is the Greek name for Marseille , where Chacornac made his discovery -LRB- de Gasparis was observing from Naples -RRB- .
Apart from the few biggest bodies over 400 km in diameter , such as 1 Ceres and 4 Vesta , most asteroids appear to have been fractured a lot .
It was Chacornac 's discovery that was announced first .
Massalia was found by A. de Gasparis on September 19 , 1852 , and also found independently the next night by J. Chacornac .
It is also the biggest member of the Massalia family of asteroids .
As such , it appears to be a solid un-fractured body , which is rare among asteroids of its size .

Asbarez Newspaper began its publication in August 1908 in Fresno as a weekly .
Asbarez is the official publisher of the Armenian Revolutionary Federation Western United States Central Committee , and mainly serves the more than 500,000 strong Armenian-American community in the Western states .
On May 1 , 1970 when Asbarez began publishing its English section .
After several successful decades the offices and publishing headquarters moved to Los Angeles in the early 1970 's .
Today , that section , which became a daily publication in January 1993 , is the voice of the community and a source of information within the halls of Congress , in libraries around the country and newsrooms of major media outlets .

There is no surviving portrait of Hooke .
Hooke 's collaboration with Christopher Wren included St Paul 's Cathedral , whose dome uses a method of construction conceived by Hooke .
In the reconstruction after the Great Fire , Hooke proposed redesigning London 's streets on a grid pattern with wide boulevards and arteries , a pattern later used in the renovation of Paris , Liverpool , and many American cities .
Hooke achieved fame in his day as Surveyor to the City of London and chief assistant of Christopher Wren .
This was a position he held for over 40 years .
This proposal was thwarted by arguments over property rights , as property owners were surreptitiously shifting their boundaries .
On 8 July 1680 , Hooke observed the nodal patterns associated with the mode of vibration of glass plates .
In 1664 Hooke also was appointed Professor of Geometry at Gresham College in London and Cutlerian Lecturer in Mechanics .
Robert Hooke FRS -LRB- Isle of Wight , 18 July 1635 â `` London , 3 March 1703 -RRB- was an English naturalist , architect and polymath . Hooke played an important role in the birth of science in the 17th century with both experimental and theoretical work .
Hooke was appointed the Royal Society 's first Curator of Experiments in 1662 , and he rose to be Secretary of the Royal Society . He took responsibility for experiments performed at its weekly meetings .
Hooke helped Wren rebuild London after the Great Fire in 1666 .
Hooke was in demand to settle many of these disputes , due to his skill as a surveyor and his tact as an arbitrator .
He ran a bow along the edge of a glass plate covered with flour , and saw the nodal patterns emerge .
Hooke also participated in the design of the Pepys Library , which held the manuscripts of Samuel Pepys 's diaries , the most frequently cited eyewitness account of the Great Fire of London .

When people write a word that is a trademark or show a picture or symbol that is a trademark , they should say that it is a trademark .
When people write a word that is a trademark or show a picture or symbol that is a trademark , they should say that it is a trademark . If a trademark is not registered , they can write the word `` Trademark '' , use the abbreviation `` TM '' , or use the symbol â cents on their products .

Horse Hollow Wind Energy Center is a large wind farm with 735.5 megawatt -LRB- MW -RRB- capacity .
It consists of 291 GE 1.5 MW wind turbines and 130 Siemens 2.3 MW wind turbines spread over nearly 47,000 acres -LRB- 190 kmÂ -RRB- of land in Taylor and Nolan County , Texas .
The first phase of the Horse Hollow Wind Energy Center consisted of 213 MW and was completed in late 2005 ; phase two consisted of 223.5 MW and was completed in the second quarter of 2006 ; phase three which consisted of 299 MW , was completed by the end of 2006 .

Multicellular organisms are organisms with more than one cell .
Multicellular organisms , especially long-living animals , also face the challenge of cancer , which occurs when cells fail to regulate their growth within the normal program of development .
In order to reproduce , true multicellular organisms must solve the problem of regenerating a whole organism from germ cells -LRB- i.e. sperm and egg cells -RRB- , an issue that is studied in developmental biology .
Changes in tissue morphology can be observed during this process .

Only fermions -LRB- examples are protons , neutrons and electrons -RRB- are bound by the Pauli exclusion principle , while bosons -LRB- an example is a photon - light beam -RRB- are not . A more precise way to describe the Pauli exclusion principle is to say that two of the same kind of fermions can not have the same quantum numbers .
A more precise way to describe the Pauli exclusion principle is to say that two of the same kind of fermions can not have the same quantum numbers . This principle was discovered by physicist Wolfgang Pauli in 1925 .

The first DNA transposon used as a tool for genetic purposes , the Sleeping Beauty transposon system , was a transposon which was ressurected from a long evolutionary sleep .
Transposons are only one of several types of mobile genetic elements .
In vertebrate animal cells nearly all the 100,000 + DNA transposons in a genome code for inactive transposase polypeptides .
They may have arisen independently many times , or perhaps just once and then spread to other kingdoms by horizontal gene transfer .
They copy themselves in two stages , first from DNA to RNA by transcription , then from RNA back to DNA by reverse transcription .
Transposons themselves are of two types according to their mechanism , which can be either `` copy and paste '' -LRB- class I -RRB- or `` cut and paste '' -LRB- class II -RRB- .
In this way , they are similar to viruses .
Bacteria may use gene deletion to remove transposons and viruses from their genomes while eukaryotic organisms use RNA interference -LRB- RNAi -RRB- to inhibit transposon activity .
While some transposons may confer benefits on their hosts , most are regarded as selfish DNA parasites .
Various viruses and transposons also share features in their genome structures and biochemical abilities , leading to speculation that they share a common ancestor .
Transposons are found in many forms of life .
Excessive transposon activity can destroy a genome , which is lethal . Many organisms have developed mechanisms to inhibit them .
Transposons may have been co-opted by the vertebrate immune system as a means of producing antibody diversity : The V -LRB- D -RRB- J recombination system operates by a mechanism similar to that of transposons .
The DNA copy is then inserted into the genome in a new position .
Transposition can create significant mutations and alter the cell 's genome size .
Retrotransposons behave very similarly to retroviruses , such as HIV .
Transposons are mutagens .
They can damage the genome of their host cell in different ways :

The most basic form can still be seen in some gastropods and annelids . These eyes have a lens of one refractive index .
Ocelli -LRB- pit-type eyes of arthropods -RRB- blur the image across the whole retina . They are very good at responding to rapid changes in light intensity across the whole visual field â '' this fast response is accelerated even more by the large nerve bundles which rush the information to the brain .
It is possible to get a better image with materials that have a high refractive index which decreases towards the edges . This decreases the focal length and allows a sharp image to form on the retina .
In this zone the eyes are flattened and the facets are larger .
Focusing the image would also cause the sun 's image to be focused on a few receptors . These could possibly be damaged by the intense light ; shielding the receptors would block out some light and reduce their sensitivity .
For the eye of a cyclone , see eye -LRB- cyclone -RRB- .
The body of Ophiocoma wendtii , a type of brittle star , is covered with ommatidia , turning its whole skin into a compound eye .
Instead of using a lens it is also possible to have cells inside the eye that act like mirrors . The image can then be reflected to focus at a central point .
To minimize the effect of eye motion while the animal moves , most such eyes have stabilizing eye muscles .
They are made of up to about hundred cells , covering about 100 Â m .
The directionality can be improved by reducing the size of the opening , and by putting a reflective layer behind the receptor cells .
Some larger organisms , such as scallops , also use reflector eyes .
The resolution of pit eyes can be improved a lot by adding a material to make a lens . This will reduce the radius of the blurring , and increase the resolution that can be achieved .
The ocelli of insects have a simple lens , but their focal point always lies behind the retina . They can never form a sharp image .
Good fliers like flies or honey bees , or prey-catching insects like praying mantis or dragonflies , have specialized zones of ommatidia organized into a fovea area which gives sharp vision .
The same is true of many chitons .
It detects moving objects as they pass successive lenses .
The flattening allows more ommatidia to receive light from a spot . This gives a higher resolution .
Each such unit is called ommatidium , several are called ommatidia .
This fast response has led to suggestions that the ocelli of insects are used mainly in flight , because they can be used to detect sudden changes in which way is up -LRB- because light , especially UV light which is absorbed by vegetation , usually comes from above -RRB- .
The scallop Pecten has up to 100 millimeter-scale reflector eyes fringing the edge of its shell .
This eye creates an image that is sharp enough that motion of the eye can cause significant blurring .
Such eyes can be found in about 85 % of phyla .
Unlike simple eyes , compound eyes have a very large angle of view . They can detect fast movement , and sometimes the polarization of light .
Many small organisms such as rotifers , copeopods and platyhelminthes use such this design , but their eyes are too small to produce usable images .

Consider two particles , indicated by subscripts 1 and 2 .
In a perfectly elastic collision -LRB- the simplest case -RRB- , no kinetic energy is lost , and so the kinetic energy of the two objects after the collision is equal to their total kinetic energy before the collision .
In a perfectly elastic collision -LRB- the simplest case -RRB- , no kinetic energy is lost , and so the kinetic energy of the two objects after the collision is equal to their total kinetic energy before the collision . Elastic collisions occur only if there is no net conversion of kinetic energy into other forms -LRB- heat , sound -RRB- .
The second rule we use is that the total kinetic energy remains the same , meaning that the initial kinetic energy is equal to the final kinetic energy .
Elastic collisions occur only if there is no net conversion of kinetic energy into other forms -LRB- heat , sound -RRB- .
Let m1 and m2 be the masses , u1 and u2 be the velocities before the collision and v1 and v2 be the velocities after collision .

Ukiyo-e , `` pictures of the floating world '' , is a genre of Japanese paintings produced between the 17th and the 20th centuries , that showed landscapes , the theater and scenes of every day entertainment . They were made using woodblock prints .
The original subject of ukiyo-e was city life , in particular activities and scenes from the entertainment district .
Beautiful courtesans , big Sumo wrestlers and popular actors would be portrayed while doing interesting activities .
They were meant for mainly townsmen , who were generally not rich enough to pay an original painting .

The Doctrine of Implied repeal is an idea in English constitutional theory which states that an earlier law can not be used to amend or repeal a later law .
This doctrine is expressed in the Latin phrase `` leges posteriores priores contrarias abrogant '' - more recent law overwrites ealier law that says differently .

FourcÃ s is a commune in southwestern France . It is more precisely in Gascony , in the Gers department , in the region Midi-Pyr Ã nÃ es .
In the neighborhood are numerous old castles , little medieval walled villages , small cities built around castles and `` sacred '' places , because the Via Podiensis and the Way of St. James of Compostela are going through the MontrÃ al and left their traces .
FourcÃ s is a typical medieval bastide , a little village where the houses are built in a circle to allow a proper defense .
The summers are long and warm ; the winters are soft and short .
Because of its landscapes and its vineyards the Gers is now and then called by some the `` Tuscany of France '' .

Germaine Tailleferre -LRB- born Saint Maur Des FossÃ s , France , 19 April 1892 ; died Paris , 7 November 1983 -RRB- was a French composer . She was one of the members of the famous group Les Six .
Ravel encouraged her to enter the Prix de Rome Competition .
Tailleferre wrote many of her most important works during the 1920s , including her 1st Piano Concerto , The Harp Concertino , the Ballets `` Le Marchand d'Oiseaux '' -LRB- the most often performed ballet in the repertoire of the Ballets SuÃ doises during the 1920s -RRB- and `` La Nouvelle CythÃ re '' which Diaghilev had asked her to write for his ballet company .
She was called Marcelle Taillefesse when she was born . When she was grown up she changed her last name to `` Tailleferre '' just to annoy her father because he had refused to let her study music .
She studied piano with her mother at home , composing short works of her own and then began studying at the Paris Conservatoire . There she met Louis Durey , Francis Poulenc , Darius Milhaud , Georges Auric and Arthur Honegger .
Her work in film music included `` Le Petit Chose '' .
They divorced shortly afterwards .
She stayed in the United States until 1927 when she and her husband returned to France .
In 1925 , she married Ralph Barton , an American caricaturist , and moved to Manhattan , New York .
In 1923 Tailleferre began to spend a great deal of time with Maurice Ravel at his home in Monfort-L ` Amaury .

TAS was the first Star Trek series to win an Emmy Award .
The success of the original live action series and fan pressure for a Star Trek revival led to The Animated Series from 1973-1974 , as the source of new adventures of the Enterprise crew , the next being the live-action feature film 1979 's Star Trek : The Motion Picture .

In the 2000s , the role of gene duplication , the extent of adaptive molecular evolution versus neutral genetic drift , and the identification of molecular changes responsible for various human characteristics especially those pertaining to infection , disease , and cognition .
Molecular systematics has been made possible by techniques for sequence analysis . This gives the exact sequence of nucleotides or bases in either DNA or RNA .
Some of the key topics have been the evolution of enzyme function , the use of nucleic acid changes as a molecular clock to study species divergence , and the origin of non-functional or junk DNA .
Molecular evolution emerged as a scientific field in the 1960s as researchers from molecular biology , evolutionary biology and population genetics sought to understand the structure and function of nucleic acids and protein .
At present it is still expensive to sequence the entire genome of an organism , but it has been done for over 100 species .
Molecular evolution is the process of evolution in DNA , RNA , and proteins .
Molecular systematics is the process of using data on the DNA , RNA , or proteins to resolve questions in phylogeny and taxonomy .
Recent advances in genomics , including whole-genome sequencing , and bioinformatics have led to a dramatic increase in studies on the topic .
In pre-modern society , the ordeal typically was done together with the oath and witness accounts as the central means by which to reach a verdict .
Johannes Hartlieb in 1456 reports a popular superstition on how to identify a thief by an ordeal by ingestion practiced privately without judicial sanction .
Priestly cooperation in trials by fire and water was forbidden by Pope Innocent III at the Fourth Lateran Council of 1215 , and replaced by compurgation .
The practice has been shown to exist in polytheistic cultures as far back as the Code of Hammurabi and the Code of Ur-Nammu , and in animist tribal societies , such as the trial by ingestion of `` red water '' -LRB- calabar bean -RRB- in Sierra Leone . There the intended effect is magical rather than invocation of a deity 's justice .
Trials by ordeal became more rare over the Late Middle Ages , often replaced by confessions extracted under torture , but the practice was discontinued only in the 16th century .
Indeed , the term ordeal itself , Old English ordÇ # l , has the meaning of `` judgment , verdict '' -LRB- German Urteil , Dutch oordeel -RRB- , from Proto-Germanic \* uzdailjam `` that which is dealt out '' .
Sullivan is a city of Illinois in the United States .
These references to the gods include a character comparing a mortal woman to a god , or saying he would rather be loved by a woman than by the gods .
Whether to honor a character or to mock him , these references were demeaning to the gods .
It is not uncommon , either , for a character to scorn the gods . This can be seen in Poenulus and Rudens .
Plautus perhaps does this to further demoralize the characters .
Naeviusâ imprisonment and eventual exile is a case of state censorship . This fear of censorship may have influenced Plautusâ choice of what he wrote about and how he wrote about it .
The plays were first shown between c. 205 BC and 184 BC .
He called himself `` Macchius '' -LRB- a clownish character in popular farces -RRB- , and `` Plautus '' -LRB- a term meaning `` flat-footed '' -RRB- .
In this way , Plautus could greatly simplify complex characters and give the audience what it wanted . â The audience to whose tastes Plautus catered was not interested in the character play , â instead it wanted humor that was easy to understand by many people .
This might be when he started to love the theater .
His comedies are among the earliest works of Latin literature that has not been lost .
As Walter Juniper wrote , â Everything , including artistic characterization and consistency of characterization , were sacrificed to humor , and character portrayal remained only where it was necessary for the success of the plot and humor to have a persona who stayed in character , and where the persona by his portrayal contributed to humor .
For example , in Miles Gloriosus , the titular â braggart soldierâ Pyrgopolynices only shows his vain and immodest side in the first act , while the parasite Artotrogus exaggerates Pyrgopolynicesâ achievements . Artotrogus creates more and more ludicrous claims that Pyrgopolynices agrees to without question .
Any character in his plays could be compared to a god .
Plautus is sometimes accused of teaching the public indifference and mockery of the gods .
Young men , meant to represent the upper social class , often make fun of the gods in their remarks .
Pyrgopolynices from Miles Gloriosus -LRB- vs. 1265 -RRB- , in bragging about his long life , says he was born one day later than Jupiter .
Naevius is most famous for having been imprisoned by the Metelli and the Scipiones -- two powerful families of the late third century .
Tolliver argues that drama both reflects and foreshadows social change .
Usually the only characters that scorn a god are those of low standing , like a pimp .
In Pseudolus , Jupiter is compared to Ballio the pimp .
Little is known about Plautus ' early life .
These two are perfect examples of the stock characters of the pompous soldier and the desperate parasite that appeared in Plautine comedies .
The state controlled stage productions , and Plautusâ plays would have been banned , had they been too risky .
It is likely that there was already much skepticism about the gods in Plautusâ time .
He fought in the First Punic War and his birth , therefore , is placed around the year 280 B.C.E. His first tragedy took place in 235 B.C.E. Plautus would have been living at the exact time as Naevius , but began writing later .
Soldiers often bring ridicule among the gods .
Parasites , pimps , and courtesans often praise the gods with little ceremony .
Plautus did not make up or encourage irreverence to the gods , but used the ideas of his time .

Recipe for Hate is the seventh album by American punk rock band Bad Religion , released on the Californian independent record label Epitaph Records in 1993 .
The album got the band 's highest U.S. chart position to date , debuting at # 14 on Billboard 's Heatseekers chart , and scored the radio hits `` American Jesus '' and `` Struck a Nerve '' .
Despite being released on a major label , Recipe for Hate initially received mixed reviews from music critics , who generally found it to be less impressive than Bad Religion 's older albums , but it has gained a cult following in recent times .
It is found in the region Pays de la Loire in the Sarthe department in the west of France .
The academic and usually ethnographic study of folklore is sometimes called folkloristics .
Folklore is the body of expressive culture , including tales , music , dance , legends , oral history , proverbs , jokes , popular beliefs , customs , and more within a particular people . This also includes the oral traditions of that culture , subculture , or group .

Thrymr is about 5.6 kilometres in diameter , and orbits Saturn at an average distance of 20,810,000 km in 1120.809 days , at an inclination of 175 Â to the ecliptic -LRB- 151 Â to Saturn 's equator -RRB- , with an eccentricity of 0.453 .
However , the IAU Working Group on Planetary System Nomenclature later decided to add the nominative case ending - r to the root Thrym .
Its name comes from Norse mythology , where Thrymr is a Jotun or frost giant .

As surveying is related to mathematics , he later studied the geometrical importance of complex numbers .
Johan Herman Wessel , Wessel 's brother was a famous person in Danish-Norwegian books .
Wessel 's thoughts on addition was : `` Two straight lines are added if we unite them in such a way that the second line begins where the first one ends and then pass a straight line from the first to the last point of the united lines .
In 1763 , having completed secondary school , he went to Denmark for further studies -LRB- since Norway did n't have any university in 1763 -RRB- .
Since it was in Danish , it was not noticed by many people . Later , Jean-Robert Argand and Carl Friedrich Gauss 's paper showed the same results .
Wessel 's main thing he wanted to show in the paper was not this , but he felt that the concept of numbers , with length and direction would be needed .
His paper was printed in a French translation in 1899 . It was released in English in 1999 as `` On the analytic representation of direction '' -LRB- ed .
In 1778 he acquired got degree of candidatus juris .
In 1794 he was hired as a surveyor ; in 1798 , a Royal inspector of Surveying .
This line is the sum of the united lines '' .
Today , the same idea is used when adding vectors .
He was born in Jonsrud , Vestby , Akershus , Norway .
Caspar Wessel -LRB- June 8 , 1745 â `` March 25 , 1818 -RRB- was a Danish-Norwegian mathematician .

He knew that on the summer solstice at local noon at the city now called Aswan on the Tropic of Cancer , the sun would appear at the zenith , directly overhead .
He calculated the tilt of the earth 's axis -LRB- again with remarkable accuracy -RRB- ; he may also have accurately calculated the distance from the earth to the sun and invented the leap day .
Assuming that Alexandria was due north of Syene he concluded that the distance from Alexandria to Syene must be 1\/50 of the total circumference of the earth .
He rounded the result to a final value of 700 stadia per degree , which implies a circumference of 252,000 stadia .
He was the first person to calculate the circumference of the Earth -LRB- with remarkable accuracy -RRB- , and he invented a system of latitude and longitude .
He also knew , from measurement , that in Alexandria , the angle of elevation of the sun would be 1\/50 of a full circle -LRB- 7 Â 12 ' -RRB- south of the zenith at the same time .
The common Attic stadium was about 185 m , which would imply a circumference of 46,620 km , which is 16.3 % too large .
The exact size of the stadion he used is frequently argued .
Eratosthenes measured the circumference of the earth without leaving Egypt .
He created a map of the world based on the available geographical knowledge of the era .
His estimated distance between the cities was 5000 stadia -LRB- about 500 geographical miles or 800km -RRB- by estimating the time that he had taken to travel from Syene to Alexandria by camel .

Houghton House was built in 1621 by Mary , Countess of Pembroke and brother of the poet Sir Philip Sidney .
The castle was built in the 15th century by Sir John Cornwall , later Lord Fanhope . He used money he had made from ransoms after the Battle of Agincourt .
Houghton House passed to the Duke of Bedford in 1738 and became a ruin after the roof was taken off in 1794 .
In 1242 , King Henry III gave Ampthill the right to hold a market on Thursdays .
The name ` Ampthill ' comes from an Anglo-Saxon word , ` Aemethyll ' , which means either ` ant-heap ' or ` ant infested hill ' .
The castle is now gone but there are some interesting parts of castle life still in existence . This includes ponds , such as West Minster Pond , made to hold and grow fish for food for the castle .
Henry VIII was often visited Ampthill Castle . Katherine of Aragon lived at the castle from 1531 until she was divorced in 1533 , when she was moved to Kimbolton .
In the Domesday Book , Ampthill is called ` Ammetelle ' , with the landholder in 1086 being Nigel de la Vast .

Both practical and theoretical research continues with interest , and many national government and military funding agencies support quantum computing research to develop quantum computers for both civilian and national security purposes , such as cryptanalysis .
A theoretical model is the quantum Turing machine , also known as the universal quantum computer .
Experiments have been done . In these , a very small number of operations were done on qubits -LRB- quantum bit -RRB- .
The basic principle behind quantum computation is that quantum properties can be used to represent data and perform operations on it .
If large-scale quantum computers can be built , they will be able to solve some problems much faster than any computer that exists today -LRB- such as Shor 's algorithm -RRB- . Quantum computers are different from other computers such as DNA computers and traditional computers based on transistors .
The idea is that quantum computers can use certain phenomena from Quantum mechanics , such as superposition and entanglement , to perform operations on data .
The basic principle behind quantum computation is that quantum properties can be used to represent data and perform operations on it . A theoretical model is the quantum Turing machine , also known as the universal quantum computer .
The Borkum and Helgoland camps were `` volunteer '' -LRB- Hilfswillige -RRB- labor camps and the labourers in those camps were treated harshly but marginally better than the inmates at the Sylt and Norderney camps .
In 1942 , Lager Norderney , containing Russian and Polish POWs , and Lager Sylt , holding Jews , were placed under the control of the SS HauptsturmfÃ 1\/4 hrer Max List .
-LRB- For further information on Alderney concentration camps , see Appendix F : Concentration Camps : EndlÃ sung â `` The Final Solution ; Alderney , a Nazi concentration camp on an island Anglo-Norman ; for further information on Nazi treatment of Jews and other people , see -RRB- .
Lager Helgoland was filled with Russian Organisation Todt workers .
Sylt camp held Jewish enforced labourers and was a death camp .
It was organised by the Schutzstaffel - SS-Baubrigade I -- which was first under supervision of the Sachsenhausen concentration camp ; and since mid-February 1943 ran under the Neuengamme camp in northern Germany .
The Germans built four concentration camps on the island , subcamps of the Neuengamme concentration camp -LRB- located in Hamburg , Germany -RRB- .
Lager Norderney was a Nazi concentration camp on Alderney , in the Channel Islands , named after the East Frisian island of Norderney .
700 people died in the Alderney concentration camps -LRB- out of a total inmate population of about 6,000 -RRB- .
Each subcamp was named after one of the Frisian Islands : Lager Norderney located at Saye , Lager Borkum at Platte Saline , Lager Sylt near the old telegraph tower at La FoulÃ re and Lager Helgoland , situated in the northwest corner of the island .
It was used by the Nazi Organisation Todt , a forced labor program , to build bunkers , gun emplacements , air-raid shelters , and concrete fortifications .
Norderney camp housed European -LRB- usually Eastern but including Spaniard -RRB- and Russian enforced labourers .
Over 700 of the inmates lost their lives before the camps were closed and the remaining inmates transferred to Germany in 1944 .
Lager Borkum was used for German technicians and volunteers from different countries of Europe .
The prisoners in Lager Norderney and Lager Sylt were slave labourers forced to build the many military fortifications and installations throughout Alderney .
These were the only Nazi concentration camps on British soil .

Aegyptosaurus was discovered and named by a German paleontologist named Ernst Stromer in 1932 .
Aegyptosaurus was a close relative of Argentinosaurus , a much larger dinosaur that lived in South America at about the same time .
Aegyptosaurus , meaning `` Egypt 's Lizard '' after the country where it was discovered -LRB- comes from the Greek word sauros , which means ` lizard ' -RRB- , is a genus of sauropod dinosaur that lived in Africa around 95 million years ago , during the Late Cretaceous period .
All known specimens were discovered before 1939 .
The animal 's long tail probably acted as a counterweight to its body mass. .
The fossils were stored together in Munich , but were obliterated when an Allied bombing raid destroyed the museum where they were kept in 1944 , during World War II .

The document affirms Russia 's stand on Taiwan as `` an inalienable part of China '' -LRB- A5 -RRB- , and highlights the commitment to ensure the `` national unity and territorial integrity '' in the two countries -LRB- A4 -RRB- .
Article 9 of the treaty has started controversy because it may be viewed as a defense pact , meaning if one of the two countries becomes involved in a war , the other country must help them . Additionally , articles A7 and A16 point at increasing military cooperation , including the sharing of `` military know-how '' -LRB- A16 -RRB- , namely , Chinese access to Russian military technology .
Both China and Russia fear the United States -LRB- especially following its strengthened geopolitical position following the September 11 , 2001 attacks -RRB- becoming involved in areas which they believe should only be affected by their respective spheres of national influences and interests : for China , this largely involves Taiwan serving as a US client state , while for Russia it involves having various former Soviet Republics as US client states .
The Treaty of Good-Neighborliness and Friendly Cooperation Between the People 's Republic of China and the Russian Federation -LRB- FCT -RRB- is a treaty outlining a twenty-year cooperation between China and Russia . It was signed by the leaders of the two world powers , Jiang Zemin and Vladimir Putin , on July 16 , 2001 .
Trees grow shorter until they simply stop growing .
Like the alpine tree-lines shown above , polar tree-lines are heavily influenced by local variables such as aspect of slope and degree of shelter ; trees can often grow in river valleys at latitudes where they could not grow on a more exposed site .
Here are some typical polar treelines :
Maritime influences such as ocean currents also play a major role in determining how far from the equator trees can grow .
At the tree-line , tree growth is often not clear with the last trees forming low bushes .
The tree line , like many other natural lines -LRB- lake boundaries , for example -RRB- , appears well-defined from a distance , but upon close inspection , it is not that clear .

Meat , fish , vegetables , fruit , roots , and nuts make up most of the modern Paleolithic diet . It does not include grains , legumes , dairy products , salt , refined sugar , and processed oils .
and that two studies of the Paleolithic diet in humans have shown good things for people 's health .
A doctor , Walter L. Voegtlin , was one of the first people to say that following a diet similar to that of the Paleolithic era might make a person 's health better .
This includes grains , legumes -LRB- e.g. beans and peanuts -RRB- , dairy products , salt , refined sugar and processed oils .
However , there are also raw , paleolithic dieters who believe that humans have not changed to be able to handle cooked foods , and so they eat only foods which are both raw and paleolithic .
In 2010 , this book was changed , updated , and published for the first time in English .
In 1975 , he published a book in which he argued that humans are carnivorous animals and that the ancestral Paleolithic diet was that of a carnivoreâ '' chiefly fats and protein , with only small amounts of carbohydrates .
The book did not say that people should not eat foods that were not available before people started farming , such as skimmed milk , whole-grain bread , brown rice , and potatoes prepared without fat .
Ideas about paleolithic nutrition come from evolutionary biology .
In 2003 , Lindeberg wrote a Swedish language medical textbook on the subject .
However , Loren Cordain has said that the new evidence shows that grains were not eaten much back then , and he has also said that eating of wild grass seeds of any kind needs technology and processing to make the food possible to eat , and that this technology was probably not around 105,000 + years ago .
more than 100,000 years ago , and perhaps as early as 200,000 years ago .
Starting with the first publication in 1993 , the Kitava Study has led to science writings on whether diseases in Western countries are caused by what people eat .
According to S. Boyd Eaton , `` we are the heirs of inherited characteristics accrued over millions of years ; the vast majority of our biochemistry and physiology are tuned to life conditions that existed before the advent of agriculture some 10,000 years ago .
The modern diet known as the Paleolithic diet -LRB- abbreviated paleo diet or paleodiet -RRB- , also called the caveman diet , Stone Age diet and hunter-gatherer diet , is a way of eating . It is based on the wild plants and animals that it thought that human species ate during the Paleolithic era .
The term `` Paleolithic diet '' can also refer to what people actually ate back then instead of the diet today .
In 1985 , S. Boyd Eaton and Melvin Konner , both from Emory University , published an important paper on Paleolithic nutrition in the New England Journal of Medicine , which made more people know about the idea .
Three years later , S. Boyd Eaton , Marjorie Shostak and Melvin Konner published a book about this way of eating . The book was about having the same proportions fat , protein , and carbohydrates , vitamins and minerals -RRB- as people near the end of the Paleolithic era ate .
In 1989 , these authors published a second book on Paleolithic nutrition .
These studies , called the Kitava Study , found that these people apparently did not suffer from stroke , ischemic heart disease , diabetes , obesity or hypertension .
Genetically our bodies are virtually the same as they were at the end of the Paleolithic era some 20,000 years ago . ''
Walter L. Voegtlin first made the modern Paleolithic diet popular in the 1970s . Authors and researchers recommended and changed the diet in several books and academic journals .
But in the 10,000 years since people started farming , natural selection has not had enough time for people 's genetics to change to get used to the new diet .
Foods that can be hunted and fished , such as meat , offal and seafood , and that can be gathered , such as eggs , insects , fruit , nuts , seeds , vegetables , mushrooms , herbs and spices make up the Paleolithic diet .
According to some supporters of the Paleolithic diet , people following the diet should get about 56 â `` 65 % of their food energy from animal foods , and 36 â `` 45 % from plant foods .
Starting in 1989 , Swedish medical doctor and scientist Staffan Lindeberg did scientific studies of people living on Kitava , one of the Trobriand Islands of Papua New Guinea .

The Order of St. John today forms part of the Canadian national honors system , and the Priory , established in 1946 out of the Commandery of Canada , is the largest outside of the United Kingdom , with some 6,000 members .

Membership in the order is by invitation only , except via appointment to certain government or ecclesiastical offices in some realms . People may not petition for admission .

Unlike with other multi-level orders , all the Order of St. John 's grades rank between the society 's predecessor and successor ; some examples follow :
Post-nominal letters of the order are not used outside the organization itself , and a Knight and Dame may not use the prefix sir or dame , though they may request from their local heraldic authority a personal coats of arms , should they not already possess any , and have it adorned with emblems of the Order of St. John .
Common for all members except Esquires is the badge , consisting of an eight-pointed Maltese cross embellished in the four principal angles alternately with two lions passant guardant and two unicorns passant .

The sopra -LRB- or supra -RRB- vest is a long drape of thin , black cloth that buttons close down the neck and to one side , falling to the ankles and cut so as to entirely cover the body .

On recommendation of that body , the Grand Prior appoints all the Grand Officers , besides himself , and may also appoint members of either Grade I or Grade II as other officers , known as the Principal Officers , such as the Secretary-General , and honorary officers , such as the Genealogist , who all hold office for a period not exceeding three years .
In 1877 , the order established at large railway centres and mining districts various St. John Ambulance associations , so that railway men and colliers could learn how to treat victims of accidents ; in 1882 , the Grand Priory founded a hospice and ophthalmic dispensary in Jerusalem -LRB- Known today as the St. John of Jerusalem Eye Hospital Group -RRB- ; and by 1887 , had created the St. John Ambulance Brigade , which undertook practical and life-saving work .

''

The Most Venerable Order of the Hospital of Saint John of Jerusalem , is a royal order of chivalry established in 1831 and found today throughout the Commonwealth of Nations , Hong Kong , Ireland and the United States of America , . Its world-wide mission is `` to prevent and relieve sickness and injury , and to act to enhance the health and well-being of people anywhere in the world . ''
Upon admission into the Order of St. John , confrÃ res are gifted various insignia of the organization , each level and office being represented by different emblems and robes for wear at important occasions for the order .
As citizens of a country that did not have the sovereignty of the Order of St. John vested in its head of state , American inductees who first joined the new Priory were specifically asked to only `` pay due obedience '' to the governing authorities of the order `` in all things consistent with your duty to your own country , '' thus eliminating any question of loyalty to a foreign head of state superseding American postulants ' duties as US citizens .
Male Knights Justice or Grace must carry their badges on a 16.5 mm wide ribbon at the neck , and Commanders , Officers , and Members have theirs on a 38 m straight ribbon suspended from a medal bar on the left breast , while females in all grades may wear their insignia either on a ribbon bow pinned at the left shoulder or hung from a medal bar in the men 's fashion , depending on the circumstance and clothing worn .

The Order of St. John is said to have arrived in Canada in 1648 , as the second Governor of New France , Charles de Montmagny , was a member of the original order , but it was not until 1883 that the first branch of the modern organization was established in the country , at Quebec City , growing to 12 branches by 1892 .

Any country without a Priory or Commandery of its own is assumed into the `` home priory '' of England and The Islands , many of these being smaller Commonwealth of Nations states in which the order has only a minor presence .

The Order of St. John 's biggest leap forward came in 1888 , when Queen Victoria granted the society a royal charter , yet again renaming the order , this time as the Grand Priory of the Order of the Hospital of Saint John of Jerusalem in England .
In 1871 , a new constitution brought about further changes to the group 's name , offering the more modest Order of Saint John of Jerusalem in England , and , five years later , Princess Alexandra , Princess of Wales , was recruited into its membership , followed by her husband , Prince Edward , Prince of Wales .
A subset of the Grand Council is the Honours and Awards Committee , which considers all recommendations for appointment or promotion into the grade of Bailiff or Dame Grand Cross , appointment or promotion into any grade of a person not resident within any priory 's territory , and advises the Grand Council in respect of the award of the Life-Saving Medal and Service Medal .
Recommendations are made by the Grand Council , and those selected have generally acted in such a manner as to strengthen the spirit of mankind as reflected in the order 's first motto , PRO FIDE and to encourage and promote humanitarian and charitable work aiding those in sickness , suffering , and\/or danger as reflected in the order 's other motto , PRO UTILITATE HOMINUM .
Each cloak also bears on its left side a rendition of the order 's star in white silk : the Sovereign Head , Grand Prior , and those in the first two grades of the order all have a 300 m diameter emblem ; the Sovereign 's and Grand Prior 's are of white silk with gold adornments , the former 's also surmounted by a St. Edward 's Crown , while those for Bailiffs and Dames Grand Cross , Knights and Dames of Justice , and Knights and Dames of Grace are rendered in white linen , the first two groups having embellishments in gold silk , the latter in white silk .
Grade I is limited to only the members of the Grand Council plus no more than 21 others , though any heads of state and members of the royal family of a Commonwealth realm , other Commonwealth of Nations member-state , or foreign country , may be appointed as a Bailiff or Dame Grand Cross without counting towards the total population ; All Priors , should they not already be in the grade or higher , are made a Knight or Dame of Justice upon their assignment ; this formerly enabled them , along with all Bailiffs and Dames Grand Cross , to nominate two personal Esquires , just as each Knight or Dame of Grace could nominate one personal Esquire , subject to the Grand Council 's scrutiny .

Thymol , an antiseptic , is the main active ingredient in Listerine mouthwash .
A tea made by infusing the herb in water can be used for cough and bronchitis .
In traditional Jamaican childbirth practice , thyme tea is given to the mother after delivery of the baby .
The ancient Greeks used it in their baths and burnt it as incense in their temples . They believed that thyme was a source of courage .
It is composed of a woody stem with paired leaf or flower clusters -LRB- `` leaves '' -RRB- spaced Â 1\/2 to 1 '' apart .
Thyme is often used to flavor meats , soups and stews .
Thyme is widely grown as a herb . Usually it is grown for its strong flavor , which is due to its content of thymol .
A sprig is a single stem snipped from the plant .
Its oxytocin-like effect causes uterine contractions and more rapid delivery of the placenta but this was said by Sheila Kitzinger to cause an increased prevalence of retained placenta .
It was thought that the spread of thyme throughout Europe was thanks to the Romans , as they used it to purify their rooms .
Thyme retains its flavor on drying better than many other herbs .
The dried equivalent is 1:3 , so substitute 1 teaspoon of dried or Â 3\/4 tsp of ground thyme for 6 small sprigs .
Fresh thyme is commonly sold in bunches of sprigs .
As with bay , thyme is slow to release its flavors so it is usually added early in the cooking process .
Dried , and especially powdered thyme occupies less space than fresh , so less of it is required when substituted in a recipe .
A recipe may measure thyme by the bunch -LRB- or fraction thereof -RRB- , or by the sprig , or by the tablespoon or teaspoon .
As a rule of thumb , use one third as much dried as fresh thyme - a little less if it is ground .
It can be propagated by seed , cuttings , or by dividing rooted sections of the plant .
Because it is antiseptic , thyme boiled in water and cooled is very effective against inflammation of the throat when gargled 3 times a day .
It tolerates drought well .
Thyme is sold both fresh and dried .
Thyme likes a hot sunny location with good-draining soil .
Depending on how it is used in a dish , the whole sprig may be used -LRB- e.g. in a bouquet garni -RRB- , or the leaves removed and the stems discarded .
In some Middle Eastern countries , the condiment za ` atar contains thyme as a vital ingredient .
Thymus vulgaris -LRB- Common Thyme or Garden Thyme -RRB- is a commonly used culinary herb . It also has medicinal uses .
If the recipe does not specify fresh or dried , assume that it means fresh .
It has a particular affinity to and is often used as a primary flavor with lamb , tomatoes and eggs .
In this period , women would also often give knights and warriors gifts that included thyme leaves . People believed it would bring courage to the bearer .
Usually when a recipe specifies ` bunch ' or ` sprig ' it means the whole form ; when it specifies spoons it means the leaves .
The fresh form is more flavourful but also less convenient ; storage life is rarely more than a week .
While summer-seasonal , fresh thyme is often available year-round .
The inflammation will normally disappear in 2 - 5 days .
Other infections and wounds can be dripped with thyme that has been boiled in water and cooled .

In French cuisine , along with bay and parsley it is a common component of the bouquet garni , and of herbes de Provence .
It has also been shown to be effective against the fungus that commonly infects toenails .
It is perfectly acceptable to substitute dried for whole thyme .

The Minor Term is the subject of the conclusion . Conversely , the predicate of the conclusion is the Major Term .
Aristotle studied different syllogisms and identified valid syllogisms as syllogisms with conclusion true if both premises are true .
The proposition that contains the Minor Term is referred to as the Minor Premise and the proposition that contains the Major Term is referred to as the Major Premise .
With hand-tuned timpani , there is no time to retune the timpani to A flat and E flat for the slow second movement in A flat .
This is a very peaceful key . It was used often by Franz Schubert .
Felix Mendelssohn and John Field each wrote one piano concerto in A-flat .
Twenty-four of FrÃ dÃ ric Chopin 's piano pieces are in A-flat major , more than any other key .
A-flat major is the major key with the most flats that Domenico Scarlatti used in his keyboard sonatas , though he used it only twice -- in K. 127 and K. 130 .
Charles-Marie Widor considered A-flat major to be the second best key for flute music .
Beethoven chose A-flat major as the key of the slow movement for most of his C minor works . This was also followed by AntonÃ n DvoÅ Ã k in his only C minor symphony and Anton Bruckner in his first two C minor symphonies .
Since A-flat major was not often chosen as the main key for orchestral music of the 18th century , passages or movements in the key often kept the timpani tuned the same way as they were in the movement before it .
In Bruckner 's Symphony No. 1 in C minor , however , the timpani are retuned between the first movement in C minor and the following in A-flat major .
Its relative minor is F minor and its parallel minor is A-flat minor .
Arnold Bax 's last symphony is also in the same key .
For example , Beethoven 's Symphony No. 5 in C minor has the timpani set to C and G for the first movement .
Edward Elgar 's Symphony No. 1 in A-flat major is probably the best-known symphony in that key .

Ultramega OK is the debut album by the American grunge band Soundgarden . It was released on October 31 , 1988 through SST Records .
The resulting album contained elements of psychedelic rock , classic rock , and hardcore punk .
Following the release of the EPs Screaming Life , released in 1987 , and Fopp , released in 1988 , for the Sub Pop record label , the band signed with the independent record label SST and went to work on its first full-length studio album .
In 1990 , the album earned a Grammy Award nomination for Best Metal Performance .

The fact that fossils were of soft-bodied forms , and the range of organisms new to science , led him to return to the quarry almost every year until 1924 .

It transports sperm cells from the pollen grain , from the stigma -LRB- in flowering plants or angiosperms -RRB- to the ovules at the base of the pistil . In some gymnosperms -LRB- conifers and gnetophytes -RRB- sperms move directly through ovule tissue .
In maize , this single cell can grow longer than 12 inches to traverse the length of the pistil .
One sperm unites with the egg cell to produce the embryo of a new plant , while a second sperm unites with the central cell -LRB- polar nuclei -RRB- to produce the endosperm of the seed .
In angiosperms the pollen tube germinates from the pollen grain and grows the entire length through the stigma , style , ovary and ovules to reach the eggs .
The sperm cells by themselves are not motile and are carried within the tube .
Like ferns , other basal land plants , and many algae , these gymnosperms have flagellate sperm , which swim through a watery fluid to fertilize the egg cells .
As the tip of the tube reaches an egg it bursts and releases two sperm cells leading to a double fertilization .
In other gymnosperms -LRB- Ginkgo and cycads -RRB- the pollen tube is involved only in nutrient uptake from ovule tissue by the pollen grain , and does not convey sperm cells to the egg .
The endosperm is rich in starch , proteins and oils and is a major source of human food -LRB- e.g. , wheat , barley , rye , oats , corn -RRB-

Newton metre is the unit of moment in the SI system .
It is a compound unit of torque corresponding to the torque from a force of one newton applied over a distance arm of one metre .
It is abbreviated N m or NÂ m , and sometimes written with hyphen newton-metre .

And to decrypt we subtract the same keystream numbers from the ciphertext to get the plaintext .
In cryptography , a keystream is a stream of random or pseudorandom characters that are combined with a plaintext message to produce an encrypted message -LRB- the ciphertext -RRB- .
Block ciphers can also be used to produce keystreams .
The `` characters '' in the keystream can be bits , bytes , numbers or actual characters like A-Z depending on the usage case .
For example , the CTR mode -LRB- also known as Integer Counter Mode -LRB- ICM -RRB- -RRB- is a block mode that makes a block cipher produce a keystream then turns the block cipher into a stream cipher .
Keystreams are used in the one-time pad cipher and in most stream ciphers .
-LRB- Such wrapping is called modular arithmetic . -RRB-
I.e. 26 becomes 0 and 27 becomes 1 and so on .
To encrypt we add the keystream numbers to the plaintext .
Usually each character in the keystream is either added , subtracted or XORed with a character in the plaintext to produce the ciphertext , using modular arithmetic .
As we have only 26 characters the random numbers in the keystream have to be at least between 0 and 25 .
In this simple example we will use only the English alphabet of 26 characters from a-z , therefore we will not encrypt numbers , commas , spaces and other symbols .
Here the plaintext message `` attack at dawn '' is combined by addition with the keystream `` kjcngmlhylyu '' and produces the ciphertext `` kcvniwlabluh '' .
If a ciphertext number becomes larger than 25 we wrap it to a value between 0-25 .

In many parts of their range they now feed on cattle , but avoid camels .
Oxpeckers feed exclusively on the backs of large mammals .
Oxpeckers also feed on the earwax and dandruffs of mammals , although less is known about the benefits of this to the mammal , it is suspected that this is also a parasitic behavior .
They feed on ectoparasites , particularly ticks , as well as insects infecting wounds and the flesh and blood of some wounds as well .
The smallest regularly used species is the Impala , probably because of the heavy tick load and social nature of that species .
Elephants and some antelope will actively dislodge the oxpeckers when they land .
Oxpecker\/mammal interactions are the subject of some debate and ongoing research .
Certain species seem preferred , whereas others , like the Lichtenstein 's hartebeest or Topi are generally avoided .
Their names come from their habit of perching on large mammals -LRB- both wild and domesticated -RRB- such as cattle or rhinoceroses , and eating ticks , botfly larvae , and other parasites .
Oxpeckers are endemic to the savanna of Sub-Saharan Africa .
Oxpeckers do eat ticks , but often the ticks that have already fed on the ungulate host and there has been no proven statistically significant link between oxpecker presence and reduced ectoparasite load .
According to the more recent studies of phylogeny , the oxpeckers are an ancient line related to the Mimidae -LRB- mockingbirds , thrashers & c. -RRB- and starlings , but not particularly close to either .
This would make the two species of Buphagus something like living fossils , and elegantly demonstrates that such remnants of past evolution can possess striking and unique adaptations .
However one study of impalas found that impalas which were used by oxpeckers spent less time grooming themselves suggesting a reduction in parasite load .
Oxpeckers have been observed to open new wounds and enhance existing ones in order to drink the blood of their perches .
Considering the known biogeography -LRB- distribution -RRB- of these groups , the most plausible explanation seems that the oxpecker lineage originated in Eastern or Southeastern Asia like the other two .
Some oxpecker hosts are intolerant of their presence .
They were originally thought to be an example of mutualism , but recent evidence suggests that oxpeckers may be parasites instead .
Other species tolerate oxpeckers while they search for ticks on the face , what one author described as `` appears ... to be an uncomfortable and invasive process .

A piÃ ata is a type of decoration with bright colors . It is made from either clay or cardboard and is covered with papier-m Ã cents chÃ .
Then , at the count of three , the children pull their strings all at the same time .
They are usually made of cardboard , colorfully decorated to match the birthday party theme and filled with candy , chocolates , small toys and confetti .
The piÃ ata is then hung somewhere where everyone can see , but the strings are kept out of the reach of children .
In Puerto Rico , Ecuador , Peru , Venezuela , Colombia and in some other Latin American countries , piÃ atas are traditionally used only at children 's birthday parties .
Toward the end of the party , usually after the cutting of the cake , an announcement is made that the piÃ ata will be ` broken ' and each child is given an empty party bag .
This opens the hidden trap-door -LRB- or ` breaks ' the piÃ ata -RRB- and the children receive a shower of candy and confetti while they rush to fill up their bags with the treats .
Colored strings -LRB- long enough to reach the ground -RRB- are attached to the bottom of the piÃ ata , where a trap-door is hidden under the decoration .
All the children get together directly underneath the piÃ ata and each child is given a string to hold .

In 1903 the Indian Army absorbed the three presidency armies -LRB- the Bengal Army , the Madras Army and the Bombay Army -RRB- .
Before that the Company had their own army units , paid for by their profits and these joined with British Army units .
The British Indian Army , officially called simply the Indian Army -LRB- IA -RRB- , was the army in British India during British rule -LRB- 1858 -- 1947 -RRB- .
The Indian Army was formed after the Indian Rebellion of 1857 when the government of Britain took over rule from the British East India Company .
The army of the British East India Company recruited mostly Muslims in the Bengal Presidency -LRB- which consisted of Bengal , Bihar and Uttar Pradesh -RRB- , and high caste Hindus mainly from the rural plains of Oudh .
After the rebellion , the British started recruiting what the British called the `` martial races , '' particularly Marathas , Rajputs , Sikhs , Gurkhas , Pashtuns , Garhwalis , Mohyals , and Dogras .
However , the first army officially called the `` Indian Army '' was raised by the government of India in 1895 .
The term `` Indian Army '' was used to describe the presidency armies , especially after the Indian Mutiny .
Between 1903 and 1947 the Army of India consisted of two separate parts : the Indian Army and the British Army in India . The first consisted of Indian Army regiments from India , while the second were British Army regiments from the United Kingdom which were sent to India .
After World War II , the British formations and units that had been part of the British Army of India were divided between India and Pakistan .

Because the grounds remain in the drink after brewing , French pressed coffee should be served quickly .
The French press has different names around the world .
Some versions are marketed to hikers and backpackers . These people often do not want to carry a heavy metal percolator or a filter using drip brew .
They are made of tough plastic instead of glass . They also have a sealed lid with a closable drinking hole .
The ground coffee should be more coarse than that used for a drip brew coffee filter , and far coarser than that used for espresso . Anything other than a coarse grind will go through the press filter and into the coffee .
Sometimes it is also called a melior -LRB- from an old brand of makers of coffee pots of this type -RRB- or a Bodum -LRB- another brand -RRB- .
In Australia , South Africa and Ireland it is known as a coffee plunger and coffee brewed in it is known as plunger coffee .
French pressed coffee is often stronger and thicker than drip-brewed one .
The French press is also more portable than other coffee makers .
Its French name is cafetiÃ re Ã piston .
A French press -LRB- also called press pot , coffee press , coffee plunger or cafetiÃ re -RRB- is a special machine used to make coffee .
In the UK the device is known as a cafetiÃ re -LRB- the French word for `` coffee pot '' -RRB- .
Because the coffee grounds are in direct contact with the brewing water , coffee brewed with the French press gets more of the coffee 's flavor and essential oils . These usually are trapped in a traditional drip brew machine 's paper filters .

The Summer of Love is the name for the summer of 1967 in the United States , especially in the Haight-Ashbury district of San Francisco , California .
