The North East MRT Line -LRB- NEL -RRB- was the third Mass Rapid Transit line in Singapore . It is the world 's second longest fully-underground , automated and driverless , rapid transit line after Singapore 's Circle MRT Line .
The line joins central Singapore to the north-eastern part of the island .
Transfer to the North South Line is done at Dhoby Ghaut station , East West Line at Outram Park station and Circle Line at Serangoon and Dhoby Ghaut stations .
The line is 20 km long with 16 stations and operated by SBS Transit .
The future Downtown Line will interchange with the North East Line at Chinatown and Little India stations .
This line is colored purple in the rail map .
This line is the first in Singapore to be totally underground .
Travelling from one end of this line to the other end takes about half an hour .
Calculations suggest that a typical Ophthalmosaurus could stay submerged for approximately 20 minutes or more .
The size of the eyes and the sclerotic rings suggests that Ophthalmosaurus hunted at a depth where there is not much light or that it may have hunted at night when a prey species was more active .
They were protected by bony plates -LRB- sclerotic rings -RRB- , which most likely assisted to maintain the shape of the eyeballs against water pressure at depth .
Ophthalmosaurus had the largest eyes of any vertebrate relative to its body size . Its eyes , 4 inches in diameter , occupied most of the space in the skull .
The swimming speed of Ophthalmosaurus has been estimated at 2.5 metres per second or greater . Even assuming a conservative speed of 1 m\/s , an Ophthalmosaurus would be able to dive to 600 meters and return to the surface within 20 minutes .

Solar box cookers can be made of materials or be manufactured in a factory for sale .
There are many kinds of solar box cookers , from small cardboard boxes , that can be used to cook a single meal , to wood and glass boxes built into the sunny side of a house .
They use no fuel and cost nothing to run . They also help slow deforestation and desertification .
Although the solar cooker was invented by Horace de Saussure , a Swiss naturalist , as early as 1767 , solar box cookers have only become popular since the 1970s .
A solar cooker is a device that uses sunlight for energy .

Common display resolutions for a portable projector include SVGA -LRB- 800 Ã -- 600 pixels -RRB- , XGA -LRB- 1024 Ã -- 768 pixels -RRB- , and 720p -LRB- 1280 Ã -- 720 pixels -RRB- .
All video projectors use a very bright light to project the image , and most modern ones can correct any curves , blurriness , and other inconsistencies through manual settings .

Ceratophyllum is a genus of flowering plants , commonly found in ponds , marshes , and quiet streams in tropical and in temperate regions .
Ceratophyllum grows completely submerged , usually , though not always , floating on the surface , and does not tolerate drought .
At intervals along nodes of the stem they produce rings of bright green leaves , which are narrow and often much-branched .

Rachel Carson was born on May 27 , 1907 on a small family farm near Springdale , Pennsylvania , just up the Allegheny River from Pittsburgh .
After false starts with pit vipers and squirrels , she completed a dissertation project on the embryonic development of the pronephros in fish .
The natural world , particularly the ocean , was the common thread of her favorite literature .
She originally studied English , but switched her major to biology in January 1928 , though she continued contributing to the school 's student newspaper and literary supplement .
In 1935 , her father died suddenly , leaving Carson to care for her aging mother and making the financial situation even more critical .
Silent Spring spurred a reversal in national pesticide policyâ '' leading to a nationwide ban on DDT and other pesticidesâ '' and the grassroots environmental movement the book inspired led to the creation of the Environmental Protection Agency .

Rachel Louise Carson -LRB- May 27 , 1907 â `` April 14 , 1964 -RRB- was an American marine biologist and nature writer whose writings are credited with advancing the global environmental movement .
Her next book , The Edge of the Sea , and the republished version of her first book , Under the Sea Wind , were also bestsellers .
At the urging of her undergraduate biology mentor Mary Scott Skinker , she settled for a temporary position with the U.S. Bureau of Fisheries writing radio copy for a series of weekly educational broadcasts entitled `` Romance Under the Waters '' .
She also spent a lot of time exploring around her 65 a farm .
Carson also began submitting articles on marine life in the Chesapeake Bay , based on her research for the series , to local newspapers and magazines .
Carson 's supervisor , pleased with the success of the radio series , asked her to write the introduction to a public brochure about the fisheries bureau ; he also worked to secure her the first full-time position that became available .
Her widely praised 1951 bestseller The Sea Around Us won her financial security and recognition as a gifted writer .
After her first year of graduate school , Carson became a part-time student , taking an assistantship in Raymond Pearl 's laboratory , where she worked with rats and Drosophila , to earn money for tuition .
Carson attended Springdale 's small school through tenth grade , then completed high school in nearby Parnassus , Pennsylvania , graduating in 1925 at the top of her class of forty-four students .
She especially enjoyed the St. Nicholas Magazine -LRB- which carried her first published stories -RRB- , the works of Beatrix Potter , and the novels of Gene Stratton Porter , and in her teen years , Herman Melville , Joseph Conrad and Robert Louis Stevenson .
Sitting for the civil service exam , she outscored all other applicants and in 1936 became only the second woman to be hired by the Bureau of Fisheries for a full-time , professional position , as a junior aquatic biologist .
In the late 1950s , Carson turned her attention to conservation and the environmental problems caused by synthetic pesticides .
Carson started her career as a biologist in the U.S. Bureau of Fisheries , and became a full-time nature writer in the 1950s .
A context switch can mean a register context switch , a task context switch , a thread context switch , or a process context switch .
A context switch is the computing process of saving and restoring the state -LRB- context -RRB- of a CPU such that multiple processes can share a single CPU resource .
A context switch can mean a register context switch , a task context switch , a thread context switch , or a process context switch . What will be switched is determined by the processor and the operating system .
What will be switched is determined by the processor and the operating system .
The context switch is an essential feature of a multitasking operating system .
Context switches are usually time consuming and much of the design of operating systems is to minimize the time of context switches .

The mean anomalies for the two points are calculated and their difference is found .
Unlike other measures of anomaly , the mean anomaly grows linearly with time . Because of the linear growth with time , the mean anomaly makes calculating the time of flight between two points on the orbit very easy .

The sickle-claws of the dromaeosaurid Deinonychus have a curvature of 160 degrees , well within the range of climbing animals .
Some , and probably all , dromaeosaurs were covered in feathers , including large , vaned , wing and tail feathers .
Ostrom compared Deinonychus to the ostrich and cassowary .
Like other theropods , dromaeosaurs were bipedal ; that is , they walked on their hind legs .
Dromaeosaurs were small to medium-sized dinosaurs , ranging from about 0.7 meters in length -LRB- 2.3 ft , in the case of Mahakala -RRB- to over 6m -LRB- 20 ft , in Utahraptor and Achillobator -RRB- .

The enlarged second toe bore an unusually large , curved sickle-shaped claw . It is thought to have been used in capturing prey and , in the smaller species , climbing trees .
He noted that the bird species can inflict serious injury with the large claw on the second toe .
Martin asserted for decades that birds were unrelated to maniraptorans , but in 2004 he changed his position , and now he agrees that the two are the closest of relatives .
The depiction of the dromaeosaur in the original Jurassic Park film , while accurate for its time , is now known to have been inaccurate in some respects , such as the lack of feathers .
However , the size of the Velociraptor in the film is much larger than the largest members of that genus .
In 2002 , Hwang and colleagues suggested that birds -LRB- avialans -RRB- were better thought of as cousins to the dromaeosaurids and troodontids .
The family Dromaeosauridae was named in 1922 , with only one new genus Dromaeosaurus .
Some were larger ; undescribed specimens of Utahraptor in BYU collections may have been up to 11 m long .
Xu and colleagues in 2003 cited the basal position of Microraptor , along with feather and wing features , as evidence that the ancestral dromaeosaur could glide .
Many other dromaeosaur fossils have been found with feathers covering their bodies , some with fully-developed feathered wings .
Another species of dromaeosaur , Microraptor gui , may have been capable of gliding using its well-developed wings on both the fore and hind limbs .
Most of the tail vertebrae bear bony , rod-like extensions , as well as bony tendons in some species .
In 2002 , Hwang et al . found that Microraptor was the most primitive dromaeosaur .
A consensus of paleontologists has concluded that there is not yet enough evidence to say whether any dromaeosaurs could fly or glide , or whether they evolved from ancestors that could .
The first , Rahonavis ostromi was originally classified as avian bird , but found to be a dromaeosaur in later studies . It may have been capable of powered flight .

The current consensus among paleontologists agrees with Hwang that dromaeosaurids are most closely related to the troodontids , and together with the troodontids form the clade Deinonychosauria .
Dromaeosauridae , along with Troodontidae , make up the infraorder Deinonychosauria .

A possible third lineage of giant dromaeosaurs is represented by isolated teeth found on the Isle of Wight , England .

This had been interpreted as evidence that these dromaeosaurs hunted in coordinated packs like some modern mammals .
Previous studies had shown that the amount of curvature in a claw corresponded to what lifestyle the animal has : animals with strongly curved claws of a certain shape tend to be climbers , while straighter claws indicate ground-dwelling lifestyles .
Other fossils , which do not preserve actual impressions of feathers , still preserve the associated bumps on the forearm bones where long wing feathers would have attached in life .
Deinonychus fossils have been uncovered in small groups near the remains of the herbivore Tenontosaurus , a larger ornithischian dinosaur .
The forelimbs of Rahonavis were more powerfully built than Archaeopteryx , and show evidence that they bore strong ligament attachments necessary for flapping flight .
Luis Chiappe concluded that , given these adaptations , Rahonavis could probably fly but would have been more clumsy in the air than modern birds .
However , not all paleontologists found the evidence conclusive , and a study in 2007 by Roach and Brinkman suggests that the Deinonychus may have actually displayed a disorganized mobbing behavior .

A challenge to all of these alternative scenarios came when Turner and colleagues in 2007 described a new dromaeosaur , Mahakala , which they found to be the most basal and most primitive member of the Dromaeosauridae , more primitive than Microraptor .
Mahakala is both the most primitive dromaeosaur ever described and the smallest .
Based on this cladistic analysis , Mahakala suggests that the ancestral condition for dromaeosaurids is non-flying .
Mahakala had short arms and no ability to glide .
In Manning 's interpretation , the second toe claw would be used as a climbing aid when subduing bigger prey and also as stabbing weapon .
Some fossils preserve long feathers on the hands and arms -LRB- remiges -RRB- and tail -LRB- rectrices -RRB- , as well as shorter , down-like feathers covering the body .
In his study of Deinonychus , Ostrom proposed that these features stiffened the tail so that it could only flex at the base , and the whole tail would then move as a single , rigid , lever .

Kitti 's Hog-nosed Bat roosts in the caves of limestone hills , far from the entrance .
The wings seem to be shaped for hovering flight , and the gut contents of specimens do include spiders and insects that are presumably gleaned off foliage .
During feeding periods , the young either stays in the roost or remains attached to the mother at one of her two vestigial pubic nipples .
There is a large web of skin between the hind legs -LRB- the uropatagium -RRB- which may assist in flying and catching insects , although there are no tail bones or calcars to help control it in flight .
Its common name refers to its discoverer , Thai zoologist Kitti Thonglongya .
In Thailand , Kitti 's Hog-nosed Bat is restricted to a small region of Kanchanaburi Province , within the drainage basin of the Khwae Noi River .
While many caves contain only 10 to 15 individuals , the average group size is 100 , with a maximum of about 500 .
Individuals roost high on walls or roof domes , far apart from each other .
Threats to the Burmese population are not well known .
Kitti 's Hog-nosed Bat -LRB- Craseonycteris thonglongyai -RRB- , also known as the bumblebee bat , is an endangered species of bat . It is the only member of the family Craseonycteridae .
Late in the dry season -LRB- around April -RRB- of each year , females give birth to a single offspring .
Soon after the bat 's discovery in the 1970s , some roosting sites became disturbed as a result of tourism , scientific collection , and even the collection and sale of individuals as souvenirs .
During this period , the bat forages within fields of cassava and kapok or around the tops of bamboo clumps and teak trees , within one kilometre of the roosting site .
Another potential risk is the activity of local monks , who have occupied roost caves during periods of meditation .
However , these pressures may not have had a significant effect on the species as a whole , since many small colonies exist in hard-to-access locations , and only a few major caves were disturbed .
In 2007 , Kitti 's Hog-nosed Bat was identified by the Evolutionarily Distinct and Globally Endangered -LRB- EDGE -RRB- project as one of its Top 10 `` focal species '' .
The bat 's upperparts are reddish-brown or gray , while the underside is generally paler .
While the Sai Yok National Park contains much of the bat 's range , some Thai populations occur outside the park and are therefore unprotected .
The dental formula is 1:1:1:3 in the upper jaw and 2:1:2:3 in the lower jaw , with large upper incisors .
Currently , the most significant and long-term threat to the Thai population could be the annual burning of forest areas , which is most prevalent during the bat 's breeding season .
The Thai and Burmese populations are morphologically identical , but their echolocation calls are distinct .
These short flights are easily interrupted by heavy rain or cold temperatures .
The bat feeds during short activity periods in the evening and dawn , foraging around nearby forest areas for insects .
Nevertheless , most prey is probably caught in flight .
Colonies range greatly in size , with an average of 100 individuals per cave .
Based on this determination , the bat 's closest relatives are members of the families Hipposideridae and Rhinopomatidae .
Despite having two caudal vertebrae , Kitti 's Hog-nosed Bat has no visible tail .
Bats also undertake seasonal migration between caves .
Main staples of the bat 's diet include small flies -LRB- Chloropidae , Agromyzidae , and Anthomyiidae -RRB- , hymenopterans , and psocopterans .
It is not known whether the two populations are reproductively isolated .
Kitti 's Hog-nosed Bat occupies the limestone caves along rivers , within dry evergreen or deciduous forests .
Its teeth are typical of an insectivorous bat .
The wings are relatively large and darker in color , with long tips that allow the bat to hover .
Since the 2001 discovery of a single individual in Burma , at least nine separate sites have been identified in the limestone outcrops outside the Thanlwin , Ataran , and Gyaing Rivers of Kayin and Mon States .
It has a reddish-brown or gray coat , with a distinctive pig-like snout .
In addition , the proposed construction of a pipeline from Burma to Thailand may have a negative impact .
The bat has a distinctive swollen , pig-like snout with thin , vertical nostrils .
Thonglongya worked with a British partner , John E. Hill , in classifying bats of Thailand ; after Thonglongya died suddenly in February 1974 , Hill formally described the species , giving it the binomial name Craseonycteris thonglongyai in honor of his colleague .
Kitti 's Hog-nosed Bat was unknown to the world at large prior to 1974 .
Kitti 's Hog-nosed Bat has a brief activity period , leaving its roost for only 30 minutes in the evening and 20 minutes at dawn .
Its ears are relatively large , while its eyes are small and mostly concealed by fur .
Kitti 's Hog-nosed Bat is the only extant species in the family Craseonycteridae , which is grouped in the superfamily Rhinolophoidea as a result of molecular testing .
It occurs in western Thailand and southeast Burma . It usually lives in where limestone caves along rivers .
Kitti 's Hog-nosed Bat is the smallest species of bat and one of the world 's smallest mammals .
As of the species ' most recent review in 1996 , Kitti 's Hog-nosed Bat is listed by the IUCN as endangered , with a downward population trend .

Janko Prunk , -LRB- born December 30 1942 -RRB- is a Slovenian historian of modern history .
He has also been actively involved in politics .
He obtained his PhD in 1976 with thesis on the relationship between the Slovenian Christian Socialist movement and the Communist Party of Slovenia within the Liberation Front of the Slovenian People , which at the time was a somehow problematic topic .
Prunk was born in the small village of Loka pri Zidanem Mostu near the town of Sevnica in central Slovenia , in what was then the German-occupied Lower Styria .
As an early admirer of JoÅ 3\/4 e PuÄ nik , he joined the Slovenian Social Democratic Union after the democratization of Slovenia .
Between 1992 and 1993 , he served as Minister for Slovenes outside Slovenia in the first coalition cabinet of Janez DrnovÅ ek .
Janko Prunk has written over 350 specialized articles and several books .
His book A brief history of Slovenia : Historical background of the Republic of Slovenia is one of the basic full works on modern Slovenian history .
He has also written on the history of political movements in Slovenia from the end of 19th century until World War II , especially with Slovene Christian socialism and the history of Slovenian national questions .
He is a member of Institute for European History in Mainz , a senior fellow of the Center for European Integration Studies in Bonn .
He has written on politology , modern history , modern political formations , and the history of social and political thought in Slovenia .
He was an active member of the Slovenian Democratic Party -LRB- known as Slovenian Social Democratic Party between 1989 and 2003 -RRB- .
He became very critial of the then prime minister Janez JanÅ a , whom he accused of being a `` liberal with an authoritative touch '' who aspires at becoming a `` Slovenian PiÅ sudski '' .
From 1966 to 1995 , he collaborated with the Institute for modern history in Ljubljana .
He graduated at the University of Ljubljana in 1966 and obtained his Master degree from the same institution in 1972 .
In 1984 and 1988 , he was awarded the scholarships by the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation , which enabled him to continue his studies in Cologne and Freiburg .
Between 2004 and 2008 , he served as chairman of the Party 's internal Committee for Education Policies ; he quit for disagreements over the Government policy favoring private universities .

A compact fluorescent lamp -LRB- CFL -RRB- , is a type of lamp -LRB- light bulb -RRB- designed to fit into the same space as an incandescent bulb , but with the advantages of a fluorescent lamp .
Many CFLs can directly replace an existing incandescent lamp .
A CFL can save over US$ 30 in electricity costs over the lampâ s lifetime compared to an incandescent lamp .
The purchase price of a CFL is often much higher than an incandescent lamp of the same output , and the light from CFLs looks different to light from incandescent lamps .
The purchase price of a CFL is often much higher than an incandescent lamp of the same output , and the light from CFLs looks different to light from incandescent lamps . But CFLs have a longer rated life and use less energy .

Due to their different approaches to a common subject , many misunderstandings have arisen between Newton 's mathematical understanding of optics , and Goethe 's experiential approach .
Confronting it is the darkness '' -LRB- Letter to Jacobi -RRB- .
`` The blue of the sky reveals to us the basic law of color .
With white above a dark boundary , we observe the light extending a blue-violet edge into the dark area ; whereas dark above a light boundary results in a red-yellow edge extending into the light area .
He observed that lights seen through a turbid medium would appear yellowish , and darkness seen through a turbid medium that had been lightened would appear blue .
Goethe 's concern was not so much with the analytic measurement of color phenomenon , as with the qualities of how phenomena are perceived . Science has come to understand the distinction between the optical spectrum , as observed by Newton , and the phenomenon of human color perception as presented by Goethe .
Search nothing beyond the phenomena , they themselves are the theory . ''
Science has come to understand the distinction between the optical spectrum , as observed by Newton , and the phenomenon of human color perception as presented by Goethe .
-LRB- Steiner , 1897 -RRB-
When viewed through a prism , the orientation of a light-dark boundary with respect to the prism is significant .
In his book , Goethe shows how color is perceived in a variety of circumstances , and considers Isaac Newton 's observations to be special cases .
Its influence extends primarily to the art world , especially among the Pre-Raphaelites .
J. M. W. Turner studied it comprehensively , and referenced it in the titles of several paintings -LRB- Bockemuhl , 1991 -RRB- .
At a certain distance , these edges overlap .
When these edges overlap in a light spectrum , green results ; when they overlap in a dark spectrum , magenta results .
Mitchell Feigenbaum had even convinced himself that ` Goethe had been right about color ! '
For Newton , all the colors already exist in white light , and the prism merely fans them out according to their refrangability .
For Goethe , light is `` the simplest most undivided most homogenous being that we know .
Based on his experiments with turbid media , Goethe characterized color as arising from the dynamic interplay of darkness and light .
With a dark spectrum -LRB- i.e. a shadow surrounded by light -RRB- , we find violet-blue along the top edge , and red-yellow along the bottom edge â `` where these edges overlap , we find magenta .
He saw only reddish-yellow edges and blue-cyan edges with white between them , and the spectrum arose only where these edges came close enough to overlap .
With a light spectrum , coming out of the prism , one sees a shaft of light surrounded by dark .
Goethe sought to show that , as a turbid medium , the prism was an integral factor in the arising of color .
We find yellow-red colors along the top edge , and blue-violet colors along the bottom edge .
Goethe 's concern was not so much with the analytic measurement of color phenomenon , as with the qualities of how phenomena are perceived .
Unlike his contemporaries , Goethe did not see darkness as an absence of light , but rather as polar to and interacting with light .
He felt that this arising of color at light-dark boundaries was fundamental to the creation of the spectrum -LRB- which he considered to be a compound phenomenon -RRB- .
-LRB- Ribe & Steinle , 2002 -RRB- .
Whereas Newton narrowed the beam of light in order to isolate the phenomenon , Goethe observed that with a wider aperture , there was no spectrum .
The spectrum with green in the middle arises only where the blue-violet edges overlap the yellow-red edges .
Although Goethe 's work was never well received by physicists , a number of philosophers and physicists have been known to have concerned themselves with it , including Arthur Schopenhauer , Kurt GÃ del , Werner Heisenberg , Ludwig Wittgenstein , and Hermann von Helmholtz .
`` Newton explains the fact that all the colors appear only when the prism is at a certain distance from the screen , whereas the middle otherwise is white ... -LRB- by saying -RRB- the more strongly diverted lights from the upper part of the image and the more weakly diverted ones from the lower part fall together in the middle and mix into white .
It contains some of the earliest and most accurate descriptions of phenomena such as colored shadows , refraction , and chromatic aberration .
In both cases , he found that the yellow and blue edges remain closest to the side which is light , and red and violet edges remain closest to the side which is dark .
The colors appear only at the edges because there none of the more strongly diverted parts of the light from above can fall into the most weakly diverted parts of the light , and none of the more weakly diverted ones from below can fall into the most strongly diverted ones . ''
For Goethe , `` the highest is to understand that all fact is really theory .
Starting from these observations , he began numerous experiments , observing the effects of darkening and lightening on the perception of color in many different circumstances .
For him , the spectrum could be explained by the simpler phenomena of color arising from the interaction of light and dark edges .
Theory of Colours -LRB- original German title , Zur Farbenlehre -RRB- is a book by Johann Wolfgang von Goethe published in 1810 .
Goethe 's studies of color began with subjective experiments which examined the effects of turbid media on the perception of light and dark .
Goethe recorded the sequence of colors projected at various distances from a prism for both cases -LRB- see Plate IV , Theory of Colours -RRB- .
Because Newton understands white light to be composed of individual colors , and Goethe sees color arising from the interaction of light and dark , they come to different conclusions on the question : is the optical spectrum a primary or a compound phenomenon ?
The editor of the Kurschner edition of Goethe 's works gives the following analogy :
Goethe was intrigued by this difference .
Wassily Kandinsky considered Goethe 's theory , `` one of the most important works . '' .
Since the color phenomenon relies on the adjacency of light and dark , there are two ways to produce a spectrum : with a light beam in a dark room , and with a dark beam -LRB- i.e. a shadow -RRB- in a light room .
Many users do n't understand how to watch the History listing to see if an article is quiet now , unchanged for weeks , and can be safely edited for hours with no one else making changes .
First , there is a heavy cost to the numerous revisions .
There might be no safe way to save revisions , or get talk-page consensus , under those circumstances .
Several simple steps could be taught :
Let the bots analyze small problems , or even count the occurrences of lowercase `` english '' and such , but those bots should wait to fix minor issues , limiting severe precision to a few times a year , and then fix all problems with one revision to each article , at that later time .
Not every group of other editors is cooperative ; sometimes , cliques of other users can act like inner-wiki -LRB- `` inner-city '' -RRB- gangs that live by their code , while outsiders receive pre-calculated treatment .
Some users do n't even realize how the extra revisions pile-up , expanding as a long list under the History tab of past edits .
Internally , the article history could record a hacking as a `` Try '' followed by an `` Erase '' so that the list of revisions would not show either transaction under the `` History '' tab when listing all the true revisions .
Either move on to other articles , or else , contact an admin or WikiProject that might help the balance of power .
It might help to explain to users that creating an offline version of an article can allow more time for completing broad revisions , but then simply merge , into that new text , any other user changes that have been made meanwhile .
Long lists of revisions showing hackings , each followed by instant-reverts , can cause the History listing of revisions to become much longer .
For example , a bot that capitalizes the word `` english '' to be `` English '' assumes that people never use the word in any other manner , such as `` putting english '' -LRB- a spin -RRB- on a billiard ball .
Users often just change a word & save , change a word & save , etc. .
Beyond just planning enhancements , it can be easier to create entire articles offline .
As of -- , the article count was articles , with total revisions , giving an average of ' revisions per article .
Such a re-created article could retain the major detailed differences , showing how the article evolved , but omit the thousands of minor interim revisions that clutter a step-by-step viewing of each next revision .
The goal of Wikipedia is to have a well-written encyclopedia .
Those recreated revisions should copy the edit-summary line from the actual old revisions , but also include text identifying each original user + date .
It is an utter myth that `` Every article gets vandalized '' -LRB- not true -RRB- : many articles go years without ever being hacked .
Seek to have a `` clean car '' , and focus on issues such as dents or tree branches falling on a automobile .
The database transaction log could handle the erase as a delete of that particular revision .
People are not discouraged from reading or editing Wikipedia for this reason .
Obviously , each transaction must be recorded , short-term , to allow backup\/recovery of the edited articles , in the event of storage failure mid-way before the erase took effect .
However , many low-traffic articles have gone years without being hacked .
Each of the above actions is elaborated below , to explain the particular ways of reducing revisions .
Sometimes , it is not easy or even possible to get the permanently planned revision made in a single edit .
I 've noticed several new users , while greatly expanding a low-traffic article , will keep saving every new phrase as though other users might pounce , at any minute , on the revised article before the next desperate SAVE is made .
Even if the minor revisions were actually left in storage , perhaps they could be bypassed when listing all other article revisions .
After 2007 , it became possible to restored a deleted article , so in the event of a major misunderstanding , any deleted article can be restored by an admin .
This can be the case when the edit contains a large amount of text , or when it is difficult to write all the text at once .
This can not be accomplished in one day , or in a single edit for each article .
Pruning , or erasing -LRB- deleting -RRB- small revisions might need changing of Wikipedia policies or adjusting the underlying MediaWiki software .
Some of the Wikipedia bots , which perform repeated robotic edits to many articles , are focused on really tiny updates to articles , with some even correcting the grammar in vandalism humor or within hacked text that will soon be removed .
When the text is copied as a new article , then all those user-space revisions could be deleted .
Many new users simply do not know they can combine their edits as one SAVE , using a longer edit-summary line .
The Wikimedia Foundation , which operates Wikipedia , is non-profit organization .
Some issues to consider :
An effective way to actually erase many old revisions is to rename an old article , by creating the new name as a new article , then copy -LRB- not move -RRB- the article to become a brand-new entry in article-space .
Perhaps the easiest way to actually erase old revisions is to create a new article within the user-space for a particular user , then copy -LRB- not move -RRB- the article to become a brand-new entry in article-space .
The quality of writing is also at stake .
That 's what this is for , and funds have been allocated for this purpose , provided they are used responsibly .
The tendency to rapidly revert vandalism , as though the whole world has stopped breathing , has made it difficult for other users to also enhance those articles while correcting hacked text .
Even though that re-creation , of major revisions , might seem extreme , many hundreds\/thousands of minor revisions would be omitted , representing years of edits with just a few dozen recreated , major -LRB- non-trivial -RRB- revisions .
Its continued operation relies solely on private donations .
Some issues to note :
Some issues to note :
Progress could be measured by comparing those averages against a future , anticipated reduction in average revisions per article .
Some kinds of vandalism go unnoticed for months , sometimes over 6 months , so there is no hurry to revert all hackings made in low-traffic articles .
Just forget about those bird droppings , rather than log each for eternity .
If hackings can not be erased , then perhaps they could be skipped in History listings .
However , long term , it might be more efficient if the hacking + erase really disappeared from the article storage at some point .
Also , an erase could complicate the wikiserver databases , unless an erase was treated as a `` delete '' transaction in the storage .
The best compromise would be to keep an old history list in the talk-page or as a subpage '' \/ old_history '' .
Without these donations , Wikipedia could not exist .
Plan some enhancements to articles by using offline files of either notes or potential new text .
Although techniques such as deleting user-space articles and copy-renaming old articles might seem extreme , the combined effect of thousands of users , each redoing articles in their specialty , could reduce portions of Wikipedia by 10x , 100x or 1000x times fewer revisions .
However , revisions could also be pruned in advance , by many actions each person could take to avoid long-term storing of more revisions .
Skipping over the hacked + reverted revisions would cut the History listing of many high-traffic articles by about 50 % or more .
The 3-revert rule is intended to limit edit-wars during a one-day period .
But there are some issues .
Of course , thousands of revisions could be generated by renaming `` metre '' to `` meter '' or some similar minor changes .
No , other users can simply revert all those revisions , reversing days\/weeks of edits .
A special type of revert could indicate that the prior revision was merely hacked text , with the result that both the hacked + reverted entries would be skipped under a History listing .
However , unrestricted use of erase could prolong edit-wars where revisions were removed without reverting .
There is a cost to each edit , each revision stored , and each time a page is viewed even without editing .
Again , some people treasure the old stuff , like keeping decades of old , worn-out shoes , so not all articles can be pruned so easily by simply copy-renaming them into a clean , fresh name .
After that point , users taught to combine numerous small edits -LRB- in the future -RRB- , and avoid panic saving , would reduce the subsequent revision lists and omit most of the small stuff that cluttered Wikipedia during 2006 â `` 2008 .
Note that offline storage does not have the Wikipedia backup protection , so be sure to make periodic copies , if needed , for backup .
An editor who makes multiple edits to an article in an attempt to achieve his\/her final plan could be viewing any edits before the final one as temporary revisions that will not remain very long .
It would be a lot easier to warn new users , early on , that just because they SAVE , after every change , as a new revision , those changes are not safer or , somehow , more permanent .
However , in a fight to retain the detailed differences , it might be necessary to recreate the major old revisions by a series of repeated edits , filling the wiki-edit buffer with each successive major revision , and then saving each to allow comparisons of texts .
You might wonder if it even matters that Wikipedia has such a high number of revisions .
The article revisions will not be removed from Wikipedia until the user-space article has been deleted .
Though the cost of each one is minute , with millions each day , these all add up .
Bots should be denied from making those minor changes .
For large updates , planning enhancements offline could reduce total revisions by a factor of 25 -LRB- or more -RRB- , due to the focus on broad wording , while avoiding hacks to half-finished text by the tinkering of other users .
It can be very tedious , when stepping through multiple revisions , to see `` Page blanked with '' and then `` Reverted '' to show the entire text of the article changed in both revisions .
However , actually erasing specific revisions from an article might require changing , or reconfiguring , the software behind Wikipedia , the MediaWiki system .
The only permanent change is bloating Wikipedia -LRB- `` forever '' -RRB- with numerous edits , all of which get reverted .
Perhaps 50 % of all revisions are hackings\/jokes + revert : it 's not just the hacking of articles that escalates the total revisions , but the instant reverting that doubles the total revisions to recover from hacking .
Beyond a survey of prankster edits , there 's not much use for the long-term logging of a hacking + revert .
When the text is copied as a new article , then all those old revisions -LRB- under the old name -RRB- could be later deleted .
It is highly debatable to allow bots to run rampant , and make opinionated conclusions about lowercase words -LRB- such as `` english '' -RRB- .
Those combined `` Try + Erase '' transactions could be removed from the system after some period of time .
Some issues to note :
It 's analogous to bird droppings : it might be beneficial to notice some short-term patterns , such as when automobiles parked under some trees get bombarded with bird droppings , but it is less useful to record all the millions of bird droppings , everywhere in the world , in a giant database of history listings .
The fixer-bots should be run on a rare basis , and perhaps even count how many corrections would be made to an article , then cleverly refuse to update an article just for a single minor word , unless the bot was running in a quarterly update-all-minor-issues mode .
Depending on notability or libel concerns , many hacked articles could wait -LRB- a long time -RRB- to be fixed while improving .
There are several issues to consider :
Many revisions of Wikipedia articles are very minor and could be `` pruned '' from the overall History of article revisions , to leave only the more major revisions .
But an edit history that is clogged with experimental or `` junk '' edits may become confusing , and versions that fail to meet encyclopedic standards may in the long run have a negative effect , particularly if they are not marked with tags to indicate their temporary status .
Although the Simple Wikipedia , today , has less than thousand articles -LRB- plus thousands of red-link articles -RRB- , the total revisions number nearly million .
The process of erasing a revision should require some special authority to avoid edit-wars that would use erase to negate other contributions .

Visiting in 1787 , the geologist James Hutton found his first example of an unconformity to the north of Newton Point near Lochranza , which provided evidence for his Plutonist theories of uniformitarianism , and about the age of the Earth .

Arran or the Isle of Arran is the largest island in the Firth of Clyde , Scotland .
After the last retreat of the ice at the close of the Pleistocene epoch sea levels were up to 70 m lower than at present and it is likely that circa 14,000 years ago the island was connected to mainland Scotland .
During the troubled Viking Age Arran became the property of the Norwegian crown before becoming formally absorbed by the kingdom of Scotland in the thirteenth century .
The island is sometimes referred to as `` Scotland in miniature '' , as it is divided into `` Highland '' and `` Lowland '' areas by the Highland Boundary Fault which runs northeast to southwest across Scotland .

His brother Rudolf was a physiologist and anatomist .
He was also a keen naturalist and collector , and it is for this work he is best known among biologists .
Wagner devoted three years -LRB- 1836 â `` 1839 -RRB- to the exploration of Algiers . It was there that he made an important discovery in natural history , which he later developed .
However , in 1942 it was reintroduced by Mayr , and the importance of geographic speciation became one of the core ideas of the evolutionary synthesis .
This was an early description of a process of geographical speciation .
The leading evolutionists -LRB- Darwin , Wallace , Weismann -RRB- attacked Wagner 's idea of geographic speciation , and it suffered a long decline .
Modern experts such as Ernst Mayr , Jerry Coyne & Allen Orr , agree that Wagner first identified geographical speciation .
Each genus is split into a number of species , each of which is confined to a stretch of the north coast between rivers which descend from the Atlas mountains to the Mediterranean .
From 1852 â `` 1855 , together with a companion , Wagner traveled through North and Central America and the Caribbean .
The zoological taxonomist Bernhard Rensch was also significant in keeping geographical speciation on the evolutionary menu .
In his old age he committed suicide in Munich , aged 73 .
As well as Darwin , the Reverend J.T. Gulick also found Wagner 's theories overstated . , but in a later paper Gulick says that `` Moritz Wagner , in his Law of the Migration of Organisms , was the first to insist on the importance of geographical isolation as a factor in evolution , but when he asserted that , without geographical isolation , natural selection could have no effect in producing new species , he went beyond what could be sustained by facts '' .
In May 1843 , Wagner toured the Lake Sevan region of Armenia .
Wagner argued in letters to Darwin that he had missed a vital geographic component in understanding the evolution of new species .
Another formulation of this idea came later : `` Organisms which never leave their ancient area of distribution will never change '' .
`` It took more than 60 years after 1859 until the leading specialists ... -LRB- agreed -RRB- that this geographical approach was the way to solve the problem of speciation ... a new species may evolve when a population acquires isolating mechanisms while isolated from its parent population . ''
Ernst Mayr 's formulation cleared up the issues which Wagner had left unresoved : `` A new species develops if a population which has become isolated from its parental species acquires during this period of isolation characters which promote or guarantee isolation when the external barriers break down '' .
During his three years in Algeria , Wagner studied -LRB- amongst other activities -RRB- the flightless beetles Pimelia and Melasoma .
Later , he found Wagner 's increasingly hysterical tone and one-sided argument upsetting , and wrote across his copy of Wagner 's 1875 paper `` most wretched rubbish , '' partly because Wagner ignored the importance of natural selection , and lifted parts of Darwin 's theory that he liked without attribution , all the while claiming that Darwin 's views were incorrect .
However , his `` migration theory '' was based on a rather simple , Lamarckian idea of evolution .
Darwin at first responded in a friendly way to these letters , and agreed that geographic isolation was important -LRB- although not the only mode of speciation -RRB- .
He identified geographical separation as the most frequent initial step towards kladogenesis -LRB- species splitting -RRB- .
'' ... an incipient species will only -LRB- arise -RRB- when a few individuals transgress the limiting borders of their range ... the formation of a new race will never succeed ... without a long continued separation of the colonists from the other members of their species . ''
Moritz Wagner -LRB- Bayreuth , 3 October 1813 â `` Munich , 31 May 1887 -RRB- was a German explorer , collector , geographer and naturalist .
Ernst Mayr , the evolutionist and historian of biology , has given an account of Wagner 's significance .
`` Unfortunately , Wagner combined -LRB- his idea -RRB- with some peculiar ideas on variation and selection '' -LRB- Mayr -RRB- .

The family Chinchillidae contains the chinchillas , viscachas , and their fossil relatives .
All species have thick , soft fur , which is considered valuable in some species .
They are restricted to southern and western South America . Often they can be found in the Andes .
There are three extant and three fossil genera currently recognized .
They are large rodents , weighing from 800 grams to 8 kilograms , with strong hind legs and large ears .

The Monte Roraima National Park is located around one of the highest mountains of Brazil , the 2727 m high Tepui Monte Roraima .
Roraima is both the northernmost and least populated state of Brazil .
The state has many mineral deposits - especially gold , diamonds , cassiterite , bauxite and copper .
The climate is tropical with an average temperature of 26 Â C. Most of the state is located in the Amazon rainforest . A small part of the state is a small strip of savanna to the east .

Electrical power transmission has replaced mechanical power transmission in all but the very shortest distances .
Power transmission is the movement of energy from its place of generation to a place where it can be used for work .
With widespread establishment of power grids , power transmission has came to be associated most often with electric power transmission .
Since the development of technology , Transmission and storage systems have been of immense interest to technologists and technology users .
Mechanical power may be transmitted directly using a solid structure such as a driveshaft ; transmission gears can adjust the amount of torque or force vs. speed in much the same way an electrical transformer adjusts voltage vs current .
From the start of the industrial revolution until the end of the 19th century mechanical power transmission was the norm .

Polish POWs in the Woldenberg -LRB- Dobiegniew -RRB- Oflag II-C POW camp were granted permission by their Nazi captors to have an unofficial POW Olympics in 1944 , showing that the Olympic spirit can survive even during war .
The anticipated 1944 Summer Olympics , which were to be officially known as the Games of the XIII Olympiad , were canceled because of World War II .
These events happened on 17 June to 19 June 1944 and were called `` The Jubilee Celebrations of IOC '' by Carl Diem , the man who began the modern tradition of the Olympic torch relay .
London hosted the next Olymic Games , the 1948 Summer Olympics , awarded without an election .
In spite of the war , the IOC had many events at its headquarters in Lausanne , Switzerland to celebrate its 50th anniversary .
They would have been held in London , England , which won the bid in the June 1939 International Olympic Committee election , over Rome , Detroit , Lausanne , Athens , Budapest , Helsinki and Montreal .
Delacroix 's use of expressive brushstrokes and his study of the optical effects of color profoundly shaped the work of the Impressionists , while his passion for the exotic inspired the artists of the Symbolist movement .
Friend and spiritual heir to ThÃ odore GÃ ricault , Delacroix was also inspired by Byron , with whom he shared a strong identification with the `` forces of the sublime '' , of nature in often violent action .
In the words of Baudelaire , `` Delacroix was passionately in love with passion , but coldly determined to express passion as clearly as possible . ''
However , Delacroix was given neither to sentimentality nor bombast , and his Romanticism was that of an individualist .
In contrast to the Neoclassical perfectionism of his chief rival Ingres , Delacroix took for his inspiration the art of Rubens and painters of the Venetian Renaissance , with an attendant emphasis on color and movement rather than clarity of outline and carefully modeled form .
A fine lithographer , Delacroix illustrated various works of William Shakespeare , the Scottish writer Sir Walter Scott , and the German writer Johann Wolfgang von Goethe .
Ferdinand Victor EugÃ ne Delacroix -LRB- 26 April 1798 â `` 13 August 1863 -RRB- was a French Romantic artist regarded from the outset of his career as the leader of the French Romantic school .
Dramatic and romantic content characterized the central themes of his maturity , and led him not to the classical models of Greek and Roman art , but to travel in North Africa , in search of the exotic .

Chants of the Office started in the early 4th century , when holy men in the deserts started the tradition of singing all 150 psalms every week .
In the past , people sang different songs in parts of Europe , but Gregorian chant replaced almost all of them . Although the Roman Catholic Church no longer requires people to sing Gregorian chants , it still says that Gregorian chant is the best music for prayer .
The sorts of songs , which Catholics later sang in the Roman Rite , started to appear in the 3rd century .
Gregorian chants are divided into three types based on the number of notes sung to each syllable . Syllabic chants mostly have one note per syllable .
People who study the history of music and religion no longer believe this , because most early Christian songs were not from the Psalms , and Jews did not sing Psalms for many centuries after their most important holy place , the Second Temple , was destroyed in the year 70 .
In Roman Catholic churches , prayers and songs follow an order called the `` Roman Rite . '' Gregorian chant is the music used in the Mass and the Office of the Roman Rite .
In neumatic chants there are mostly two or three notes per syllable , while melismatic chants have lots of notes for one syllable . .
The words `` amen '' and `` alleluia '' come from the Hebrew language of the Jews . The prayer `` santus , sanctus , sanctus , '' which means `` holy , holy , holy , '' comes from the Jewish prayer `` kadosh , kadosh , kadosh . ''
However , some parts of Jewish music and prayer ended up later in Gregorian chant . The organized order of prayers called `` canonical hours '' come from Jewish tradition .
It is bordered by the counties of Kent , Surrey and West Sussex , and to the south by the English Channel .
East Sussex is a county in South East England .

The William M. Jennings Trophy was created as a replacement and is given to the goaltender -LRB- s -RRB- playing for the team with the fewest goals scored against them .
Roy has won the trophy five times , the most of any goaltender .
The William M. Jennings Trophy is an award in the National Hockey League -LRB- NHL -RRB- given each year to `` to the goalkeeper -LRB- s -RRB- having played a minimum of 25 games for the team with the fewest goals scored against it .
Since it began in 1982 , it has been awarded at the end of 25 seasons to 27 different players .
It has been won most often by the Montreal Canadiens , on 5 occasions .
It is named for the late William M. Jennings , who was a governor and president of the New York Rangers and who helped build ice hockey in the United States .
The Jennings Trophy was donated by the NHL 's board of governors and first handed out at the end of the 1981 â `` 82 season .
Until the 1980 â `` 81 season , the Vezina Trophy was awarded to the goaltender -LRB- s -RRB- of the team allowing the fewest number of goals during the regular season .
The most recent winner is Martin Brodeur of the New Jersey Devils , who allowed a league-low 191 team goals against in 2010 .
The New Jersey Devils have won four times , and Buffalo Sabres and Chicago Blackhawks have three wins each .
Up until 1981 , the Vezina Trophy had been awarded under that definition , but it was later changed and replaced by the Jennings Trophy .
Winners are selected based on regular-season play . ''
However , it was discovered that this often meant the trophy went to the goaltender of the better team rather than the individual , so they changed it to offer the Vezina to the most outstanding goaltender , as voted by the NHL General Managers .
Normally the lowest number of games a goaltender must play to be eligible for the trophy is 25 , but for the lockout shortened 1994 â `` 95 season , the lowest was fourteen games .
Belfour and Brodeur are tied for second , having each won the trophy four times .

The MIPS architecture has instructions which are 32 bits long .
The fields used in these types are :
A program normally relies on such factors . For this reason , different systems will typically not run the same machine code .
They specify the basic instruction type . Other fields may give the type of the operands , the addressing mode , and so on .
Machine code is sometimes called native code .
Machine code or machine language is the name for commands . They can directly be executed by a processor .
The general type of instruction is in the op -LRB- operation -RRB- field . It is the highest 6 bits .
R-type -LRB- register -RRB- instructions include the field funct . It determines the exact operation of the code .
Every processor or processor family has its own machine code instruction set .
An instruction set is specific to a processor or a family of processors that have a similar set up .
Instructions are patterns of bits . They correspond to the different commands that can be given .
J-type -LRB- jump -RRB- and I-type -LRB- immediate -RRB- instructions are fully given by op .
rs , rt , and rd indicate register operands . shamt gives a shift amount .

Each of these employ a different form of martial arts in their fighting choreography : Ba Gua for Airbending , Hung Gar for Earthbending , Northern Shaolin for Firebending , and Tai Chi for Waterbending .

In particular , Mell enjoyed the development of Katara and Zuko throughout the first season , but thought that Zuko 's relationship with his uncle was not `` very organic . ''
In the show , some characters have the ability to manipulate one of the four classic elements of ancient philosophy : Water , Earth , Fire and Air , although the Avatar has the ability to control all four .
DVDVerdict felt that some minor characters , especially Mai and Ty Lee , were `` love em ' or hate em ' '' characters .
Toph , despite being blind , is extremely perceptive of the world around her due to her connection to the Earth .
Studios such as Studio 4 Â C , Production I. G , and Studio Ghibli , which produced anime-styled cartoons , were also sources of inspiration .
The greatest influences on the series were Asian art and history ; the characters ' various personalities and traits are based on philosophical teachings such as Taoism and Buddhism .
Jamie S. Rich of DVD Talk generally agreed with Mell 's assessment of the characters .
This makes the cartoon one of few animations to win the award and the only one to be cited for its character development .
Fitz at Lair of the Green Knight lauded the decision to not stereotypically fashion the woman into the `` usual weak female characters '' but to instead give them `` strong opinions and strength '' .
The anime-styled character art based on Shinichiro Watanabe 's Cowboy Bebop , Samurai Champloo , and FLCL -LRB- Fooly Cooly -RRB- of Gainax .
The original character conception was derived from a sketch by Bryan Konietzko that depicted a middle-aged balding man with an arrow on his head .
These starkly individual tendencies are explained in eighty-five distinct types of `` Jings '' , or internal energy .
The characters of Avatar : The Last Airbender were designed by Michael Dante DiMartino and Bryan Konietzko , the co-creators of the series .
Lair of the Green Knight and DVD Verdict also enjoyed the romantic tension , focusing mainly on the female cast : Katara , Toph , and Azula , as well as the two minor characters , Mai and Ty Lee .
Aang , a pacifist monk , is also very carefree and child-like , which is commonly attributed to the `` freedom '' of the wind and the air .
Rich also praised the fact that , unlike many cartoon television series , Avatar introduces antagonists that have a deep backstory and `` are -LRB- not -RRB- just evil for the sake of it '' .
Many of the recurring characters of the series have received more depth in their personalities , which are usually based on their respective element .
Gabriel Powers of DVDActive thought that while the characters fit into neat `` archetypes '' , it was not a bad thing and fit well with the series .
Unlike Aang , she is extremely brusque when criticizing others , which is attributed to Earth 's tough and unbreakable nature .
For example , Ba Gua employs the `` negative jing '' to create erratic circular movements and capitalizes on centripetal force and defensive positions while Northern Shaolin follows the `` positive jing '' and emphasizes brute strength and aggression to generate power .
The characters of Avatar : The Last Airbender received both praise and criticism from reviewers .
Iroh -LRB- Mako in season one and two .
In 2008 , Avatar was awarded a Peabody for its `` unusually complex characters '' .
Troy Island Mell , of IGN , felt that the story `` would -LRB- not -RRB- be anywhere near as good as it is without its ability to create such strong characters '' .
Jeremy Mullin , another IGN reviewer , disagreed with Mell and Rich ; he felt that the characters were not brilliantly done , though he noted that they introduced some drama and romantic tension usually not found on Nickelodeon , especially between Aang and Katara .

Weak anthropic principle : `` We must be prepared to take into account the fact that our location in the universe is necessarily privileged to the extent of being compatible with our existence as observers . ''
There are two different kinds of anthropic principles : the weak anthropic principle , and the strong anthropic principle .
The anthropic principle is a principle that says that the universe is how it is because it must allow for the eventual creation of us , as observers . The anthropic principle was thought of in 1974 , by the astronomer Brandon Carter .

Nevertheless , he finished with career highs of 16 goals and 35 assists for 51 points in just 60 games .
By the 1979 â `` 80 season , the emergence of young stars like Thomas Gradin , Stan Smyl and Curt Fraser , as well as the acquisition of several skilled veterans , had pushed Oddleifson into a mainly defensive role , and he finished the season with career lows of just 8 goals and 28 points .
He managed to crack the Bruins full-time in 1974 â `` 75 , highlighted by a four-goal game against the Golden Seals , the team that had given up on him two years earlier .
In 1972 â `` 73 , Oddleifson finally made his NHL debut , appearing in 6 games for Boston without recording a point .
Following his career , Oddleifson returned to Vancouver and became a successful real estate agent .
In 1975 â `` 76 , Oddleifson would have his finest NHL season , as he notched 16 goals and a club-leading 46 assists for a career high 62 points .
Oddleifson spent two more seasons playing in Switzerland before retiring in 1983 .
He remains active with the Canuck Oldtimers squad .

Christopher Roy Oddleifson -LRB- born September 7 , 1950 in Brandon , Manitoba -RRB- is a retired professional ice hockey player who played in the National Hockey League from 1972 until 1981 .
In 1977 â `` 78 , he recorded a career-high 17 goals for the club .
Late in the season , he was dealt to the Vancouver Canucks in a deal for sniper Bobby Schmautz , and he finished out his rookie season with decent totals of 13 goals and 29 points in 70 games between Boston and Vancouver .
He finished his NHL career with totals 95 goals and 191 assists for 286 points in 524 games , along with 464 penalty minutes .
He lead the Canucks in scoring through the early part of the season , until a fractured jaw forced him to miss 20 games .
Although his production waned somewhat in the next few seasons , he remained one of the team 's top all-around forwards and most popular players .
Early in the 1980 â `` 81 campaign , he was assigned to the Dallas Black Hawks , effectively ending his NHL career .
He was named team captain for 1976 â `` 77 , although he was replaced by Don Lever the following year .
He proved himself to be an exceptional all-around player who possessed size , toughness , and playmaking ability , as well as the ability to play both at center and on the wing .

Ender 's Shadow -LRB- 1999 -RRB- is a science fiction book that was written by Orson Scott Card . It is a parallel novel , which means it has a story that has some of the events in Ender 's Game from the point of view of another character named Bean .

The award was first introduced in 1956 by Commissioner Ford Frick in honor of Hall of Fame pitcher Cy Young , who died in 1955 .
The formula used to calculate the final scores is a weighted sum of the votes : Score = 5F + 3S + T , where F is the number of first place votes , S is second place votes , and T is third place votes .
Each league 's award is voted on by two members of the Baseball Writers Association of America in each league city , meaning 28 ballots are cast for the American League winner , and 32 for the National League .
The pitcher with the highest score in each league wins the award .
Each places a vote for first , second , and third place among the pitchers of each league .
The award was given to the best pitcher in the major leagues .
If two pitchers receive the same number of votes , the award is shared between the two .
In baseball , the Cy Young Award is an honor given to the best pitcher in the Major League Baseball .

Since he was working at the same time as DÃ 1\/4 rer , the most recognized artist at the time , one of his early woodcuts , `` Head of Christ '' , was thought to have been done by DÃ 1\/4 rer .
He is one of the most important of the `` Little Masters '' , a group of German artists making old master prints in the generation after Albrecht DÃ 1\/4 rer .
His book was mostly just a simplified book of DÃ 1\/4 rer 's own books , but his book was easier to use and cheaper than DÃ 1\/4 rer 's books , so artists preferred to buy his .
He worked on small , very detailed engravings -LRB- sometimes as small as a postage stamp -RRB- . This makes him part of the German printmaking school called the `` Little Masters '' , since their works were so small .
He created and published his works himself , but his larger works were mostly commissioned work to be sold .

Vetus Latina is the name given to a collection of Biblical texts that were translated into Latin before the Vulgate became the standard version used in the Latin-speaking world .
The Vulgate text means `` Glory -LRB- belongs -RRB- to God among the most high and peace among men of good will on earth '' .
The texts themselves are written in Late Latin , not in Old Latin .
Probably the best known difference between the Old Latin and the Vulgate is in the Pater Noster , where the phrase from the Vetus Latina , quotidianum panem , `` daily bread '' , becomes supersubstantialem panem , `` supersubstantial bread '' in the Vulgate .
The Old Latin text means , `` Glory -LRB- belongs -RRB- to God among the high , and peace -LRB- belongs -RRB- to men of good will on earth '' .

Kiloware usually consists of used stamps and commonly still on paper , although off paper stamps may also be sold as kiloware .

Swordfish is a particularly popular fish for cooking .
The International Game Fish Association 's all-tackle angling record for a swordfish was a 1,182 lb -LRB- 535.15 kg -RRB- specimen taken off Chile in 1953 .
Since swordfish are large animals , meat is usually sold as steaks , which are often grilled .
Swordfish are elongated , round-bodied , and lose all teeth and scales by adulthood .
The color of the flesh varies by diet , with fish caught on the east coast of North America often being rosier .
However , many sources including the United States Food and Drug Administration warn about potential toxicity -LRB- how poisonous it is -RRB- from high levels of methylmercury in swordfish .
Swordfish -LRB- Xiphias gladius -RRB- are large fish characterized by a long , flat bill .
They are a popular sport fish .

Human penis size is described by length and circumference of penis .
The size depends on arousal level , time of day , room temperature , frequency of sexual activity , and unreliability of the measurement methods .

It has been suggested that penis size differences between individuals may also be caused by environmental factors such as culture , diet , chemical\/pollution exposure , etc. .
Males may quite easily underestimate the size of their own penis compared to that of others because of looking down and the accumulation of fat at the base of the penis .

Flaccid length is not a reliable indication of erect length .
An adult penis with an erect length of less than 7 cm but otherwise formed normally is referred to as having the micropenis condition .

Age does not negatively correlate with penis size .

Nereid or Neptune II , is a moon of Neptune .
The unusual orbit suggests that it may be a captured asteroid or Kuiper belt object , or possibly that it was perturbed during the capture of Neptune 's largest moon Triton .
It is named after the Nereids , sea-nymphs of Greek mythology .
Nereid was found on 1 May 1949 by Gerard P. Kuiper , who suggested the name in the report of his discovery .

Dragonflies are usually found around lakes , ponds , streams and wetlands . Their larvae , known as ` nymphs ' , are aquatic .
They have large multifaceted eyes , two pairs of strong transparent wings , and an elongated body .
When at rest , most damselflies hold their wings together above the body , whereas most dragonflies at rest hold their wings horizontally or occasionally slightly down and forward .
Dragonflies are predators which eat mosquitoes , and other small insects such as flies , bees , ants , and butterflies .
When at rest , most damselflies hold their wings together above the body , whereas most dragonflies at rest hold their wings horizontally or occasionally slightly down and forward . The eyes of dragonflies are larger , and touch each other .
Even though dragonflies possess six legs -LRB- like any other insect -RRB- , they are not capable of walking .

Shield volcanoes are known to form on other planets .
The largest known mountain in the solar system , Olympus Mons on Mars , is a shield volcano thought to be extinct .
Shield volcanoes usually occur along constructive boundaries or above hotspots . However , the numerous large shield volcanoes of the Cascade Range of northern California and Oregon are over a more complex environment .

The auditory system is the sensory system for the sense for hearing .
Sound waves traveling through the ear canal will hit the tympanum , or eardrum .
The outer ear is the folds of cartilage surrounding the ear canal . They are called the pinna .
They are then converted to nerve impulses in the cochlea .

Malcolm Charles Barber -LRB- b. March 4 , 1943 -RRB- is a scholar of medieval history , described as the world 's leading expert on the Knights Templar .
He is considered to have written the two most comprehensive books on the subject , The Trial of the Templars -LRB- 1978 -RRB- and The New Knighthood : A History of the Order of the Temple -LRB- 1994 -RRB- .
Barber was a Professor of Medieval European History in the Faculty of Arts and Humanities at the University of Reading in the UK , until his retirement in September 2004 .
He has been an editor for The Journal of Medieval History and written many articles on the Templars , the Cathars , various elements of the Crusades , and the reign of Philip IV of France .
Born in 1943 , Barber attended Walpole Grammar School in Ealing from 1954-1961 , followed by the University of Nottingham from 1961-1966 , where he received his Bachelors Degree in 1964 .

The solar power plant cost Â # 35 million and covers 77 hectares of land .
Just under 1,500 `` SOLON-Movers '' modules convert sunlight into environmentally friendly power , generating as much as the average consumption of the nearby town of Arnstein .
On the former wine-producing Erlasee estate near Arnstein in Bavaria , in southern Germany , SOLON has constructed what is currently the largest tracking photovoltaic solar power station in the world with an output of 12 MW .
The Erlasee Solar Park is located in one of the sunniest regions of Germany .
It took over the functions of the London School Board in 1903 , and Dr C W Kimmins was appointed chief inspector of the education department in 1904 .
London County Council -LRB- LCC -RRB- was the principal local government body for the County of London , during its whole existence -LRB- 1889-1965 -RRB- , and the first London-wide general municipal authority that was directly elected .
While the Conservative government of the day would have preferred not to create a single body covering the whole of London , their election promise to the Liberal Unionists led them to this policy .
The LCC inherited the powers of its predecessor the MBW , but also had wider authority over matters such as education , city planning and council housing .
It covered the area today known as Inner London and was replaced by the Greater London Council .
A later Government created the 28 metropolitan boroughs as lower tier authorities to replace the various local authorities in 1899 ; they assumed some powers of the LCC and shared others .
The creation of the LCC in 1889 , as part of the Local Government Act 1888 , was forced by a succession of scandals involving the Metropolitan Board of Works -LRB- MBW -RRB- , its predecessor , which had not been directly elected .
The LCC was the largest , most significant and ambitious municipal authority of its day .
The National Geographic Channel , also commercially abbreviated as Nat Geo , is an Asian subscription television channel that features non-fiction , factual programming involving nature , science , culture , and history , produced by the National Geographic Society , just like History and the Discovery Channel .
As of 2008 , the Asian version of National Geographic Channel is available in over 56 million homes .
NGC Asia has eight different channels feeds .
It was launched in 1 January 1994 in partnership and distribution with Star TV , a Hong Kong-based pan-Asian satellite network owned by Rupert Murdoch 's News Corporation , replacing the NBC Asia channel .

Due to the odd number of cylinders in each bank , V6 designs are unbalanced , what ever V-angle they use .
Some 90 Â V6 engines are built . They are usually based on V8 engines .
The first Buick V6 was a 90 Â , based on their 90 Â V8 .
The V6 has an end-to-end rocking motion . Counterweights on the crankshaft and a counter rotating balancer shaft compensate for some of the rocking motion .
In 1959 , General Motors built a heavy-duty 305 inÂ -LRB- 5 L -RRB- 60 Â V6 for use in their pickup trucks and Chevrolet Suburban . The engine was later enlarged to 478 inÂ -LRB- 7.8 L -RRB- for heavy truck and bus use .
This allows pairs of pistons to share crank pins -LRB- a connection on the crankshaft -RRB- .
Race cars are designed around the engine , and vibration is not as important .
It takes little work to change an V8 into a V6 engine . The problem is these engines are wider and have more vibration than a 60 Â V6 .
The first series production V6 was introduced by Lancia in 1950 .
The flat-6 boxer engine -LRB- 180 Â -RRB- is only slightly wider than the 120 Â V6 , and it is a fully-balanced .
60 degree V6 engines do not need balance shafts .
It is more complicated and not as smooth as the inline-6 . The V6 is more compact , more rigid , and less prone to vibrations .
A V6 engine often just called a V6 is an internal combustion engine with six cylinders . The engine has three cylinders on each side called banks .
The most efficient cylinder bank angle for a V6 is 60 degrees .
This still has some balance and secondary vibration problems .
Some of the first V6-cars were built in 1905 by the Marmon Motor Car Company .
Alfredo Ferrari , the son of Enzo Ferrari , was nicknamed Dino . He suggested building a 1.5 Litre V6 engine for Formula Two racing .
It is the second most common engine design in modern cars after the inline four .
A ` split ' crank pin is weaker than a straight one . Modern metallurgical techniques can produce a crankshaft that is strong enough to not break .
The Lancia V6 in 1950 used a 60 Â angle between the cylinder banks and a six-throw crankshaft . to achieve equally spaced firing intervals of 120 Â .
The Dino V6 was used in the Ferrari 246 Formula One car in 1958 .
In 1962 , the Buick Special offered a 90 Â V6 with uneven firing intervals .
Laverda showed a 996 cc V6 engined motorcycle at the 1977 Milan show .
More modern 90 Â V6 engine designs avoid vibration problems by changing the crankshafts design and firing timing . Balancing shafts are often used to remove the remaining vibration .
Then Ferrari built the Dino V6 .
Many V6 engines are narrower than the V8 engine . They work well with are and is well suited to the popular transverse engine front-wheel drive cars .
Other builders soon started using V6 engines .
The motorcycle was raced in the 1978 Bol d'Or 24 hour race .
It has largely replaced the inline-6 , which is too long to fit in many modern cars .
Each bank in a V6 has an odd number of pistons .
This produced a rough-running design . This was unacceptable to many customers .
60 Â V6 engines are not as well balanced .
120 Â could be thought of as the natural angle for a V6 . Each cylinder fires a power stroke every 120 Â of crankshaft rotation .

According to the website , the Library covers material that can not be found anywhere else in the world , such as information about projects where the United States and Israel worked together , and how Americans were treated during the Holocaust .
It explains that it got permission to use materials from the Library of Congress , from the American Jewish Historical Society , the Anti-Defamation League , the Simon Wiesenthal Center , the Israeli Foreign Ministry , and Prime Ministerâ s Office , Rabbi Joseph Telushkin -LRB- author of Jewish Literacy -RRB- , and dozens of other sources .
It has more than 13,000 articles and 6,000 photographs and maps about Jewish history , Israel , U.S.-Israel relations , the Holocaust , anti-Semitism , and Judaism .
The site is extremely well put together .
One has options to click on , such as history , women , biography , politics , Israel , maps , and Judaic Treasures at the Library of Congress , with each launching a person into a different realm .
The Jewish Virtual Library also has the Israel advocacy text `` Myths and Facts '' , edited by Mitchell Bard , in several languages .
JVL got awards from Britannica Internet Guide Selection , USA Today Hot Site , and the Best of the Jewish Web from the Jewish Agency for Israel , the Academic Excellence Award from Study Web and others .
Karen Evans of Indiana State University wrote that the site covers many different topics , with `` easily accessible , balanced information '' .
The website was first made in the late 1990s . It was first called The Jewish Student Online Research Center -LRB- JSOURCE -RRB- .
The website has all of the words of the Tanakh .
The Jewish Virtual Library has been used as a source by CNN , New York Times , BBC , CBS News , Fox News , The Los Angeles Times , USA Today , Business Week , and Bloomberg , among others .
John Jaeger , in an article published by the Association of College and Research Libraries , said of the Jewish Virtual Library : `` This library , once it is entered , is more like a living encyclopedia than it is anything else .

Mahmud Shah Durrani was the ruler of the Durrani Empire between 1801 and 1803 , again between 1809 and 1818 .
On July 25 , 1801 , Zaman Shah was deposed , and Mahmud Shah ascended to rulership .
He then had a chequered career ; he was deposed in 1803 , restored in 1809 , and finally deposed again in 1818 .
He died in 1829 .
He was the son of Timur Shah Durrani and half-brother of his predecessor , Zaman Shah .
Between his two stnts , the country was ruled by Shoja Shah , another of his half-brothers .

Black dwarfs are not confirmed to exist because it takes longer than the current age of the universe for a white dwarf to become one .
A black dwarf is created when a white dwarf becomes too cool . Then it can no longer create large amounts of heat and light .
