Social gerontologists may have degrees or training in social work , nursing , psychology , sociology , demography , gerontology , or other social science disciplines .
Most `` life extensionists '' believe the human life span can be altered within the 21st century .
Gerontology -LRB- from Greek : Î Î Ï Ï Î 1\/2 , geron , `` old man '' and - Î '' Î Î Î Î , - logy , `` study of '' -RRB- is the study of the social , psychological and biological aspects of aging .
It is distinguished from geriatrics , which is the branch of medicine that studies the disease of the elderly .
It includes Biomedical gerontology , also known as experimental gerontology and life extension , is a sub discipline of biogerontology that endeavors to slow , prevent , and even reverse aging in both humans and animals .
Curing age-related diseases is one approach , and slowing down the underlying processes of aging with the help of physical exercises is another .
Social gerontology is a multi-disciplinary sub-field that specializes in studying or working with older adults .
Social gerontologists are responsible for educating , researching , and advancing the broader causes of older people by giving informative presentations , publishing books and articles that pertain to the aging population , producing relevant films and television programs , and producing new graduates of these various disciplines in college and university settings .

Notre-Dame-de-Livaye is a commune . It is found in the region Basse-Normandie in the Calvados department in the northwest of France .
It soon spread to conservatives among the Baptists and other denominations during and immediately following the First World War .
The term `` fundamentalism '' has its roots in the Niagara Bible Conference -LRB- 1878 â `` 1897 -RRB- which defined those things that were fundamental to Christian belief .
The movement 's purpose was to reaffirm orthodox Protestant Christianity and zealously defend it against the challenges of liberal theology , German higher criticism , Darwinism , and other movements which it regarded as harmful to Christianity .
The term was also used to describe `` The Fundamentals '' , a collection of twelve books on five subjects published in 1910 and funded by Milton and Lyman Stewart
Fundamentalism began as a movement in the U.S. , starting among conservative Presbyterian academics and theologians at Princeton Theological Seminary in the first decade of the Twentieth Century .

GÃ del 's work has had a big impact on scientific and philosophical thinking in the 20th century . Many people , such as Bertrand Russell , A. N. Whitehead , and David Hilbert , tried to use logic and set theory at that time .
The theorems were published in 1931 . He was 25 years of age , and had just finished his doctorate at the University of Vienna one year earlier .
To prove this theorem , GÃ del developed a technique now known as GÃ del numbering , which codes formal expressions as natural numbers .
He also showed that the continuum hypothesis can not be disproved from the accepted axioms of set theory , if those axioms are consistent .
He made important contributions to proof theory . He did this by clarifying the connections between classical logic , intuitionistic logic , and modal logic .

In the United States , `` yogurt ' '' is the usual spelling .
Yoghurt , or yogurt , is a dairy product made by bacterial fermentation of milk .
It was introduced to the United States in 1947 , by Dannon .
Yoghurt with fruit jam added to it was patented in 1933 by the RadlickÃ MlÃ kÃ rna dairy in Prague .
By the late 20th century yoghurt had become a common food in America and Colombo Yogurt was sold in 1993 to General Mills , who stopped using the brand name in 2010 .
The milk is heated to about 80 Â C to kill any bad bacteria and to change the milk proteins so that they set together instead of becoming curds .
Mechnikov believed that Lactobacillus was needed for good health , and worked to make yoghurt popular through Europe .
Stamen Grigorov -LRB- 1878 â `` 1945 -RRB- , a Bulgarian student of medicine in Geneva , first examined the bacteria in Bulgarian yoghurt .
In 1907 the rod-like bacteria was called Lactobacillus bulgaricus -LRB- now Lactobacillus delbrueckii subsp .
The word is usually said with a short o in the UK , with a long o -LRB- \/ Ë joÊ É É rt \/ -RRB- in North America , Australia and South Africa , and with either a long or short o in New Zealand and Ireland .
In the United Kingdom `` yoghurt '' and `` yogurt '' are both used , but `` yoghurt '' is more common , and `` yoghourt '' is also sometimes used .
Lactic acid acts on the protein in the milk to make yoghurt thick and sour .
In the 1950s and 60s yoghurt became very popular in the United States because it was sold as a health food .
Both texts mention the word `` yoghurt '' in different sections and describe how it was used .
The grateful French king spread around the information about the food which had cured him .
Lactic acid acts on the protein in the milk to make yoghurt thick and sour . Yoghurt made from cow 's milk is called dairy yoghurt .
After it is cooled to about 45 Â C , the bacteria culture is added , and the milk is kept at that temperature for 4 to 7 hours to ferment .
The oldest writings mentioning yogurt were by Pliny the Elder , who said that some people knew how to thicken the milk into something which was sour but tasty .
Many people who are lactose-intolerant can enjoy yoghurt , because much of the lactose in the milk has become lactic acid .
In Canada , `` yogurt '' is most common among English speakers , but many brands use `` yogourt , '' because it is correct in both French and English .
Yoghurt made from cow 's milk is called dairy yoghurt .
A study in the International Journal of Obesity -LRB- 11 January 2005 -RRB- found that eating low-fat yoghurt can help weight loss .
The use of yoghurt by medieval Turks is recorded in the books Diwan Lughat al-Turk by Mahmud Kashgari and Kutadgu Bilig by Yusuf Has Hajib written in the 11th century .
Yoghurt has a lot of protein , calcium , riboflavin , vitamin B6 and vitamin B12 in it .
In Australia and New Zealand `` yoghurt '' is the main spelling .

In 1919 , a Sephardic Jewish entrepreneur named Isaac Carasso started a small yoghurt business in Barcelona and named the business Danone -LRB- `` little Daniel '' -RRB- after his son .
Until the 1900s , yoghurt was eaten all the time by people in the Russian Empire -LRB- and especially Central Asia and the Caucasus -RRB- , Western Asia , South Eastern Europe\/Balkans , Central Europe , and India .
Yoghurt was first brought to the United States by Armenian immigrants Sarkis and Rose Colombosian , who started `` Colombo and Sons Creamery '' in Andover , Massachusetts in 1929 .
Colombo Yogurt was first sent around New England in a horse-drawn wagon with the Armenian word `` madzoon '' written on it . This was later changed to `` yogurt '' , the Turkish name of the product .
Yoghurt also has medical uses . and in preventing antibiotic-associated diarrhea .

This and other observations of acquired immunity was later exploited by Louis Pasteur -LRB- 1822-1895 -RRB- in his development of vaccination and his proposed Germ theory of disease .
Primary response can take 2 days to even 2 weeks to develop .
Immunology made a great advance towards the end of the 19th century , through rapid developments , in the study of humoral immunity and cellular immunity .
The earliest known mention of immunity was during the plague of Athens in 430 BC .
Immunology is a science that examines the structure and function of the immune system .
Pasteur 's theory was in direct opposition to contemporary theories of disease , such as the miasma theory .
Common autoimmune diseases include Hashimoto 's thyroiditis , rheumatoid arthritis , diabetes mellitus type 1 , and lupus erythematosus .
In some organisms , the immune system has its own problems within itself , called disorders . These result in other diseases , including autoimmune diseases , inflammatory diseases and possibly even cancer .
This process of acquired immunity is the basis of vaccination .
Particularly important was the work of Paul Ehrlich -LRB- 1854-1915 -RRB- , who proposed the side-chain theory to explain the specificity of the antigen-antibody reaction ; his contributions to the understanding of humoral immunity were recognized by the award of a Nobel Prize in 1908 , which was jointly awarded to the founder of cellular immunology , Ilya Mechnikov -LRB- 1845-1916 -RRB- .
In the 18th century , Pierre-Louis Moreau de Maupertuis made experiments with scorpion venom and observed that certain dogs and mice were immune to this venom .
The system mounts stronger attacks each time the pathogen is encountered .
After the body gains immunity towards a certain pathogen , when infection by that pathogen occurs again , the immune response is called the secondary response .
It originates from medicine and early studies on the causes of immunity to disease .
Immunodeficiency can either be the result of a genetic -LRB- inherited -RRB- disease , or an infection , such as the acquired immune deficiency syndrome -LRB- AIDS -RRB- , that is caused by the retrovirus HIV , or other causes .
In contrast , autoimmune diseases result from an immune system that attacks normal tissues as if they were foreign organisms .
Viruses were confirmed as human pathogens in 1901 , with the discovery of the yellow fever virus by Walter Reed -LRB- 1851-1902 -RRB- .
It was not until the proofs of Robert Koch -LRB- 1843-1910 -RRB- published in 1891 , for which he was awarded a Nobel Prize in 1905 , that microorganisms were confirmed as the cause of infectious disease .
Immunodeficiency diseases occur when the immune system is less active than normal .
Thucydides -LRB- 460-395 BC -RRB- noted that people who had recovered from a previous bout of some diseases could nurse the sick without contracting the illness a second time .

The DC motor is made in two parts ; the rotating armature and the fixed field windings .
This was achieved by an accelerating relay in the motor circuit . This was often called a notching relay .
AC induction motors known as asynchronous traction motors .
Before the mid-20th century , a single large motor was often used to drive multiple wheels through connecting rods . This was the same way that steam locomotives would turn their drive wheels .
A series-wound motor has the armature and the field windings connected in series .
As the DC motor starts to turn , the magnetic fields inside start to join together . They create an internal voltage .
The motor will stop increasing its speed when the torque matches -LRB- is the same as -RRB- the drag on the train .
When no resistors are left in the circuit , full line voltage is applied directly to the motor .
The rotating shaft of the motor was also the axle for the wheels .
The armature is connected to the field windings through brushes . The brushes are spring loaded contacts pressing against the commutator .
As the motor speeds up , the EMF falls . Less current flows into the motor , and it makes less torque .
The field windings are made of tightly wound coils of wire inside the motor case .
They are also used in electric vehicles , such as electric milk floats , elevators , and conveyors . Vehicles with electrical transmission systems such as Diesel-electric locomotives , electric hybrid vehicles and battery powered electric vehicles .
On an electric train , the train driver originally had to control the speed by changing the resistance manually . By 1914 , automatic acceleration was being used .
Railroad first used DC motors . These motors usually ran on about 600 volts .
The `` Bi-Polar '' electric locomotives built by General Electric for the Milwaukee Road had direct drive motors .
Usually , the traction motor is mounted between the wheel frame and the driven axle . This is called a `` nose-suspended traction motor '' .
Traditionally road vehicles -LRB- cars , buses and trucks -RRB- have used diesel or gasoline engines with a transmission .
Now , the normal practice is to use one traction motor to drive each axle through a gear drive .
Traction motor refers to a type of electric motor . A traction motor is used to make rotation torque on a machine .
A series-wound DC motor has a low electrical resistance .
All the driver had to do was select low , medium or full speed . These speeds are called shunt , series and parallel from the way the motors were wired .
Resistors are used to limit the current when the motor starts .
When voltage is applied to the motor , it makes a strong magnetic field inside the motor . This produces a high amount of torque , so it is good for starting a train .
Because of the high power levels used by traction motors , they create a lot of heat .

This works by convection ; the heat is taken from the relatively warm object to the relatively cold coolant .
Absolute zero is also 0 K on the Kelvin scale and 0 Â R on the Rankine scale
Fluids used to cool objects are called coolants .
Air cooling making the temperature of an object lower using air .
The coldest possible temperature is â ' 273.15 Â C , which can be expressed as about -459.67 Â F on the Fahrenheit scale . This is called absolute zero .
Other ways to cool objects include using ice , dry ice , or liquid nitrogen .
This will only work if the air is at a lower temperature than the object . The process will work better if there is more surface area on the object or if the item 's mass can be made smaller .

The Civil Polices of Brazil had origin in the General Intendancy of Police , created in Rio de Janeiro in 10 of May of 1808 .
The services of judiciary police are given through the Police stations of Police , agencies that have jurisdiction on small cities or quarters of the great cities .
27 Civil Polices in Brazil , one for each State of the federacy exist .
Today , the constitutional existence of the Civil Police and its attributions elapse of article 144 , IV and 144 Â 4 Â , of the Federal Constitution .
They had been gradually if developing for all country during the governments Imperial and Republican .
The Civil Polices are agencies of the public administration of the federative units of Brazil , whose function is , in accordance with article 144 of the Federal Constitution of 1988 , the exercise of the public security for the preservation of the public order , of the safety of the people and the patrimony .
They are directed by a Head of Police , chosen amongst the Commission agents of Police of career .
Each of the states of Brazil has its own `` Civil Police Department '' , which carries out detective work , forensics and criminal investigation , acting as a state bureau of investigation .
In Brazil , the Civil Police is the name of the investigative state police forces .

The NHM is one of the four large institutions on Exhibition Road in South Kensington , London . The others are the Science Museum , the Victoria and Albert Museum and Imperial College London .
In 1986 , the museum absorbed the adjacent Geological Museum of the British Geological Survey , which is to immediately to the north of the NHM .
The museum 's galleries were completely rebuilt and relaunched in 1996 as The Earth Galleries , with the other exhibitions in the Waterhouse building retitled The Life Galleries .
The Natural History Museum 's own Mineralogy displays remain largely unchanged as an example of the 19th-century display techniques of the Waterhouse building .
Built in two phases , with two new buildings adjacent to the main Waterhouse building , it is the most important new project in the museum 's history .
The newly-developed Darwin Centre -LRB- named after Charles Darwin -RRB- is designed as a new home for the museum 's collection of tens of millions of preserved specimens , and new work spaces for the museum 's scientific staff .
The NHM was at first a department of the famous British Museum . When the present NHM building was opened in 1881 , it was then called the British Museum -LRB- Natural History -RRB- or BMNH .

In molecular biology , two nucleotides on opposite complementary DNA or RNA strands that are connected by hydrogen bonds are called a base pair -LRB- often abbreviated bp -RRB- .
In the Watson-Crick base pairing , adenine -LRB- A -RRB- forms a base pair with thymine -LRB- T -RRB- , and guanine -LRB- G -RRB- with cytosine -LRB- C -RRB- in DNA .

The orbits of centaurs change from time to time because of interactions with the giant planets .
At perihelion -LRB- closest approach to the Sun -RRB- , it moves closer to the Sun than Uranus , while at aphelion -LRB- farthest approach to the Sun -RRB- it goes even farther thanNeptune .
7066 Nessus is a centaur -LRB- a type of icy planetoid -RRB- that was found by David L. Rabinowitz , working with Spacewatch , at Kitt Peak on 26 April , 1993 .
Nessus is thought to have a fairly long orbital half-life of about 4.9 Myr .
It was the second centaur found by him -LRB- 5145 Pholus being his first -RRB- , and the third centaur to be found -LRB- 2060 Chiron was the first -RRB- .
Nessus finishes one orbit around the Sun in 122.4 years , an eccentricity of 0.52 and an inclination to the ecliptic of 15.6 degrees .

This was famously disapproved by Tanenbaum in the Tanenbaum-Torvalds debate .
-LRB- Tanenbaum explained again his rationale for using a microkernel in May 2006 . -RRB-
Its licensing fee was very small -LRB- $ 69 -RRB- compared to the ones of other operating systems .
MINIX is a Unix-like computer operating system based on a microkernel architecture . Andrew S. Tanenbaum wrote the operating system so it could be used for educational purposes ; MINIX also helped Linus Torvalds design the Linux kernel .
Although Tanenbaum wished for MINIX to be as easily available to students , his publisher would not allow it .
The design principles Tanenbaum applied to MINIX had influenced the design decisions Linus Torvalds applied in the creation of the Linux kernel .
It contains X11 , emacs , vi , cc , gcc , perl , python , ash , bash , zsh , ftp , ssh , telnet , pine , and over 400 other common UNIX programs .
Released under the BSD license , MINIX is free and open source .
Torvalds used and appreciated MINIX , but his design was different from the MINIX architecture in significant ways , most notably by employing a monolithic kernel instead of a microkernel .
In May 2004 Kenneth Brown of the Alexis de Tocqueville Institution raised the accusation that major parts of the Linux kernel had been copied from MINIX , in a book called Samizdat .
These accusations were refused by almost everyone - in particular by Andrew Tanenbaum , who strongly felt that Kenneth Brown was very wrong and published a long rebuttal on his own personal website .
When free\/open source Unix-like operating systems such as Linux became available in the early 1990s , many volunteer software developers stopped using MINIX for Linux .
Andrew S. Tanenbaum created MINIX at Vrije Universiteit in Amsterdam .
In April 2000 , MINIX became free\/open source software under a permissive free software licence , but by this time other operating systems were much better , and it was mostly used as an operating system for students and hobbyists .

He was the second son of Emperor Kimmei by his consort Iwahime , who was a daughter of Emperor Senka .

The British Rail Class 09 is a class of 0-6-0 diesel locomotive designed primarily for shunting but also short distance freight trips along branch lines .
For this reason , though similar to the existing Class 08 shunting locomotives , Class 09s were re-geared to give a maximum top speed of 27.5 mph -LRB- 44 km\/h -RRB- at the expense of a lower tractive effort .

`` Mean Mr. Mustard '' is a song written by John Lennon -LRB- credited to Lennon\/McCartney -RRB- and performed by The Beatles on their album , Abbey Road .
As with the performance of `` She 's Leaving Home '' also in the film , the computerized singing of the Computerettes was performed by the Bee Gees .
Additionally , the original version of the song was a quieter acoustic rendition and was over 4 minutes in length .
According to Lennon , `` In ` Mean Mr. Mustard ' , I said ` his sister Pam ' â '' originally it was ` his sister Shirley ' in the lyric .
The Abbey Road version was recorded with `` Sun King '' in one continuous piece .
The version in the Sgt. Pepper 's Lonely Hearts Club Band film was performed by Mean Mr. Mustard -LRB- played by Frankie Howerd -RRB- and his evil robot companions named the Computerettes .
Written in India , Lennon said that the song was inspired by a newspaper story about a miser who hid his cash wherever he could so he can stop people from making him spend it .
A demo version of the song was recorded in May 1968 at Kinfauns , George Harrison 's home in Esher , and appears on Anthology 3 .
In that version , Mustard 's sister is named Shirley .
I changed it to Pam to make it sound like it had something to do with it . ''
Lennon changed it to Pam when he saw the ochance to ease the segue into the song `` Polythene Pam '' , which is after `` Mean Mr. Mustard '' on the album .
On reflection , he did n't think highly of the composition , describing it in Anthology as `` a bit of crap I wrote in India . ''

The Kara receives a large amount of fresh water from the Ob , Yenisei , Pyasina , and Taimyra rivers , so its salinity is very variable .
It is roughly 1,450 kilometres long and 970 kilometres wide . It has an area of around 880,000 kmÂ and a average depth of 110 m.

The Kara Sea is separated from the Barents Sea to the west by the Kara Strait and Novaya Zemlya , and the Laptev Sea to the east by the Severnaya Zemlya .
Significant discoveries of petroleum and natural gas , an extension of the West Siberian Oil Basin , have been made but have not yet been developed .

Its main ports are Novy Port and Dikson and it is important as a fishing ground although the sea is ice-bound for all but two months of the year .

TIFF has not had a major update since 1992 , though several Aldus\/Adobe technical notes have been published with minor extensions to the format , and several specifications , including TIFF\/EP , have been based on the TIFF 6.0 specification .
Adobe Systems , which acquired Aldus , now holds the copyright to the TIFF specification . TIFF has not had a major update since 1992 , though several Aldus\/Adobe technical notes have been published with minor extensions to the format , and several specifications , including TIFF\/EP , have been based on the TIFF 6.0 specification .
Tagged Image File Format -LRB- also known as TIFF -RRB- is a container format for storing images , including photographs and line art .
Originally created by the company Aldus for use with what was then called `` desktop publishing , '' TIFF is a popular format for color and black and white images . The TIFF format is widely supported by image-manipulation applications , by publishing and page layout applications , by scanning , faxing , word processing , optical character recognition and other applications .
It is now under the control of Adobe .
Adobe Systems , which acquired Aldus , now holds the copyright to the TIFF specification .
Noraduz cemetery is a medieval cemetery with many ancient khachkars in the village of Noraduz , Gegharkunik marz near Gavar and Lake Sevan , 90 km north of Yerevan .
During the revival of the khachkar tradition in the 16-17th centuries many khachkars were built under the yoke of the Safavid Empire when oriental influences seeped into Armenian art .
The oldest khachkars in the cemetery go back to the late 10th century .
According to one story the villagers placed helmets on top of the khachkars and leaned swords against them .
From a distance the khachkars looked like armed soldiers holding a defensive position as a result of which Tamerlaneâ s army retreated .
A popular folktale involving the cemetery concerns the invading army of Tamerlane .
Three master carvers from this period carved khachkars in Noraduz , the most notable of whom was Kiram Kazmogh -LRB- 1551-1610 -RRB- , his contemporaries were Arakel and Meliset .
Michigan Territory was a territory of the United States in the early 19th century , between June 30 , 1805 and January 26 , 1837 , when it became Michigan , the 26th state of the Union .
In 1800 , the whole of the Northwest Territory had 43,365 people living in it .
Detroit was the territory 's capital .
Under the Northwest Ordinance , a territory could apply to become a state once it had 60,000 people living in it .

Anthology is a compilation album by Canadian singer-songwriter Bryan Adams which contains songs he recorded from 1978 through 2005 .

The two disc set includes songs from 1980 -- 2005 .
All the songs are in chronological order of their release , except the last song on the first disc on the North American edition , which was released in 1999 .

Philosophical skepticism -LRB- Greek Ï Î Î Ï Î Ï - skepsis meaning `` enquiry '' -RRB- is a school of philosophical thought that began in Ancient Greece and a method that crosses many different cultures .
This skepticism can be either disbelief in philosophical solutions , agnosticism , or even rejecting the reality of the outside world .
In Islamic philosophy , philosophical skepticism was started by Al-Ghazali , known in the West as `` Algazel '' , as a part of the orthodox Ash ` ari school of Islamic theology .
Many skeptics examine the meaning systems of their times , and this can often result in a position of doubt .
One kind of scientific skepticism talks about looking into claims that lack evidence that can be seen .

From a geometric point of view , all points on a sphere are the same . One could select any point on the Earth , and create a paper map that covers the Earth with strips that come together at that point and the antipodal point .
The fact that the Earth is a sphere was established by Hellenistic astronomy in the 3rd century BCE . The earliest globe of the Earth appeared in that period .
This makes it easy to visualize how days and seasons change .
A copy of the globe showing America was made by Martin Waldseemueller in 1507 .
Early globes of the Earth that show all of the Old World were constructed in the Islamic Golden Age .
An example of a surviving celestial globe is part of a Hellenistic sculpture , called the Farnese Atlas . It survives in a 2nd century AD Roman copy in the Naples Museum , Naples , Italy .
Mass-produced globes are typically covered by a printed paper map .
One such example was made in the 9th century by Muslim geographers and cartographers working under the Abbasid caliph , Al-Ma ` mun .
Another early globe , the Hunt-Lenox Globe , ca .
Then a small disk is used to paper over the irregularities at the poles .
The earliest known example is the one made by Crates of Mallus in Cilicia -LRB- now Ã ukurova in modern-day Turkey -RRB- , in the mid-2nd century BCE .
The word `` globe '' comes from the Latin word globus , meaning round mass or sphere .
The most common type has long , thin gores -LRB- strips -RRB- of paper . These strips narrow to a point at the North Pole and the South Pole .
Another `` remarkably modern-looking '' globe of the Earth was made by Taqi al-Din at the Istanbul observatory of Taqi al-Din during the 1570s .
The more gores there are , the less stretching and crumpling is needed to make the paper map fit the sphere .
1507 , is thought to be the source of the phrase `` Here be dragons . ''
This mounting represents the angle of the planet in relation to its sun and the spin of the planet .
A globe is usually mounted at a 23.5 Â angle on bearings .
The oldest surviving globe of the Earth is credited to Martin Behaim in NÃ 1\/4 rnberg , Germany , in 1492 .
No globes of the Earth from Antiquity or the Middle Ages have survived .
Another example was the globe introduced to Beijing by the Persian astronomer , Jamal ad-Din , in 1267 .

Sveccha means one 's own wish or free will .
The term `` Paro '' means a mysterious or secret pattern to that action done by one 's own Will .
Doing one 's own Will .
The concluding Sanskrit expression in the Avadhoota Upanishad is `` Svecchachara Paro . ''
In other words , we do our Will but with discretion , not making it too obvious , nor to harm or hurt other people .
Svecchachara means a way of life where one acts as one wishes and does what is right in one 's own eyes .

Around 400 BC sphairai were introduced .
Later , the boxers began to fight while standing . They also started to wear gloves -LRB- with spikes -RRB- and wrappings on their arms below the elbows .
Korykos were the equivalent to modern punching bags .
People taking part trained on punching bags -LRB- called a korykos -RRB- .
However , Spartans never took part in the competitive version of boxing . They thought it was dishonorable to be defeated that way .
They were thongs of ox hide between 3 and 3.7 meters long . The himantes were wrapped around the hands and knuckles many times .
One legend says that the heroic ruler Theseus invented a type of boxing where two men sat face to face and beat each other with their fists until one of them was killed .
Boxing was one of the contests held in memory of Achilles ' friend Patroclus , who was killed toward the end of the Trojan War .
The sphairai were very similar to himantes .
According to Iliad , Mycenaean warriors included boxing in their competitions .
Fighters wore leather straps -LRB- called himantes -RRB- over their hands , wrists , and sometimes chest , to protect themselves from injury . The straps also left the fingers free .
Soon after the saphirai had been introduced , they were replaced by oxys used for boxing .
To commemorate Patroclus the Greeks later introduced boxing -LRB- pygme \/ pygmachia -RRB- to the Olympic Games in 688 BC .
Philostratus was a scholar and an historian . According to him , boxing was originally developed in Sparta , in order to harden warriorsâ faces for battle .
A band of fleece was placed on the forearm to wipe away sweat .
They were used for practice in the Palaestra and were filled with sand , flour , or millet .
Oxys were made of several thick leather bands that were wrapped around the hand , wrist , and forearm .
Many legends tell about the origins of boxing in Greece .
Leather braces extended up the forearm to give greater support when punching . The knuckles were reinforced with leather as well .
The early Spartans believed helmets were unnecessary and boxing prepared them for when they were hit on the head in battle .
Until around 500 BC himantes were used as protection for the knuckles and hand .
The biggest difference was that the inside was padded when they were wrapped around the hands . The outside of the thong was more rigid too .
In nature it is found as a mix of seven stable isotopes .
Ytterbium is found in minerals named gadolinite , monazite , and xenotime .
It has the chemical symbol Yb . It has the atomic number 70 .

Some Catholics have attempted to make theories of modesty .
Many Muslim women wear a headscarf -LRB- hijab -RRB- as a sign of modesty . More conservative societies expect that women cover their whole body , except for their hands and their face .
Non-orthodox Jewish women tend to adopt the fashions of the non-Jewish society in which they live .
The taqiyah cap may vary in shape , size or color just as the hijab does , with many regional differences according to tradition and personal taste .
Another example is Giuseppe Cardinal Siri of Genoa , who stated that trousers were unacceptable dress for women .
Sometimes this is from a sociological perspective , while at other times it takes a more systematic , Thomistic approach , combined with the writings of the Church Fathers .
In 1992 , New York State 's highest court accepted 14th Amendment arguments and struck down the provision in New York 's Exposure of the Person statute that made it illegal for women to bare their chests where men were permitted to do so .
Naturists have different views . They want to create an environment , were people can feel at ease , even when they are nude , they can be seen nude , or nude people are among them .
Some communities apply these standards to girls as young as three .
Some communities have stricter standards and expect women to cover their elbows and legs , with blouses covering the collarbone and sleeves covering elbows . Skirts are expected to cover the knees .
People are usually also subjected to peer pressure .
Excessive immodesty is called exhibitionism .
Approaches arguing primarily from traditional practices and traditional authorities , such as the saints , can also be found .
The Church also expects men to dress modestly , but the demands are not as strict for them as for women ; this is largely because men are often thought to be more inherently susceptible to sexual thoughts .
Pope Pius XII stated that women should cover their upper arms and shoulders , that their skirts should cover at least as far as the knee , and the neckline should not reveal anything .
Different fashions test the level of modesty .
Likewise , according to some Islamic interpretations of Hadith , men are required to cover everything from ` navel to knee ' ; with some men choosing to extend this to the traditional Islamic head covering taqiyah -LRB- cap -RRB- , the male counterpart to hijab which closely resembles the Jewish yarmulke but is slightly larger in size .
See-through materials may not be used and clothes are expected not to be tight-fitting , provocative , loud in color , or display texts .
Some people still insist on maintaining their standards of modesty , even in an emergency situation .
Proponents of modesty often see it as respect for their bodies and the feelings of themselves and others , and some people believe it may reduce sexual crimes .
Islamic society thinks modesty is important , but there are different interpretations of what dress should be considered modest .

Other active bushrangers included Dan Morgan , based around the Murray River , and Captain Thunderbolt , killed outside Uralla , New South Wales .
The increasing push of settlement , increased police efficiency , better rail transport and communications , such as telegraphy , made it increasingly difficult for bushrangers to evade capture .
In 1900 the Governor Brothers scared many people in the north of New South Wales .
Bushranging was common all over Australia , but Van Diemen 's Land -LRB- later known as Tasmania -RRB- produced the most violent and serious convict bushrangers .
Leading a gang of escaped convicts , Donahue became an important person in Australian folklore as the Wild Colonial Boy .
He was reported in newspapers around 1827 as being responsible for bushranging on the road between Sydney and Windsor .
Among the last bushrangers was the Kelly Gang led by Ned Kelly , who were captured at Glenrowan , Victoria in 1880 , two years after they were outlawed .
The bushrangers were busiest during the Gold Rush years of the 1850s and 1860s . Gold can be easily carried and also it can easily be turned into cash .
Indigenous Australian bushranger Musquito led attacks on settlers .
John `` Black '' Caesar was the first bushranger .
Bold Jack Donahue is recorded as the last convict bushranger .
He ran away from Sydney Cove several times before being shot dead in 1796 .
George Melville was hanged in front of a large crowd for robbing the McIvor gold escort near Castlemaine in 1853 .
Frank Gardiner , John Gilbert and Ben Hall led the most notorious gangs of the period .
In the 1830s he was regarded as the worst bushranger in the colony .
Hundreds of convicts were at large in the bush , farms were given up , and the army was brought in to try and capture the bushrangers .
Much of the bushranging in these years , was in the Lachlan Valley , around Forbes , Yass and Cowra .
Bushranging numbers grew in New South Wales with the rise of the colonial-born sons of poor , often ex-convict farmers , who wanted a more exciting life than mining or farming .

Alaska plaice feed mostly on polychaetes , but also eat amphipods and echiurans .
Like most flatfish , they live on the bottom of the continental shelf , up to 600 metres deep .
Their geographical range is from the Gulf of Alaska in the east , to the Chukchi Sea in the north , to the Sea of Japan in the west .
So many Alaska plaice get caught anyway that , for example , the 2005 total allowable catch in the Bering Sea and Aleutian Islands management area -LRB- BSAI -RRB- was reached before the end of May of that year .
Alaska plaice -LRB- Pleuronectes quadrituberculatus -RRB- are salt water fish that live in the north Pacific Ocean .
Alaska plaice can live for up to 30 years , and grow to 60 centimetres -LRB- 24 inches -RRB- long , but most that get caught are only seven or eight years old , and about 30 cm -LRB- 12 in -RRB- .

The band 's official website describes their music as simply `` rock '' or `` violent , dangerous pop '' .
Way has also said that his band patterns their career after that of The Smashing Pumpkins , another band they like .
However , Way has reportedly also described the band 's style as `` What-else-ya-got-emo '' .
Lead singer Gerard Way has stated that the band is very influenced by The Cure , Joy Division , Bauhaus , Siouxsie and the Banshees , and The Smiths\/Morrisey .
Way said to Rolling Stone , `` We love bands like Queen , where it 's huge and majestic , but also bands like Black Flag and the Misfits , who would go absolutely crazy . ''
Band frontman Gerard Way has publicly rejected the term `` emo '' , describing the genre as `` fucking garbage '' .

Harvey Bernard Milk -LRB- May 22 , 1930 -- November 27 , 1978 -RRB- was an American politician and a member of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors . He was the first openly gay man to be elected to public office in California .
Milk served 11 months in office and helped gay rights in the city .
Milk became an icon in San Francisco and `` a martyr for gay rights '' , according to University of San Francisco professor Peter Novak .
Anne Kronenberg , his final campaign manager , wrote of him : `` What set Harvey apart from you or me was that he was a visionary .
Milk was posthumously given the Presidential Medal of Freedom by President Barack Obama on August 12 , 2009 .
In 2002 , Milk was called `` the most famous and most significantly open LGBT official ever elected in the United States '' .
Milk moved from New York City to live in San Francisco in 1972 . This was a time when lots of gay men moved to live in the Castro District of San Francisco .

Beryl dropped moderate precipitation just offshore , though the maximum precipitation total in the United States was only 0.97 inches -LRB- 24.6 mm -RRB- on Nantucket .
Throughout much of its duration , the storm tracked through an environment with light vertical wind shear and well-established upper-level outflow .
Across southeastern Massachusetts , police departments maintained extra staff in preparation for any potential problems from the storm .
Shortly after becoming a tropical storm , the low-level circulation of Beryl became exposed with limited deep convection , though deep convection re-developed the following morning .
The only reported damage were some downed telephone poles and fallen tree branches .
About 22 hours before landfall , the National Hurricane Center replaced the watch with a tropical storm warning for the same area , and also issued a tropical storm watch from Woods Hole , Massachusetts westward to New Haven , Connecticut and for the eastern portion of Long Island from east of Fire Island to Port Jefferson .
Overall damage was minor .
Forecasters orginially predicted Beryl to brush the Carolinas ; as such , a tropical storm watch was issued for the eastern coast of North Carolina from Cape Lookout northward to Currituck Beach Lighthouse .
Moderate winds were reported along its path , which peaked at 60 mph -LRB- 96 km\/h -RRB- in southern Nova Scotia .
The depression moved slowly to the north-northwest through a break in the subtropical ridge , and as convective banding features became more visible the system strengthened into Tropical Storm Beryl .
Rainfall along southeastern Massachusetts reached 0.33 inches at Chatham .
Hours later , it made landfall in southwestern Nova Scotia , and on July 22 the extratropical remnants of Beryl merged with an approaching cold front over Newfoundland .
Beryl produced rough seas along the northeast United States coastline .
Beryl later produced moderate rainfall and gusty winds across Atlantic Canada , resulting in some localized power outages though little damage .
No deaths were reported .
In anticipation of heavy rainfall , the agency also issued heavy rainfall warnings for western Nova Scotia , including Halifax .
Several days prior to the passage of Beryl through Atlantic Canada , the Canadian Hurricane Centre issued gale warnings for the coastal waters off of Nova Scotia and Newfoundland .
High surf was also reported along the southern coast of Massachusetts and Rhode Island .
Local Red Cross chapters were opened , as well , with two volunteer teams placed on standby to assist .
Many fishermen secured their boats , while some business owners boarded up windows to prevent storm damage .
Late on July 20 , it began a slow weakening trend after passing over cooler waters .
The convection diminished as it moved through progressively colder waters , and shortly after 1200 UTC on July 21 Beryl became an extratropical cyclone a short distance east of Cape Cod .
After turning to the northeast , Beryl weakened over cooler waters .
Developing from a tropical disturbance on July 18 , it tracked generally northward , and strengthened to attain peak winds of 60 mph -LRB- 95 km\/h -RRB- under generally favorable conditions .
The rainfall caused some flooding , with some overflown streams flooding some streets .
Overall impact was minor ; there were no reported power outages , deaths , injuries , or maritime emergencies in association with the storm .
Waves along the southern coast of Nantucket reached 10 feet in height as the storm approached the island , resulting in four people being rescued by lifeguards from rip currents .
The extratropical remnants continued northeastward through Nova Scotia , and on July 22 it merged with an approaching cold front .
Steering winds ahead of an approaching mid-level trough caused Beryl to speed up northeastward , and early on July 21 the center of the storm crossed the island of Nantucket .
In Massachusetts , its impact was limited to light rainfall and gusty winds , with no reported damage .
The remnants of Beryl dropped moderate precipitation in Atlantic Canada , officially peaking at 2.8 inches -LRB- 71 mm -RRB- in Scotts Bay , Nova Scotia with an unofficially higher total of 3.5 inches -LRB- 88 mm -RRB- ; in some locations 1 inch of rain fell in an hour .
Outflow continued to improve , and with warm sea surface temperatures Beryl slowly strengthened further to reach peak winds of 60 mph -LRB- 95 km\/h -RRB- early on July 20 while located about 120 miles -LRB- 190 km -RRB- east of Nags Head , North Carolina .
Tropical Storm Beryl was the third tropical storm of the 2006 Atlantic hurricane season .
Winds across southeastern Massachusetts were fairly light , with no sustained tropical storm force winds and wind gusts peaking at 44 mph ; unofficially gusts reached 51 mph .
On July 21 it struck the island of Nantucket , and shortly thereafter it became extratropical .
A cold front moved off the East Coast of the United States on July 16 and stalled off the coast of North Carolina .
Beryl also produced a storm surge of 0.9 feet on Nantucket .
The first low quickly organized into an unnamed tropical storm , and the other area stayed broad and disorganized .
However , by July 18 , the system became much better organized with improved banding features , and the area developed into Tropical Depression Two while located 220 miles -LRB- 355 km -RRB- south-southeast of Cape Hatteras .
Beryl maintained peak winds for about 18 hours as it paralleled the Mid-Atlantic and New Jersey coasts , during which an eye-like feature developed in the center of the convection .
It slowly decayed into a surface low pressure trough , and developed into two disturbances ; one was centered 290 miles -LRB- 490 km -RRB- south-southeast of Cape Cod and another was located 200 miles -LRB- 320 km south of Cape Hatteras , North Carolina .
The winds downed some tree limbs and led to some power outages .
Additionally , a station in Fredericton , New Brunswick reported 1.77 inches -LRB- 45 mm -RRB- in 2 hours .
The storm caused high waves along the East Coast of the United States , with 19 foot seas -LRB- 5.97 m -RRB- in the open ocean .
Expecting for the storm , the Massachusetts Emergency Management Agency was activated as a trial run for the hurricane season .
When a more northeastward track became apparent , a tropical storm watch was issued about 33 hours before moving ashore from Woods Hole to Plymouth , Massachusetts , including Cape Cod , Nantucket , and Martha 's Vineyard .

Also , the French historian Thuanus thought Waldo died in the year 1179 .
Centuries after his death , the Waldensian denomination joined the Genevan or Reformed branch of the Protestant Reformation .
The Roman Catholic Church began to persecute the Waldensians , and many were tried and sentenced to death in different European countries during the 12th , 13th , and 14th centuries .
In 1179 , Waldo and one of his followers went to Rome , where they were welcomed by Pope Alexander III , and the Roman Curia .
Between 1175-1185 , Waldo either had a cleric from Lyons translate the New Testament of the Bible into the language that most people spoke , the Arpitan -LRB- Franco-Proven Ã al -RRB- language , or translate it himself .
Peter Waldo , Valdo , or Waldes -LRB- c. 1140 -- c. 1218 -RRB- , also Pierre VaudÃ s or de Vaux , is believed by many to have started the Waldensians . This was a Christian spiritual movement of the Middle Ages .
Sent away from Lyon , Waldo and his followers moved to the high valleys of Piedmont , and in France , in the Luberon .
They had to explain what they believed in front of a panel of three clergymen , including issues which were then debated within the Church .
Finally , Waldo was excommunicated by Pope Lucius III during the synod held at Verona in 1184 , and the doctrine of the Poor of Lyon was again condemned by the Fourth Lateran Council in 1215 where they are mentioned by name for the first time , and called heresy .
The results of the meeting were inconclusive , and Waldo 's ideas , but not the movement itself , were condemned at the Third Lateran Council in the same year , although the leaders of the movement had not been yet excommunicated -LRB- kicked out of the Church -RRB- .
After this , he began living a radical Christian life . He gave his property to his wife .
By 1170 , many people were following him . These people were called the Poor of Lyon , the Poor of Lombardy , or the Poor of God who would spread their teaching abroad while dressed up as peddlers .
Often called the Waldensians -LRB- or Waldenses -RRB- , they were different from the Albigensians or Cathari .
Sometime not long before the year 1160 he was inspired by some events . One of these was hearing a sermon on the life of St. Alexius .

The average player can generally play around ten pieces from memory which they will aim to play very well , learning new pieces as and when they feel like it .
Qin pieces are usually around three to eight minutes in length , with the longest being `` Guangling San '' ã å '' # é æ # ã , which is 22 minutes long .
The rich tones of the qin can be categorised as three distinctively different `` sounds . ''
Nowadays , many qin players perform at concerts in large concert halls , almost always , out of necessity , using electronic pickups or microphones to amplify the sound .
Traditionally , the qin was played in a quiet studio or room by oneself , or with a few friends ; or played outdoors in places of outstanding natural beauty .
The first is san yin ã '' æ # é ã , which means `` scattered sounds . ''
According to tradition , the qin originally had five strings , representing the five elements of metal , wood , water , fire and earth .
The twisted cord of strings is then wrapped around a frame and immersed in a vat of liquid of natural glue that binds the strands together .
It can also be called qixianqin ã ä ç ç ã -LRB- `` seven-stringed instrument '' -RRB- .
Later in the Tang dynasty , Cao Rou -LRB- æ æ '' -RRB- and others simplified the notation , using only the important elements of the characters -LRB- like string number , plucking technique , hui number and which finger to stop the string -RRB- and combined them into one character notation .
By the 20th century , there had been attempts to try to replace the shorthand notation , but so far , it has been unsuccessful ; since the 20th century , qin music is generally printed with staff notation above the qin tablature .
An earlier form of music notation from the Tang era survives in just one manuscript , dated to the 7th century CE , called Jieshi Diao : You Lan ã ç cents # ç è å 1\/2 è ã -LRB- Solitary Orchid , in Stone Tablet Mode -RRB- .
Other famous pieces include `` Liu Shui '' ã æ æ ã -LRB- Flowing Water -RRB- , `` Yangguan San Die '' ã é 1\/2 é -- ä ç -- ã -LRB- Three Refrains on the Yang Pass Theme -RRB- , `` Meihua San Nong '' ã æ cents è ä å 1\/4 ã -LRB- Three Variations on the Plum Blossom Theme -RRB- , `` Xiao Xiang Shui Yun '' ã ç æ æ é ã -LRB- Mist and Clouds over the Xiao and Xiang Rivers -RRB- , and `` Pingsha Luo Yan '' ã å æ è 1\/2 é ã -LRB- Wild Geese Descending on the Sandbank -RRB- .
In old times , the se -LRB- a long zither with movable bridges and 25 strings , similar to the Japanese koto -RRB- was frequently used in duets with the qin .
Qin study was initially confined to China in ancient times . Today countries like Japan also have their own qin small traditions .
They sit facing one another , with the student copying the master .
It can , however , be played together with a xiao -LRB- end-blown bamboo flute -RRB- , with other qin , or played while singing .
In 1977 , a recording of `` Liu Shui '' -LRB- Flowing Water , as performed by Guan Pinghu , one of the best qin players of the 20th century -RRB- was chosen to be included in the Voyager Golden Record , a gold-plated LP recording containing music from around the world , which was sent into outer space by NASA on the Voyager 1 and Voyager 2 spacecrafts .
Because Robert Hans van Gulik 's famous book about the qin is called The Lore of the Chinese Lute , the qin is sometimes inaccurately called a lute .
This meant simply pluck the required string to sound an open note .
Players mainly learn popular well studied versions , often using a recording as a reference .
Because of this , traditional qinpu do not indicate them .
Many traditionalists feel that the sound of the fingers of the left hand sliding on the strings to be a distinctive feature of qin music .
In 2003 , guqin music was proclaimed one of the Masterpieces of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity by UNESCO .
Many qinpu compiled before the Ming dynasty are now lost , and many pieces have remained unplayed for hundreds of years .
By tradition the qin originally had five strings , but ancient qin-like instruments with 10 or more strings have been found .
This was partly due to the scarcity of high quality silk strings and partly due to the newer strings ' greater durability and louder tone .
Silk strings are made by gathering a prescribed number of strands of silk thread , then twisting them tightly together .
Furthermore , it is the case that nylon-wrapped metal strings can cause damage to the wood of old qins .
The modern form has been standardized from about two thousand years .
The style of singing is similar to that used to recite Tang poetry .
The surface board is round to represent Heaven and the bottom board flat to represent earth .
The top thicker strings -LRB- i.e. strings one to four -RRB- are further wrapped in a thin silk thread , coiled around the core to make it smoother .
If one did not have a teacher , then one had to work out the rhythm by themselves .
Other incorrect classifications -LRB- mainly from music CDs -RRB- include `` harp '' or `` table-harp '' .
The entire length of the qin -LRB- in Chinese measurements -RRB- is 3 feet , 6.5 inches , representing the 365 days of the year -LRB- though this is just a standard since qins can be shorter or longer depending on the period 's measurement standard or the maker 's preference -RRB- .
Normally , qin players will learn the rhythm of a piece through a teacher .
It was so successful that from the Ming dynasty -LRB- 1368-1644 -RRB- onwards , a lot of qinpu ã '' ç è ã -LRB- qin tablature collections -RRB- appeared , the most famous and useful being `` Shenqi Mipu '' -LRB- The Mysterious and Marvellous Tablature -RRB- compiled by Zhu Quan -LRB- æ å -RRB- , the 17th son of the founder of the Ming dynasty .
These are harmonics , and the player simply lightly touches the string with one or more fingers of the left hand at a position indicated by the white hui dots , pluck and then lift , creating a crisp and clear sound ringing sound .
é ã literally `` elegant gatherings '' -RRB- , at which a number of qin players , music lovers , or anyone with an interest in Chinese culture can come along to discuss and play the qin .
If one sings to qin songs -LRB- which is rare nowadays -RRB- then one should not sing in an operatic or folk style as is common in China , but rather in a very low pitched and deep way ; and the range in which one should sing should not exceed one and a half octaves .
In order for an instrument to accompany the qin , its sound must be mellow and not overwhelm the qin .
The earliest example of the modern shorthand tablature survives from around the 12th century CE .
The tablature will only be looked at if the teacher is not sure of how to play a certain part .
The ' -LRB- Chinese : å ç ; pinyin : gÇ '' qÃ n ; Wade-Giles : ku-ch ` in ; literally `` ancient stringed-instrument '' -RRB- is the modern name for a plucked seven-string Chinese musical instrument of the zither family .
Legend has it that the qin , has a history of about 5,000 years ; that the legendary people of China 's pre-history ; Fuxi , Shennong and Huang Di -LRB- the Yellow Emperor -RRB- , was involved in its creation .
Later , in the Zhou dynasty , Zhou Wen Wang å ` æ -- ç added a sixth string to mourn his son , Bo Yihou ä 1\/4 é ` è .
The third is an yin ã '' æ é \/ æ é \/ å é \/ è é ã , or `` stopped sounds . ''
Classical books such as Qin Shi , Qinshi Bu and Qinshi Xu have biographies of hundreds of more players .
Some famous players are also associated with some melodies , like Confucius and Qu Yuan .
Since qin tablature does not indicate note value , tempo or rhythm , the player must work it out for him\/herself .
This forms the majority of most qin pieces and requires the player to press on a string with a finger or thumb of the left hand until it touches with the surface board , then pluck .
It is mentioned in Chinese writings dating back nearly 3,000 years , and related instruments have been found in tombs from about 2,500 years ago .
Written qin music did not directly tell what notes were played like many outer musical instruments ; instead , it was written in a tablature detailing tuning , finger positions , and plucking technique , thus made up of a step by step method and description of how to play a piece .
The guqin is nearly always used a solo single instrument , as its quietness of tone means that it can not be heard over the sounds of most other instruments or an ensemble .
There have been many players throughout the ages . The instrument was a favorite of the scholars , so many artists played it .
The guqin is not to be confused with the guzheng , another Chinese long zither also without frets , but with moveable bridges under each string .
Dapu ã '' æ `` è ã is the conversion of old tablature into a playable form .
Because of the difference in geography in China , many qin schools known as qin pai -LRB- ç æ 3\/4 -RRB- developed over the centuries .
Some tablatures do indicate notes using the gongche notation system , or indicate rhythm using dots .
To enjoy qin songs , one must learn to become accustomed to the strange style some players may sing their songs to .
Although most contemporary players use nylon-wrapped metal strings , some argue that nylon-wrapped metal strings can not replace silk strings for their refinement of tone .
The second is fan yin ã '' æ é ã , or `` floating sounds . ''
Traditionally the instrument was called simply qin ã ç ã , but by the 20th century the term had come to be used on many other musical instruments as well -LRB- for example , the yangqin ã æ ç ã hammered dulcimer , the huqin ã è ç ã family of bowed string instruments , and the Western piano -LRB- Chinese : é 1\/4 ç ; pinyin : gÄ ng qÃ n ; literally `` steel stringed-instrument '' -RRB- -RRB- , so the prefix `` gu - '' ã å ã -LRB- meaning `` ancient '' -RRB- was added for clarification .
Until the Cultural Revolution , the guqin 's strings were always made of various thicknesses of twisted silk ã ç ã , but since then most players use modern nylon-flatwound steel strings ã é 1\/4 ç ã .
The qin is a very quiet instrument , with a range of about four octaves , and its open strings are tuned in the bass register -LRB- its lowest pitch is about two octaves below middle C , or the lowest note on the cello -RRB- .
His successor , Zhou Wu Wang å ` æ ç , added a seventh string to motivate his troops into battle with the Shang .
Such schools generally formed around areas where qin activity was greatest .
This meant that instead of having two lines of written text to describe a few notes , a single character could represent one note , or sometimes as many as nine .
The strings are taken out and left to dry , before being cut into the appropriate length .
Because qin tablature is so useful , logical , easy , and the fastest way -LRB- once the performer knows how to read the notation -RRB- of learning a piece , it is invaluable to the qin player and can not totally be replaced .
This notation form was called jianzi pu ã '' æ å -- è ã -LRB- literally `` reduced notation '' -RRB- and it was a great step forward for recording qin scores .
It is the longest music track included on the disc .
Each part of the qin has meaning , some more obvious , like `` dragon pool '' ã é 3\/4 æ ã and `` phoenix pond '' ã é æ 1\/4 ã .
The modern nylon-wrapped metal strings were very smooth in the past , but are now slightly modified in order to capture these sliding sounds .
But it would be a mistake to say that qin music has no rhythm or melody .
In the 1960s , Zha Fuxi discovered more than 130 qinpu that contain well over 3360 pieces of written music .
Thus , the xiao generally used for this purpose is one pitched in the key of F , known as qin xiao , which is narrower than an ordinary xiao .
It is written in a longhand form called wenzi pu ã '' æ -- å -- è ã -LRB- literally `` written notation '' -RRB- , which gives all the details using ordinary written Chinese characters .
Many qin players attend yaji -LRB- ã é é ã literally `` elegant gatherings '' -RRB- , at which a number of qin players , music lovers , or anyone with an interest in Chinese culture can come along to discuss and play the qin .
Sounds are produced by pluck open strings , stopped strings , and harmonics .
The thirteen hui ã å 3\/4 1\/2 ã on the surface represent the 13 months of the year -LRB- the extra 13th is the ` leap month ' in the lunar calendar -RRB- .
In addition to learning to play established or ancient pieces very well , highly skilled qin players may also compose or improvise , although the player must be very good and extremely familiar with the instrument to be successful at it .
Schwelm is a town in the district of Ennepe-Ruhr Rural District the state of North Rhine-Westphalia .
Schwelm is situated in the southeast of the `` Ruhrgebiet '' , the Ruhr Area of Germany , between Westphalia and the `` Bergisches Land '' .
Schwelm is home to the `` Brauerei Schwelm '' , the Schwelm Brewery , one of the few remaining private breweries in Germany .
The original office building of the brewery , the `` Rietz ` sche Haus '' built in 1701 , is still in use today .
The history of Schwelm goes back to the ninth century , where it is first mentioned as `` Suelmiu '' .
Schwelm is commonly known as the `` Pforte Westfalens '' -LRB- `` Gate to Westphalia '' -RRB- .
According to its area , Schwelm is the smallest town in North Rhine-Westphalia .

The city of Schwelm was officially established in 1496 and became seat of the Ennepe-Ruhr district in 1929 .

The 1992 World Cup , held in Australia and New Zealand , introduced many changes to the game , such as colored clothing , white balls , day\/night matches , and an alteration to the fielding restrictions .

The first three events were held in England and officially known as the Prudential Cup after the sponsors Prudential plc. .
The number of teams participating in the event increased from twelve to fourteen .
The matches consisted of 60 six-ball overs per team , played during the daytime in traditional form , with the players wearing cricket whites and using red cricket balls .

Australia won the championship by defeating England by 7 runs in the final , the closest margin in World Cup final history .
The tournament was won by the West Indies , who defeated Australia by 17 runs in the final at Lord 's .
The games were reduced from 60 to 50 overs per innings , the current standard , because of the shorter daylight hours in the Indian subcontinent compared with England 's summer .
The 1983 event was hosted by England for a third consecutive time .
In 2007 the tournament was hosted by the West Indies . The Cricket World Cup became the world tournament to be hosted on all six populated continents .

Germanicus 's forces smashed across the Rhine and quickly occupied all of the territory between the Rhine and the Elbe .
As a result , in AD 18 Germanicus was granted control over the eastern part of the empire , just as both Agrippa and Tiberius had received before , and was clearly the successor to Tiberius .
Finally , with Tiberius 's withdrawal to Capri in AD 26 , Sejanus was left in charge of the entire state mechanism and the city of Rome .
Tiberius -LRB- Tiberius Julius Caesar Augustus , 16 November 42 BC â `` 16 March 37 -RRB- was the second Roman Emperor . He ruled from 14 to 37 AD .
Sejanus began a series of purge trials of Senators in Rome .
Germanicus 's widow Agrippina the Elder and two of her sons were arrested and exiled in AD 30 and later all died in suspicious circumstances .
Then , in AD 31 , Sejanus was summoned to a meeting of the Senate , where a letter from Tiberius was read condemning Sejanus and ordering his immediate execution .
However , Tacitus ' portrayal of a tyrannical , vengeful emperor has been challenged by several modern historians .
Sejanus had served the imperial family for almost twenty years when he became Praetorian Prefect in AD 15 .
So Germanicus dealt a significant blow to Rome 's enemies , and quelled an uprising of troops , actions that increased his fame with the Roman people .
After being recalled from Germania , Germanicus celebrated a triumph in Rome in AD 17 , the first full triumph that the city had seen since Augustus 's own in 29 BC .
He was the step-son of Augustus .
Problems soon arose .
Germanicus rallied the mutineers and led them on a short campaign across the Rhine into Germanic territory , stating that whatever treasure they could grab would count as their bonus .
Germanicus and Tiberius 's son , Drusus , were dispatched with a small force to quell the uprising and bring the legions back in line .
Tiberius had statues of Sejanus erected throughout the city , and Sejanus became more and more visible as Tiberius began to withdraw from Rome altogether .
The prominent ancient historian Edward Togo Salmon notes in his work , A history of the Roman world from 30 B.C. to A.D. 138 : `` In the whole twenty two years of Tiberius ' reign , not more than fifty-two persons were accused of treason , of whom almost half escaped conviction , while the four innocent people to be condemned fell victims to the excessive zeal of the Senate , not to the Emperor 's tyranny '' .
Sejanus was tried , and he and several of his colleagues were executed within the week .
The death of Drusus elevated Sejanus .

In the Korean alphabet hangeul , í -LRB- è -RRB- signifies `` to strike with the foot '' ; ê -LRB- æ -RRB- to `` strike with the hand '' ; and ë -LRB- é `` -RRB- signifies `` way '' , `` road '' or `` route '' .
Taekwondo can therefore be translated as `` way of the foot and of the fist '' .
Breaking boards , for example , demonstrates a union of mental and physical discipline . Breaking a board with one 's hand or foot requires both the physical mastery of the technique and a concentrated focus on one 's force .
Taekwondo develops force , speed , balance , flexibility , and stamina .
Taekwondo as a sport and as an exercise is popular among people of both sexes and many ages .

Niels Bohr -LRB- October 7 , 1885 - November 18 , 1962 -RRB- was a famous Danish physicist who helped discover quantum physics , the structure of the atom , and the atomic bomb . Bohr was awarded the Nobel Prize in 1922 for , in short , discovering the quantization of atomic energy levels .

The nagamaki is considered to be a type of the no-dachi sword . This one was a variation of long samurai sword .
It was also sharpened along the back edge to reduce its weight .
Warriors used the weapon against horsemen .
The way to hold nagamaki was also very specific .
The nagamaki is designed for large sweeping and slicing strokes .
It also works as a spear .
Still , it required more time and materials to create a nagamaki than a spears or a naginata sword , this is why it was not so widely spread .
Traditionally , it was used as infantry weapon .
In contrast to it naginata is shorter , wider and more curved to the tip .
Unlike the naginata , the hands did not change when handling the weapon and the right hand was always the closest to the blade .
Nagamaki is a Japanese pole weapon with a large and heavy blade .
The blade was single-edged .
It was held with the two hands in a fixed position in the same way a katana sword is held .
Even the name `` nagamaki '' is given by the tradition of handle wrapping . The word `` nagamaki '' means `` long wrapping '' .
The closest exemplar of real nagamaki you can see today is nagamaki-naoshi .
The nagamaki was not spread and developed until much later like the naginata sword .
The nagamaki is considered the favored weapon of General Oda Nobunaga .
It appears to be like a long katana-shaped halberd , but straighter and thinner , with a very long tsuka .
While handling nagamaki not too many sliding actions on the handle were performed as it was in naginata 's case , where you use the entire length of the shaft .
During the middle of the Muromachi period -LRB- 1336-1600 A.D. -RRB- it reached its peak of usage .
The nagamaki handle was wrapped with cords in criss-crossed manner , very similar to the wrapping that is made on katana .
It was introduced and used primarily during the Kamakura -LRB- 1192 - 1333 -RRB- , Nanbokucho -LRB- 1334 - 1392 -RRB- and early Muromachi -LRB- 1392 â `` 1573 -RRB- periods .
It reminds a traditional naginata , but the main difference was that the handle -LRB- tsuka -RRB- of the nagamaki was not constructed of wood ; it was made more like a katana handle .
It is very much like a glaive .

The title of Formula One World Champion Constructor is given to the car make that scores the most points during the season . The `` make '' of a car includes both the chassis and engine .
n Minardi subsequently became Scuderia Toro Rosso .
a Arrows were known as Footwork from 1991 to 1996 .

j Ligier subsequently became Prost Grand Prix .
This list only shows chassis constructors for that reason .
s Sauber subsequently became BMW works team BMW Sauber , then reverted back to Sauber .
Because both engine and chassis are included in the make name , chassis run with different engines are counted as two separate makes . For example , Lotus-Ford is a make different from Lotus-BRM .
Rob Walker Racing Team was the most successful example . They earned the first victories in Formula One for both Cooper and Lotus .

The World Constructors ' Championship title is awarded to the constructor of the chassis of the make that scores the most points .
An entrant is the person or corporate entity that enters a race . They register a car and driver with the FIA .

The show has also featured guest mediums .
Fielding denied the claims .
So far these have been Ian Lawman , Ian Shillito , Gordon Smith , Uri Geller and Kevin Wade .
So far celebrities have included Vic Reeves , Nancy Sorrell , Gaby Roslin , Scott Mills , Mark Chapman , Simon Gregson , Sue Cleaver , Carol Thatcher , Paul O'Grady and Lee Ryan .
Even though O ' Keeffe exposed Acorah , the paper also claimed that O ' Keeffe had exposed the rest of the Most Haunted team .
Some episodes have also included at least one celebrity .
During the investigation , which was later broadcast , he presented the information as fact and even behaved as though being possessed by the fictional ghost .
Most of these on-screen crew members also take part in sÃ ances .
One such case that exposed Acorah was at Bodmin Gaol , Cornwall .
Most Haunted has a main presenter , a psychic medium and a parapsychologist .
Many times , former `` psychic medium '' Derek Acorah was possessed by a spirit , sometimes evil or sometimes `` lost and confused '' .
These are supported by some of the production crew , who appear in the show and generally have some involvement with many parts of the investigation as they are performing their normal crew role .
Acorah glossed over his mistake and changed the subject .
Before the filming , Acorah had been fed misinformation about a non-existent ghost of Kreed Kafer by the show parapsychologist Dr. Ciaran O ' Keeffe .
On the final night , at Berry Pomeroy , Fielding reminded Acorah that he had mentioned the incarcerated sister two nights prior .
On the first night filming `` Terror in Torbay '' , Acorah mentioned a woman incarcerated by her jealous sister in the cellar of Lupton House , even coming up with the names Margaret and Eleanor .
O'Keeffe later reported that he had been grossly misquoted and misrepresented in the article , and produced a response outlining his version of the show based on his observations and findings , saying he had exposed Derek Acorah and NOT Most Haunted .
O'Keeffe later revealed Kreed Kafer is an anagram of ` Derek Faker ' in a national newspaper .
Although not mentioned by O'Keeffe , the Mirror article also brought into question unedited footage which appeared to show Fielding and Karl Beattie faking ` paranormal ' occurrences such as ghostly bumps and knocks .
It is shown on the satellite and cable channels Living , Living2 and Virgin 1 -LRB- Formerly Ftn -RRB- , mainly for the UK market .
The show 's presenter and executive producer , Yvette Fielding said in an interview that she believes it was a fake possession .
This is the well-known legend of Berry Pomeroy Castle which was to be the last night 's location .

A barrel organ plays music by using turning a barrel , with notes decided by an arrangement of pins .
Stationary barrel organs , built into large houses or churches , were larger pipe organs , and could play longer , and more serious music .
Even a small hand carried organ could play six or eight tunes . Stationary barrel organs , built into large houses or churches , were larger pipe organs , and could play longer , and more serious music .
A barrel organ plays music by using turning a barrel , with notes decided by an arrangement of pins . It is very similar to a simple music box where the pins pluck a metal harp .

Modular Audio Recognition Framework -LRB- MARF -RRB- is a computer program that tries to understand voice , sound , speech , text and human language in general . In MARF , scientists and programmers write algorithms using Java .
There is also a lot of documentation of the project . MARF and its programs are published under a BSD-style license .
MARF itself can be piece in other computer programs or used for learning , education , and making MARF itself better .

Monocytes are produced by the bone marrow from stem cell precursors called monoblasts .
They are cells that possess a large smooth nucleus , a large area of cytoplasm and many internal vesicles for processing foreign material .
These are phagocytosis , antigen presentation and cytokine production .
Monocytes circulate in the bloodstream for about one to three days and then typically move into tissues throughout the body .
Macrophages are responsible for protecting tissues from foreign substances .
They are usually identified in stained smears by their large two-lobed nucleus .
Monocytes which migrate from the bloodstream to the tissues will then differentiate into macrophages or dendritic cells , which then stay in the tissue .
Monocytes and their macrophage and dendritic cell progeny serve three main functions in the immune system .
They make up three to eight percent of the leukocytes in the blood .
Monocytes are a type of white blood cell , part of the human body 's immune system .

In terms of botany it means the main structural member of a tree that is directly connected to the roots and which supports the branches . The trunk is also often called the bole .
The trunk , or bole , is the most important part of the tree for timber production .
The trunk is covered by the bark , which protects the tree against damage and often differs markedly from the bottom of the trunk to the top , depending on the species .

The important east\/west U.S. Highways usually have numbers ending in `` 0 '' and the important north\/south Interstates have numbers ending in `` 1 '' . Many of the routes ending in `` 0 '' or `` 1 '' used to go across the country , but no longer do because of the Interstate Highway System .

The British Transport Commission -LRB- BTC -RRB- was created by Clement Attlee 's post-war Labor government . It was a part of its nationalisation program .
Its objective was to provide an efficient , adequate , economical and properly integrated system of public inland transport and port facilities within Great Britain for passengers and goods , excluding transport by air .

For example , 1936 was the year of the Yang Fire Rat . 60 years later , 1996 was the next year of the Yang Fire Rat .
This means that anyone born from January 1 to January 25 , 1990 was actually born in the year of the snake not the year of the horse .
The year 1990 was the year of the horse .
The dates for the Spring Festival from 1996 to 2019 -LRB- in the Gregorian calendar -RRB- are at the right . The list also includes the year 's animal zodiac and its earthly branch .
Because the Chinese New Year starts in late January or early February , the Chinese year begins several weeks after the it begins in the Gregorian calendar . If a person is born in early January , their Chinese birth-year is the last Gregorian year , not the current one .
The names of the earthly branches have no English translations . They are not Chinese translations of the animals .
The elements are changed every two years and a yin and yang association changes every year .
The calendar has a 12-year cycle of the animal zodiac and a 10-year cycle of heavenly stems .
For example , 1989 was the year of the snake .
Some people had problems with the difference between the Chinese birth-year and the Gregorian birth-year .
Each of the ten heavenly stems is associated with one of the five elements of Chinese astrology . These elements are Wood , Fire , Earth , Metal , and Water .
The elements are named : Yang Wood , Yin Wood , Yang Fire , Yin Fire , and so on .
These two cycles create a combined cycle that repeats every 60 years .
It began on 26 January 1990 .

The Lachlan river is in the area where the aboriginal people called the Wiradjuri lived .
The Lachlan does not gets its water from melting snow like the Murrumbidgee River or the Murray River .
Water from this big -LRB- 500 kmÂ -RRB- swamp finally goes into the Murrumbidgee River . Water from the Lachlan is used for farming .
During the flood in August 1990 , 132 houses in Forbes were flooded . The water covered their floors .
The Lachlan River flows west and then south , finishes in the Great Cumbung swamp . This swamp is near Oxley between Hay and Balranald .
More than 900 families had to move away . Many were saved from roof-tops by boat and helicopter .
In 1944 the flow was less than 1,000 megalitres -LRB- 810 acre-feet -RRB- . Six years later -LRB- 1950 -RRB- there was a flow of 10,900,000 megalitres -LRB- 8.8 million acre feet -RRB- .
In 1870 the river flooded . The top of the flood water was measured at 15.9 metres at Cowra .
More than 100,000 people live in the Lachlan area .
Since 1887 , the highest flood level at Forbes was in June 1952 . The river got to 10.8 m -LRB- 35 feet 3 inches -RRB- at the Forbes Iron Bridge .
24 local governments look after the Lachlan area .
The Lachlan has flooded every 7 years since 1887 at Forbes .
The European who found the Lachlan River in 1815 was Acting-Surveyor George William Evans . He named the river after Lachlan Macquarie , the Governor of New South Wales .
In the early days of New South Wales , the south part of the Lachlan was known as Fish River .
With more exploration it was realized that two rivers were the same river and the name Fish River was dropped .
The Wiradjuri land has been called `` the land of the three rivers , the Wambool -LRB- Macquarie -RRB- , the Kalare -LRB- Lachlan -RRB- and the Murrumbidjeri -LRB- Murrumbidgee -RRB- .
The Murray River was the south side of Wiradjuri land . The change from forest to open grassland was the east side . ''
Wyangala Dam was built near Cowra to control the amount of water in the river .
At least 500 sheep were drowned on farms in the Eugowra\/Trundle area . Most of Eugowra 's 400 residents were moved for safety .
14 % of NSW farm goods come from the area which is about 10 % of NSW .
Other big floods were in : 1891 , 1916 , 1951 , 1956 , 1961 , 1974 , 1976 , 1993 , 1998 .
Floods in 1992 were smaller than 1990 , but Lachlan Valley farmers lost about 30 percent of their lucerne crops just before harvest .
The Lachlan River is an important river in central New South Wales , Australia .
The Lachlan River was explored by John Oxley in 1817 .
Other rivers that join the Lachlan River are the Carcoar River , the Belubula River and the Abercrombie River .
In dry years , for example April 1944 to April 1945 , the Lachlan may have no water flowing in it at all .
